questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes for a follow-up appointment with her outpatient provider. She underwent a partial thyroidectomy to treat localized thyroid cancer one week ago. Since the surgery, the patient has felt more tired and noticed puffiness on her face. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and osteoporosis. Family history is notable for Addison disease in her mother. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 141/76 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and weight is 82 kg. Physical examination reveals mild periorbital swelling. The patient is started on a dose of levothyroxine lower than that typically given to patients of similar body weight. Which of the following factors best explains this treatment approach?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypothyroidism symptoms following a partial thyroidectomy. As a result, she was started on levothyroxine (synthetic T4).

Patients with hypothyroidism are generally started on an initial levothyroxine dose based on body weight. The conversion ratio is 1.6 µg/kg/day. In other words, a patient weighing 75 kg would be started on 120 µg of levothyroxine daily. The dose can then be adjusted at follow-up appointments based on the patient’s symptoms and TSH levels.

However, certain patient groups should be started on a lower initial dose. These include the elderly, patients with heart disease (e.g. coronary artery disease), and patients with long-standing untreated hypothyroidism. These individuals should be started on 25-50 µg/day and increase the dose incrementally to avoid precipitating cardiac ischemia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ History of thyroid cancer:
Incorrect: Patients who undergo treatment for thyroid cancer (e.g., surgical resection, radioiodine ablation) can develop hypothyroidism if not treated with thyroid hormone supplementation. Individuals can be started on a normal initial dose of levothyroxine, generally 1.6 µg/kg/day.  
❌ Family history of adrenal insufficiency:
Incorrect: Levothyroxine therapy is contraindicated in patients with a personal history of poorly controlled adrenal insufficiency. However, a family history of adrenal insufficiency would not be a contraindication, and these patients can be started on a normal initial dose.  
❌ Family history of osteoporotic fractures:
Incorrect: Levothyroxine can increase bone turnover, increasing the risk of osteoporosis and fragility fractures. However, undertreated hypothyroidism can also cause significant complications, including depression, myopathy, bradycardia, and myxedema coma. As a result, patients with osteoporosis would generally receive a normal starting dose of levothyroxine  
❌ History of diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus can lead to complications, including coronary artery disease and renal failure. However, diabetes mellitus in and of itself would not be an indication to start the patient on a lower than usual dose of levothyroxine.  
✅ History of coronary artery disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old individual presents to their primary care physician for evaluation of recurrent sinus congestion. The patient states, “I’ve been using my nasal spray like crazy! I just can’t seem to unclog my nose!” The patient does not have any other medical history and does not take any other medications daily. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 166/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears nervous and is figiditing. Nasal examination demonstrates clear discharge from the nares bilaterally. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of nasal discharge and congestion and is noted to be hypertensive, agitated, and nervous on examination. The patient also endorses frequent use of nasal spray. Together, these findings are consistent with phenylephrine overuse, causing rebound nasal congestion.   

Phenylephrine is a selective α1 agonist without beta effects. This sympathomimetic is used to treat shock states (e.g. distributive shock), nasal congestion, epistaxis, hemorrhoids, and intraocular bleeding. Phenylephrine’s wide use owes to the fact that it is a potent systemic and local vasoconstrictor. In patients with nasal congestion, administration of phenylephrine vasoconstricts tortuous capillary beds, resulting in improvement in symptoms.    

Adverse side effects of phenylephrine include hypertension with possible concomitant reflex bradycardia. Additional side effects include headache, excitability, cardiac arrhythmias, and restlessness. Excessive use of intranasal phenylephrine can result in rebound nasal congestion.   

Option Analysis

✅ Phenylephrine :
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Fluticasone:
Incorrect: Fluticasone is a common intranasal medication used for the treatment of allergic rhinitis. Its primary side effects include central nervous system effects, such as headaches.   
❌ Albuterol:
Incorrect: Albuterol can cause nervousness and agitation due to beta agonist effects; however, it is not used for the treatment of congestion  
❌ Olopatadine:
Incorrect: Olopatadine is a selective antagonist of the H1 receptor used for the treatment of allergic rhinitis. Common side effects include headache and eye burning or stinging.   
❌ Cromolyn sodium:
Incorrect: Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer used in the treatment of allergic rhinitis. It does not carry sympathomimetic effects.

questions.text: A medication is currently under-review for administration in human clinical trials. The medication has been previously tested in rat models with the following observed changes in hemodynamic properties. Pharmacological data indicates this medication carries beta agonist properties without associated alpha agonism. Which of the following describes an appropriate clinical use of the medication described above?

choices.text: Acute heart failure with cardiogenic shock

questions.solution:
The medication described carries only beta agonist properties and is found to result in a widened pulse pressure, increased heart rate, decreased peripheral resistance, and ultimately decreased mean arterial pressure. These findings are consistent with the non-specific beta agonist isoproterenol, which can be used as an inhaled medication for the treatment of acute asthma exacerbations due to its agonistic effects on ß2 receptors.    

Isoproterenol is the prototypical non-selective beta agonist and is rarely used in clinical practice due to its hemodynamic effects. By stimulating ß2 receptors, isoproterenol results in bronchodilation and smooth muscle relaxation, causing decreased peripheral resistance and widened pulse pressure with subsequent reflex tachycardia. In concert, the ß1 effects result in an augmented tachycardia and cardiac stimulation.    

Isoproterenol carries little clinical utility in modern medicine but can be used as an adjunct for the treatment of acute asthma exacerbations, bronchospasm, refractory high grade AV block, or during evaluation of tachyarrhythmias. Side effects include excess sympathomimetic effects, predominantly arising from the sustained tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acute asthma exacerbation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute heart failure with cardiogenic shock:
Incorrect: Dobutamine is often used in the treatment of cardiogenic shock secondary to decompensated heart failure in an attempt to increase cardiac output. Isoproterenol, a non-selective beta agonist, is not used for this condition.  
❌ Anaphylactic shock:
Incorrect: The medication of choice in acute anaphylaxis or anaphylactic shock is epinephrine. Unlike isoproterenol, epinephrine will result in an increased mean arterial pressure.  
❌ Septic shock:
Incorrect: Isoproterenol is not the first-line treatment for septic shock. Norepinephrine, which increases systemic vascular resistance and mean arterial pressure, is the most appropriate first-line medication for this condition. Unlike isoproterenol, norepinephrine results in a reflex bradycardia.  
❌ Nasal congestion:
Incorrect: Inhaled phenylephrine, a pure alpha agonist, is used for the treatment of nasal congestion. Administration of this medication results in a reflex bradycardia, not tachycardia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening shortness of breath. The patient was diagnosed with asthma in childhood. The patient has been using an inhaler every one to two hours without relief of symptoms for the past two days. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 132/85 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Pulmonary auscultation demonstrates diffuse end expiratory wheezing. The patient is provided with an inhaled nebulizer treatment and intravenous glucocorticoids. Upon reassessment, the patient reports improvement in their work of breathing, but feels “tremulous.” Heart rate is now 121/min. Repeat pulmonary auscultation demonstrates clear lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the chest with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
This patient received a nebulizer treatment with subsequent tachycardia and tremor, one of the most common side effects of short-acting ß2 agonists. This adverse effect will resolve with metabolism of the medication, and no further interventions are required.    

Short-acting ß2 agonists include medications such as albuterol, metaproterenol, and terbutaline, which are primarily utilized in the treatment of acute bronchospasm due to asthma, COPD, or inhalation injury. This is due to their potent selective ß2 effects. In particular, albuterol is considered a first-line treatment for acute asthma exacerbations. Stimulation of ß2 receptors ultimately facilitates vasodilation and bronchodilation, improving airflow in the lungs. In addition, the medication terbutaline can be administered orally or intravenously for ß2-mediated tocolysis in peri-partum patients to delay delivery. The most common side effects of these medications are tremor, tremulousness, and tachycardia due to their small effect as ß1 agonists.  

Option Analysis

✅ Observation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administration of additional nebulizer treatment:
Incorrect: Administration of an additional nebulizer treatment is not clinically indicated given the resolution in this patient’s symptoms and would likely worsen the tachycardia.  
❌ CT of the chest with intravenous contrast:
Incorrect: This patient likely has tremor and tachycardia secondary to usage of a beta agonist. A CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is not indicated.  
❌ Administration of intravenous lorazepam:
Incorrect: This patient’s tachycardia and tremors will resolve with metabolism of the inhaled beta agonist. Administration of intravenous lorazepam is not clinically indicated.  
❌ Administration of intramuscular epinephrine:
Incorrect: Administration of intramuscular epinephrine will worsen this patient's tachycardia and is not clinically indicated given this patient is without features of anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old is admitted to the hospital for management of severe, symptomatic hypertension. In the emergency department, the patient was noted to have a blood pressure of 225/105 mmHg, severe headache, and was ultimately found to have an intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The patient was provided with a medication that acts selectively on D1 receptors, decreases blood pressure, and increases heart rate and cardiac output. Which of the following medications is described in this vignette?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with a hypertensive emergency was provided with a selective D1 agonist with a subsequent decrease in blood pressure and increase in heart rate and cardiac output. Of the medications listed, only fenoldopam carries these effects.    

Fenoldopam is a selective D1 agonist without associated effects on other dopaminergic receptors, beta receptors, or alpha receptors. Selective agonism of this receptor results in marked vasodilation in coronary, renal, splanchnic, and peripheral vasculature, making it a reasonable choice for the treatment of severe symptomatic hypertension. Similar to medications such as nitroprusside, fenoldopam is short-acting and administered via intravenous infusion. Side effects include over-correction of hypertension, resulting in hypotension.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fenoldopam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is a pure alpha agonist and could potentially worsen this patient’s cardiac function via an increase in afterload and subsequent worsening of hypertension.  
❌ Epinephrine:
Incorrect: Epinephrine is an α1, α2, ß1, ß2, and ß3 agonist and is not clinically indicated for the treatment of hypertensive crises.  
❌ Isoproterenol:
Incorrect: Isoproterenol is the prototypical non-selective beta agonist and results in widened pulse pressure; increased heart rate; decreased peripheral resistance; and ultimately, decreased mean arterial pressure. It is not clinically indicated in the treatment of hypertensive crises.  
❌ Dopamine:
Incorrect: Dopamine carries sympathomimetic activity when administered peripherally and was historically used for patients in shock with concomitant renal failure due its agonistic effects on D1 receptors. Unlike fenoldopam, dopamine also carries alpha and beta activity.

questions.text: A graduate student is using mice models to study kidney physiology. A sample of chemical X, a mineralocorticoid that is produced in the zona glomerulosa of the human adrenal gland, is successfully obtained. Afterward, chemical X is injected into the mice models and its effects are recorded. Assuming mice and human kidneys have similar physiology, which of the following best describes the effect that chemical X would have on serum electrolyte levels?
questions.solution:
Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid hormone produced in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. It exerts a downstream effect on α-intercalated cells and principal cells of the cortical collecting duct.

The principal cell has two pumps on its apical surface. First, it has epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs) that bring sodium into the cell. Second, it has potassium channels that excrete potassium into the renal tubule.

The α-intercalated cell mainly excretes hydrogen into the urine and utilizes two pumps on its apical surface. First, it has an H+-ATPase, which pumps hydrogen into the tubule. Second, it has an H+/K+-ATPase, which pushes one hydrogen into the tubule in exchange for one potassium.

The activity of these cells is regulated by aldosterone. In principal cells, aldosterone diffuses across the basolateral membrane and binds to cytoplasmic mineralocorticoid receptors. The aldosterone-receptor complex then enters the nucleus, triggering the increased synthesis of ENaCs and potassium channels. Together, they increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion into the urine. In α-intercalated cells, aldosterone increases the synthesis of H+-ATPase and H+/K+-ATPase, resulting in increased hydrogen secretion into the urine.

The net effect of aldosterone is increased serum sodium levels and decreased serum potassium and hydrogen levels.
 

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone is produced in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland. It acts on principal and α-intercalated cells of the collecting tubule. In principal cells, aldosterone increases sodium reuptake and potassium excretion into the urine. The latter would cause serum potassium levels to decline.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone acts on principal cells, causing increased sodium reuptake from the urine and increased potassium excretion into the urine. In addition, aldosterone acts on the α-intercalated cells, where it increases hydrogen excretion. Thus, aldosterone would cause an increase in serum sodium but a decrease in serum potassium and hydrogen.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone is produced in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland. It acts on principal cells in the collecting duct of the nephron, increasing sodium reuptake and potassium excretion into the urine. As a result, administration of aldosterone to mice models would cause an increase in serum sodium and a decline in serum potassium.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone acts on principal cells in the collecting duct of the nephron, causing increased sodium reuptake and increased potassium excretion into the urine. Injection of aldosterone into the mice model would cause an increase in serum sodium and a decrease in serum potassium.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department with shortness of breath, which began four hours ago. The patient also has swelling of the bilateral lower extremities. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and congestive heart failure. At arrival, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 145/87 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. Physical examination reveals bibasilar inspiratory crackles and pitting edema in the lower extremities. Imaging is ordered and reveals the findings below. Laboratory testing reveals a sodium level of 135 mEq/L and potassium of 5.3 mEq/L. Concurrent administration of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath, peripheral edema, and increased lung shadowing on the x-ray in the setting of congestive heart disease. He most likely has pulmonary edema. Laboratory testing reveals hyperkalemia. To avoid exacerbating the electrolyte abnormality or triggering an arrhythmia, patients with hyperkalemia should avoid taking potassium-sparing diuretics.

Potassium-sparing diuretics are used in the treatment of hypertension and edematous states, such as pulmonary edema and abdominal ascites. This is because potassium-sparing diuretics increase sodium and water loss via urine, which helps decrease plasma volume, cardiac output, and extracellular fluid volume. In addition, potassium-sparing diuretics that act as aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) are useful in treating conditions associated with hyperaldosteronism (e.g., adrenal adenoma, adrenal hyperplasia).

Finally, spironolactone and amiloride can bind to androgen receptors and prevent testosterone from binding. These medications help blunt the effects of testosterone in the body and can be used to manage conditions such as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Of note, spironolactone has stronger antiandrogenic properties and is used more commonly than amiloride to treat PCOS.

Side effects on these medications include hyperkalemia (due to reduced potassium excretion) and metabolic acidosis (due to reduced potassium excretion). In addition, spironolactone can cause gynecomastia as a side effect.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Triamterene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: This patient has pulmonary and peripheral edema, likely due to congestive heart failure exacerbation. Laboratory testing reveals hyperkalemia and medications that increase serum potassium levels should be used with caution, as they may exacerbate hyperkalemia and cause arrhythmias. However, metformin does not typically increase serum potassium levels.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hypokalemia as a side effect. As a result, it can be administered safely to this patient, who has hyperkalemia.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive that causes vasodilation. Side effects include headache, reflex tachycardia, and lupus-like syndrome. However, it does not exacerbate hyperkalemia. Hence, hydralazine can be safely administered to this patient.  
❌ Glyburide:
Incorrect: Glyburide is a medication that increases endogenous insulin release. Side effects include disulfiram-like reactions, hypoglycemia, and weight gain. However, glyburide would not typically cause hyperkalemia and would not exacerbate this patient’s electrolyte abnormality.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress. Over the past few days, the patient has been having difficulty breathing due to weather changes and COPD flare ups. Past medical history is notable for COPD, for which he takes albuterol as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 166/92 mmHg. There is audible wheezing in the bilateral lung fields. The patient is noted to be using accessory muscles while breathing. The decision is made to perform rapid sequence intubation (RSI) for airway management. Shortly after receiving RSI medications, the patient develops diffuse muscle rigidity and becomes diaphoretic. Repeat vitals reveal a temperature of 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse of 122/min, and blood pressure of 107/82 mmHg.  Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the medication that most likely precipitated the clinical findings observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of shortness of breath and subsequently undergoes rapid sequence intubation (RSI) for airway management. After administration of RSI medications, the patient develops fever, muscle rigidity, and autonomic dysfunction. These findings are consistent with malignant hyperthermia. Of the mechanisms of action listed, only the acetylcholine receptor agonist succinylcholine has been shown to precipitate this condition.  

Despite the widespread use of depolarizing neuromuscular blockers to facilitate endotracheal intubation, these medications are associated with several side effects. These include malignant hyperthermia, hyperkalemia, as well as postoperative myalgias due to muscle fasciculations.    

Depolarizing neuromuscular blockers should be used with caution in patients with hyperkalemia and end-stage renal disease. They should be avoided in patients with burns causing significant tissue damage (due to increased risk of hyperkalemia) or history of malignant hyperthermia. In addition, these medications are contraindicated in those with neurological injury (e.g., cerebral vascular accident, spinal cord injury) or degenerative neuromuscular conditions (e.g., ALS, multiple sclerosis) due to upregulation of acetylcholine receptors and risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Acetylcholine receptor agonist :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Competitive acetylcholine receptor antagonist :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockers, such as rocuronium. These medications are not associated with malignant hyperthermia.   
❌ Potentiation of GABAA receptors :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of propofol, which is not associated with malignant hyperthermia. The most common side effect of propofol is hypotension.    
❌ Ryanodine receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: This patient developed fevers, muscle rigidity, and autonomic dysfunction after undergoing rapid sequence intubation. These findings are concerning for malignant hyperthermia. Dantrolene, which is a ryanodine receptor antagonist, is used to treat malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ NMDA receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of ketamine, which is often used as an induction agent while intubating patients in severe respiratory distress due its secondary bronchodilatory effects. Ketamine is not associated with malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is undergoing an evaluation for respiratory distress in the emergency department. The patient has been experiencing worsening blurry vision, dysphagia, and dyspnea. The patient describes her breathing as shallow, thus prompting her visit to the emergency department. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/87 mmHg, pulse is 97/min, respiratory rate is 23/min, and oxygen saturation is 91%. Negative inspiratory force (NIF) is 24 (normal: -80 to -100). Based on these findings, the emergency medicine physician proceeds to intubate the patient using a medication that works by preventing acetylcholine from binding to receptors on the motor end plate, thus inhibiting depolarization. Which of the following is a known adverse effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with respiratory distress in the setting of an unknown neuromuscular disorder. The patient is subsequently intubated using a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, which is associated with antimuscarinic effects including tachycardia.    

In comparison to depolarizing agents, non-depolarizing agents are generally well-tolerated medications. However, these agents are less selective for the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor on the motor end-plate, resulting in associated antagonistic effects on muscarinic receptors.    

Rocuronium and pancuronium are known to antagonize cardiac muscarinic receptors, resulting in tachycardia. In contrast, succinylcholine, a direct muscarinic agonist, results in bradycardia.    

In addition, several medications in this class including tubocurarine and atracurium are known to stimulate histamine release, causing bronchoconstriction, hypotension, and hives.  

Lastly, these medications have a much longer duration of action when compared to depolarizing agents, thus resulting in an increased risk of aspiration if mechanical ventilation is not promptly initiated.   

Option Analysis

✅ Tachycardia :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Laryngospasm:
Incorrect: Ketamine, an NMDA receptor antagonist, has a known adverse effect of laryngospasm. This is not a documented side effect of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.   
❌ Fever and muscular rigidity:
Incorrect: Malignant hyperthermia is a known adverse reaction of succinylcholine, which is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that acts as an agonist at acetylcholine receptors. In contrast, malignant hyperthermia is not associated with non-depolarizing agents.   
❌ Hyperkalemia :
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia is a known side effect of depolarizing agents such as succinylcholine. This medication should be used with caution in patients with suspected hyperkalemia or end-stage renal disease, as it may precipitate fatal cardiac arrhythmias.   
❌ Bradycardia:
Incorrect: Bradycardia is a known side effect of depolarizing agents such as succinylcholine, due to its mechanism of action as a strong muscarinic agonist.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever. The patient was in his usual state of health until he returned home from a dialysis session three days ago and developed fevers, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort. Past medical history includes end-stage renal disease, hypertension, diabetes, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 31/min, and blood pressure is 86/62 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is obtunded and responds only to painful stimuli. There is purulent drainage from his dialysis graft. The decision is made to perform rapid sequence intubation for airway protection. In addition to giving etomidate, administration of which of the following medications is the most appropriate next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has findings concerning sepsis and bacteremia. Given his history of end-stage renal disease, the most appropriate medication to administer for rapid sequence intubation is the non-depolarizing drug rocuronium.  

Neuromuscular blocking medications are used most commonly during intubation, prolonged surgeries, and for the facilitation of mechanical ventilation. Several critical considerations arise when deciding whether to administer a non-depolarizing agent or a depolarizing agent.    

Succinylcholine, the most widely used depolarization agent, carries a risk of inducing malignant hyperthermia and hyperkalemic cardiac arrest. The medication should be used with caution in patients with hyperkalemia and end-stage renal disease. It should be avoided in patients with burns causing significant tissue damage (due to increased risk of hyperkalemia) or history of malignant hyperthermia. In addition, succinylcholine is contraindicated in those with neurological injury (e.g., cerebral vascular accident, spinal cord injury) or degenerative neuromuscular conditions due to upregulation of acetylcholine receptors and risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia. For patients without any of the aforementioned contraindications, succinylcholine is the preferred agent of choice for rapid sequence intubation given its rapid onset and short duration of action.  

In contrast, nondepolarizing medications such as cisatracurium and rocuronium have a much longer half-life and duration of action when compared to succinylcholine. These medications are ideal agents for prolonged surgery or mechanical ventilation synchrony. The specific nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker to use is largely dependent on the desired duration of effect as well as the patient’s hepatic and renal function.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rocuronium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Succinylcholine:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of end-stage renal disease and is at risk of hyperkalemia. Succinylcholine should be avoided in the rapid sequence intubation of this patient due to its ability to precipitate or worsen underlying hyperkalemia.   
❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic used for sedation, not neuromuscular blockade. Administration of propofol with etomidate can produce deep sedation, but will not relax the vocal cords for adequate passage of an endotracheal tube.  
❌ Ketamine:
Incorrect: A sedative and neuromuscular blocker should be administered prior to rapid sequence intubation. Etomidate is a sedative commonly used for this purpose. Therefore, a neuromuscular blocker, as opposed to another sedative such as ketamine, should be administered to this patient.   
❌ Baclofen:
Incorrect: Baclofen is an antispasmodic agent and is not used for rapid sequence intubation.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is brought to an emergency room from a nursing home due to increased agitation. The patient’s symptoms developed around 12 hours ago. The nursing staff reported that the patient saw people when no one was there. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 153/87 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination is unremarkable except for flushed skin. The patient is oriented to self but not to time or place. She describes seeing “scary animals” in the room. Which of the following medications could be responsible for the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This elderly individual presents with agitation, visual hallucinations, and flushed skin. Among the answer choices listed, diphenhydramine best accounts for these symptoms. Furthermore, diphenhydramine is listed in Beers criteria, a set of guidelines to reduce polypharmacy, inappropriate drug prescriptions, and drug-related side effects in patients over 65-years-old. Examples of medications listed in Beers criteria include:  

Alpha-blockers- increased risk of orthostatic hypotension  
Anticholinergics and antihistamine- increased risk of confusion, falls, urinary retention, and constipation  
Antidepressants- causes sedation, orthostatic hypotension  
Benzodiazepines- increased risk of cognitive impairment, delirium, falls  
NSAIDs- increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding  

Option Analysis

❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor and can cause side effects, including angioedema, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. However, the medication does not typically cause agitation or hallucinations in elderly patients.  
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). The Beer criteria recommend against scheduling PPIs for more than 8-weeks in elderly individuals, given the medication can cause bone loss and increased risk of Clostridium difficile infection. However, PPIs do not typically cause agitation, hallucinations, or flushed skin in elderly patients.  
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is a relatively safe drug and would not account for the symptoms experienced by this patient.  
❌ Zoledronate:
Incorrect: Zoledronate is a bisphosphonate and is used to treat osteoporosis. The drug can cause pill esophagitis, osteonecrosis of the jaw, and atypical stress fractures. However, bisphosphonates do not typically cause agitation, hallucinations, or flushed skin in elderly patients.    
✅ Diphenhydramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and palpitations for 2 hours. Past medical history is significant for congestive heart failure, nonischemic cardiomyopathy, and hypertension. Current medications include furosemide, metoprolol, lisinopril, and digoxin. The patient’s ejection fraction on transthoracic echocardiography a month ago was 40%. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows absent P waves with an irregularly irregular rhythm and nonspecific T wave changes. The patient is started on apixaban and amiodarone. His symptoms improved during the hospital stay, and he was discharged home on day three, with these new medications added to his regimen. He returns to the emergency department a week later with generalized fatigue, nausea, non-bloody vomiting, and nonspecific abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s current presentation with generalized fatigue, nausea, non-bloody vomiting, and nonspecific abdominal pain suggests digoxin toxicity, most likely due to the addition of amiodarone to the patient’s medication regimen.

Acute toxicity can present with nausea, vomiting, hyperkalemia, and cardiac arrhythmias (sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial tachycardia with AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation). In contrast, chronic toxicity presents with less profound gastrointestinal symptoms and more significant neurological (e.g., lethargy, fatigue, and confusion) and visual (e.g., changes in color vision and scotomas) symptoms.

Amiodarone, verapamil, quinidine, or propafenone (when coadministered with digoxin) can increase the risk of digoxin toxicity by reducing its renal excretion (competing for or inhibiting P-glycoprotein) or by displacement of digoxin from tissue binding sites. This leads to increased serum levels in a patient who has previously been on a stable digoxin regimen. It is recommended to decrease the dose of digoxin by 20-50% when initiating therapy with any of these drugs.

Other factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity include:

  • Hypokalemia which can increase digoxin binding at the K+-binding site on Na+/K+ ATPase
  • Hypomagnesemia (which leads to hypokalemia)
  • Renal failure (decreased digoxin clearance)
 


Option Analysis

❌ Erosive gastritis:
Incorrect: Erosive gastritis can present with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. This patient's presentation with generalized fatigue in a possible drug interaction makes this unlikely.  
❌ Pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis usually presents with nausea, vomiting, and epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back in predisposing factors (e.g., excessive alcohol use and gallstones). This patient’s presentation is not typical of pancreatitis.  
✅ Drug interaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Apixaban toxicity:
Incorrect: Apixaban is an anticoagulant, and its toxicity can present with bleeding gums, epistaxis, hematuria, melena, or hematochezia, none of which are seen in this patient.  
❌ Heart failure exacerbation:
Incorrect: Heart failure exacerbation usually presents with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, cough, early satiety, weight gain, and increasing abdominal girth. It is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after losing consciousness at work. The patient is somnolent but responds to vocal stimuli. He recalls that over the last 12 hours, he has been experiencing muscle spasms, blurred vision, dry mouth, and hallucinations. The symptoms started after  eating some wild berries that he had picked during a camping trip. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dry flushed skin and enlarged pupils. The bladder is palpable, and straight catheterization drains 450 mL of urine. Which of the following best describes the drug that can help reverse this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, blurred vision, dry mouth, flushed skin, and urinary retention. This constellation of symptoms suggests anticholinergic syndrome, likely due to intoxication from belladonna alkaloids in the wild berries. The central acetylcholinesterase inhibitor physostigmine can best treat the patient’s condition.  

Anticholinesterases, also termed indirect cholinomimetics, inhibit the enzyme acetylcholinesterase that typically degrades acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft. As a result, more acetylcholine molecules remain, causing increased and prolonged acetylcholine-mediated muscarinic and nicotinic effects. Examples of anticholinesterases include edrophonium, neostigmine, physostigmine, pyridostigmine, rivastigmine, galantamine, and donepezil.  



Option Analysis

❌ Centrally acting anticholinergic:
Incorrect: Benztropine is a centrally acting anticholinergic agent used to treat Parkinsonism. Given its anticholinergic properties, benztropine will most likely worsen this patient’s condition.  
❌ Centrally acting dopamine blocker:
Incorrect: Haloperidol is a centrally acting dopamine blocker used to treat psychosis. It has anticholinergic properties and will most likely worsen this patient’s condition.  
✅ Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ β1-adrenergic receptor blocker:
Incorrect: Metoprolol, a β1-adrenergic blocker, is used to treat angina, arrhythmias, and coronary artery disease. However, it would be ineffective in reversing this patient’s symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity.  
❌ μ-receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a μ-receptor blocker used as an antidote for opioid overdose. However, naloxone is ineffective in reversing anticholinergic toxicity.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to worsening headaches and altered mental status. The patient is unable to provide a thorough history. A medical record review reveals that the patient was diagnosed with HIV, has been inconsistent in obtaining treatment, and his CD4+ count was 42/mm3 a month ago. Temperature is 39.5°C (103°F), blood pressure is 127/73 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. The patient is oriented to self on physical examination, but not place or time. Blood cultures are obtained and reveal the findings below. The patient is started on a medication that inhibits fungal 14-alpha-demethylase. Long-term administration of this medication may cause which of the following side effects?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has altered mental status, headaches, and fever in the setting of a low CD4+ cell count. Blood samples reveal the presence of an organism with pseudohyphae and spores, making invasive candidiasis the most likely diagnosis. Azoles are a class of antifungals that work by inhibiting fungal 14-alpha demethylase and can be used to treat invasive candidiasis.  

Topical azoles are generally safe but may lead to skin irritation. However, azoles can also cause several side effects. If used systematically, azoles can cause hepatotoxicity. This medication class also inhibits human cytochrome p450, leading to the accumulation of medications metabolized by these enzymes (e.g., warfarin, phenytoin).    

Moreover, azoles, in particular ketoconazole, can inhibit the synthesis of androgens in the adrenal gland and testes, leading to gynecomastia and infertility. In rare cases, when patients are on high doses of ketoconazole for a prolonged duration, it can suppress glucocorticoid production by the adrenal glands and cause adrenal insufficiency. Finally, voriconazole may cause visual disturbances.   



Option Analysis

❌ Renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent that can treat systemic fungal infections, including Candida bacteremia. The medication can cause type I renal tubular acidosis as a side effect. However, amphotericin B does not work by inhibiting 14-alpha-demethylase activity.   
❌ Hirsutism:
Incorrect: Azoles, in particular ketoconazole, may inhibit androgen synthesis and lead to gynecomastia and infertility. Azoles do not usually manifest with clinical findings of hyperandrogenism.  
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Several antibiotics, including clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, and cephalosporins, can predispose patients to Clostridium difficile infection and subsequent pseudomembranous colitis. However, these agents would not be effective in treating candidemia.  
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Uncommonly, prolonged use of azole drugs can cause adrenal insufficiency as a side effect, which would lead to hypoglycemia, not hyperglycemia.  
✅ Adrenal insufficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with fatigue for seven months. He notes a mild headache in the morning, difficulty concentrating at work, and feeling like he could fall asleep at any minute during the day. Over the past year, he gained 25 pounds of weight. He started taking a brisk walk every day after work about one month ago to help lose weight. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mmHg. BMI is 36. On physical examination, his neck circumference is 42 cm, and his thyroid is not enlarged. Skin is warm and slightly moist, with no swelling. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Abdomen is nontender to palpation. Strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Which of the following tests should be ordered next as part of the diagnostic workup?

choices.text: Complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and thyroid-stimulating hormone

questions.solution:
This patient presents with non-exertional fatigue, excessive daytime sleepiness, and morning headaches that started after a weight gain. His presentation, in combination with the physical exam finding of a large neck circumference, is consistent with a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Laboratory testing is not necessary to diagnose sleep apnea, but initial labs are important to rule out conditions such as anemia, electrolyte abnormalities, and hypothyroidism which may cause fatigue. This patient should have initial laboratory testing that includes a complete blood count, a basic metabolic panel, and thyroid-stimulating hormone.

OSA is a disorder that disrupts breathing during sleep and is more prevalent in those who are genetically male, obese, and middle-aged or older. Those with OSA temporarily stop or have decreased breathing due to repetitive partial or complete obstructions of the airway throughout sleep. This results from narrowing of the respiratory passages and can cause awakenings, prevent deep sleep, and cause nocturnal hypoxia.

Clinical features predictive of OSA include observed gasping during sleep, loud snoring, morning headache, excessive daytime sleepiness, and neck circumference of greater than 16 inches (40.6 cm). It is also commonly associated with hypertension and depression. The STOP-Bang questionnaire is a helpful tool to assess the likelihood of sleep apnea based on clinical factors. Polysomnography is the diagnostic standard.  

Option Analysis

✅ Complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and thyroid-stimulating hormone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Polysomnography:
Incorrect: While a sleep study is the key diagnostic test for sleep apnea, it is important to first perform a basic laboratory workup to avoid missing other conditions that may be contributing to fatigue and weight gain in this patient.  
❌ Creatine kinase level:
Incorrect: Levels of creatine kinase can help determine the presence of muscle damage as part of an initial laboratory workup for fatigue. However, this is only indicated when muscle pain or weakness is present.  
❌ Thyroxine:
Incorrect: Elevated TSH and low free thyroxine (T4) are diagnostic of hypothyroidism. Since this patient does report weight gain and fatigue, it would be reasonable to check his TSH in initial laboratory studies despite absence of cold intolerance, bradycardia, or any physical exam findings commonly seen with hypothyroidism (ie. goiter, dry skin, fragile hair). Thyroxine can be tested if the initial TSH is abnormal.  
❌ Morning cortisol:
Incorrect: Adrenal insufficiency is assessed with morning cortisol/ACTH and ACTH stimulation tests. Patients with adrenal insufficiency can present with weight loss, gastrointestinal complaints, and hypotension. In contrast, this patient has weight gain and mild hypertension.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of four months of fatigue and weight gain. She frequently feels cold, even when others in the room are comfortable, and her menstrual cycles have been irregular the last few months. She also has been experiencing constipation and dryness of her skin. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 58/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg. On exam, her skin appears dry and her hair is brittle. There are no palpable masses at the anterior neck. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. Initial lab results can be seen below. Which of the following tests should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?  

Laboratory value
Result
TSH
13.1 mIU/L  
Serum free T4   
0.6 ng/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and laboratory results consistent with primary hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient parts of the world. It can be diagnosed with findings of antibodies to thyroid peroxidase. Anti-thyroglobulin antibodies may also be present.

For patients with suspected hypothyroidism, testing should begin with TSH and serum-free T4. If TSH is high and serum-free T4  is low, then the patient can be diagnosed with primary hypothyroidism. The next step is to test for anti-thyroid peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies which, if positive, can be used to diagnose Hashimoto thyroiditis. If antibody testing is negative, then the patient should be evaluated for other causes of primary hypothyroidism including iatrogenic causes (e.g., thyroidectomy, radioactive iodine treatment, external neck radiation), iodine deficiency or excess, drugs, and infiltrative diseases.

If both TSH and serum-free T4 are low, then the patient should be evaluated for central hypothyroidism which can occur when thyroid hormone deficiency is due to a disorder of the pituitary, hypothalamus, or hypothalamic-pituitary circulation. Pituitary causes include pituitary adenomas, prior radiation or surgery for pituitary adenomas, as well as infections, inflammation, and infarction (Sheehan syndrome). Infiltrative processes like sarcoidosis and brain injury can also affect the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

When TSH is high but the serum-free T4 is within normal limits, this is referred to as subclinical hypothyroidism. A significant portion of these patients will eventually go on to develop clinical hypothyroidism.  

Option Analysis

❌ TSH receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: TSH receptor antibodies can be seen in Grave disease, which leads to hyperthyroidism. TSH would be low and serum-free T4 high.  
❌ Anti-centromere antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-centromere antibodies may be seen in scleroderma which can lead to hypothyroidism and skin changes; however, Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient parts of the world, and patients should first be tested for this.  
❌ Thyrotropin-releasing hormone level:
Incorrect: TRH is the hormone released by the hypothalamus to stimulate TSH from the pituitary and is typically assessed indirectly through TRH stimulation testing. TSH would typically be low when there is a problem with the hypothalamus leading to hypothyroidism.  
✅ Thyroid peroxidase antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum glucose level:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can be a rare manifestation of thyroid disease but would not help determine the definitive diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right arm and leg weakness. The symptoms began suddenly two hours ago while he was eating breakfast. He was treated for an upper respiratory tract infection two weeks ago with azithromycin. Past medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, right hip osteoarthritis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include warfarin, acetaminophen, and omeprazole. The patient started taking St. John’s Wort a few weeks ago for his depressed mood. The patient goes for a brisk walk every morning. He does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.33°C (99.2°F), pulse is 120/minute and irregularly irregular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates right-sided hemiplegia and right lower facial paresis. INR is 0.9. CT-angiography shows an occlusive thrombus of the left middle cerebral artery. Which of the following factors is most likely responsible for the development of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely suffered a thrombotic stroke due to diminished anticoagulation while on warfarin therapy, as indicated by a subtherapeutic INR. St. John’s Wort is a CYP450 inducer that results in enhanced metabolism of warfarin, resulting in its diminished anticoagulant effects. Target INR in patients taking warfarin lies between two and three. Patients with a subtherapeutic INR are at risk of thrombus formation, whereas those with supratherapeutic INR can suffer bleeding complications. Several factors can affect warfarin activity:  
​
  •  Dietary factors: Foods such as brussels sprouts and spinach are rich in vitamin K and can act as a substrate for generating vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. This can decrease the efficacy of warfarin and subtherapeutic INR. 
 
  •  Medications/Supplements: Warfarin is metabolized by the cytochrome P450 system, and medications that inhibit this enzyme system (e.g., fluoroquinolones, erythromycin, metronidazoles, and amiodarone) can cause a supratherapeutic INR. In contrast, medications or supplements that induce this system (e.g., carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin, and St. John’s Wort) can lead to a subtherapeutic INR. 
 
  •  Liver disease can increase the INR due to decreased production of clotting factors. Similarly, acetaminophen use (>2-3 g/day) can prolong the INR in those on warfarin therapy due to its interruption of vitamin K recycling in the liver.  


Option Analysis

❌ Daily exercise:
Incorrect: Exercise has not been shown to alter warfarin's physiologic function or metabolism.   
✅ St. John’s Wort:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Azithromycin :
Incorrect: Macrolides, including erythromycin and clarithromycin, are CYP 450 inhibitors that can potentiate warfarin and increase INR. Azithromycin does not affect warfarin function.  
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is an inhibitor of CYP 450 and can result in supratherapeutic INR levels causing bleeding.  
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen use (>2-3 g/day) can prolong the INR in those on warfarin therapy due to its interruption of vitamin-K recycling in the liver. This patient’s INR is subtherapeutic.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a throbbing headache and dizziness for the past few days. He visited the emergency department two months ago for sudden onset chest pain, which was adequately managed. The remainder of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and chronic angina. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and isosorbide dinitrate. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in his father. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following strategies will most likely improve this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s headache and dizziness are most likely due to the development of nitrate tolerance, a significant problem in patients on chronic nitrate therapy.  

Isosorbide dinitrate is a nitrate used in the long-term prevention of angina pectoris. It acts by causing venous smooth muscle relaxation (via cGMP), leading to a decrease in cardiac preload, which, in turn, causes a reduction in myocardial oxygen demand. Continuous nitrate administration results in the development of tolerance (tachyphylaxis). Therefore, intermittent therapy with nitrate-free intervals (8-10 hours, usually timed during bed-time when cardiac work is minimum) must be provided to allow adequate time for the regeneration of reduced sulfhydryl groups (which helps restore vascular sensitivity to nitrates).  

The mechanism of nitrate tolerance is not well understood. Still, it is thought to result from decreased vascular sensitivity to nitrates and increased activity of the vasoconstrictor renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) in patients on chronic nitrate therapy. A similar effect is observed in industrial workers exposed to nitroglycerin (from explosives production) during the workweek, i.e. they develop tolerance to the vasodilation of nitrates after the initial period of headache and dizziness. The loss of tolerance over the weekend results in the recurrence of headache and dizziness upon re-exposure. This is called Monday disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Discontinuation of metformin:
Incorrect: Headache and dizziness experienced by this patient are most likely due to the chronic consumption of nitrates. Metformin is known to cause GI side effects, including nausea and diarrhea occasionally. No drug-drug interaction has been reported among metformin, nitrates, or atorvastatin.   
✅ Intermittent therapy with nitrates:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Direct observed therapy:
Incorrect: Direct observed therapy (DOT) is usually recommended for healthcare workers to monitor the drug's dose and compliance with managing tuberculosis patients. There is no evidence of non-compliance in this patient.  
❌ Tapering off nitrates:
Incorrect: This patient suffers from chronic angina, and tapering off nitrates is not recommended.  
❌ Add-on therapy with PDE-5 inhibitors:
Incorrect: Add-on therapy with PDE-5 inhibitors will most likely exacerbate this patient’s headache and dizziness by potentiating the effect of cGMP (by inhibiting PDE-5).

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine follow-up of hypertension. He has no complaints during this visit. His blood pressure 2 months ago was 165/95 mmHg. The patient has had 2 follow-up visits since then, both documenting high blood pressure. The patient suffered a hypersensitivity reaction to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 6 months ago for the treatment of a urinary tract infection. Past medical history is significant for gout, congestive heart failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 162/95 mmHg. Serum creatinine is 5.5 mg/dL. CT angiography reveals 80% narrowing of the right renal artery and 90% narrowing of the left renal artery. The physician discusses the risks and benefits of starting the patient on lisinopril to manage his hypertension. Which of the following is a contraindication to this medication in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s CT angiogram is suggestive of bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS) which is seen in patients with atherosclerosis and results in renovascular hypertension. RAS activates the renin-angiotensinogen-aldosterone system (RAAS) which helps increase renal blood flow (RBF) to the stenotic kidneys and improves the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This can lead to volume expansion, sodium retention, and subsequent hypertension.  

Patients with bilateral RAS are dependent upon angiotensin II for maintaining adequate GFR. The use of angiotensinogen-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs), such as lisinopril, blocks the angiotensin II-mediated vasoconstriction, which can reduce systemic blood pressure and reduce RBF. In addition, it also causes renal efferent arteriole dilation and a reduction in GFR and renal filtration fraction. Therefore, ACEIs can precipitate renal failure and are relatively contraindicated in patients with bilateral RAS.  The medication, however, can be continued if the rise in serum creatinine remains acceptable (i.e. <30 %). On the other hand, in unilateral renal artery stenosis, the unaffected kidney compensates for the reduced GFR in the stenosed kidney. The acute change in GFR is usually minimal.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Aspirin is contraindicated in patients with gout as it competes with the excretion of uric acid. ACEI use is not contraindicated in patients with a history of gout.  
❌ Congestive heart failure:
Incorrect: ACEI promotes natriuresis and can be used in patients with heart failure. This condition is not a contraindication in this patient.  
❌ Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers, such as propranolol, are contraindicated in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease due to the risk of causing bronchospasm. Lisinopril does not affect the bronchial tone and COPD is not a contraindication to its use.  
❌ Sulfonamide hypersensitivity:
Incorrect: ACEI, such as lisinopril, is not a sulfonamide derivative and it is not a contraindication for its use in this patient.  
✅ Bilateral renal artery stenosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the clinic with crampy abdominal pain and non-bloody watery diarrhea. He has had similar episodes during the past seven months. He says his symptoms occur after eating regardless of the type of food he eats, and the pain is relieved following defecation. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. He has no family history of gastrointestinal malignancies. He has not traveled recently, has no food allergies, does not smoke, consumes alcohol occasionally, and does not use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals mild, diffuse, non-radiating epigastric tenderness on palpation. Perianal and rectal examination are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show a normal CBC and a negative tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTg-IgA). Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Initiate a high fiber, low carbohydrate diet

questions.solution:
This patient’s seven-month history of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain relieved by defecation without evidence of underlying organic pathology is strongly suggestive of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)-D. IBS is defined as a chronic bowel condition that requires at least three-months of symptoms and is characterized by recurrent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, or both). Initial management of patients with mild to moderate IBS is with lifestyle and dietary modifications, which include increasing soluble fiber intake, eating a low carbohydrate diet, and increasing physical activity.

Certain high carbohydrate foods, such as potatoes, brown rice, oats, and almonds, should be avoided. Additionally FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) can be limited or avoided.

If initial management of IBS with dietary modifications is unsuccessful or in patients with severe symptoms, pharmacologic agents can be prescribed based on the subtype and the predominant symptoms as detailed in the table below. The treatment goal for IBS-D is to increase stool firmness and decrease bowel movement frequency. This can be accomplished by using TCAS (which can slow GI transit), cholestyramine, non-absorbed antibiotics (e.g. rifaximin) or mixed opioid agonist-antagonists (e.g. eluxadoline).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate a high fiber, low carbohydrate diet:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eliminate gluten-containing foods:
Incorrect: Gluten-sensitive enteropathy, or Celiac disease, is an immune-mediated inflammatory gastrointestinal disease that is caused by sensitivity to gluten-containing foods. Eliminating these foods usually resolves symptoms associated with Celiac disease. Since this patient has a negative tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTg-IgA), this is not appropriate management.  
❌ Eliminate lactose-containing foods:
Incorrect: Lactose intolerance presents with abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, nausea, or diarrhea following ingestion of lactose containing products. Given the lack of these symptoms, this patient is not lactose intolerant and would not benefit from eliminating lactose-containing foods.  
❌ Start antimicrobial therapy:
Incorrect: This patient's symptoms have persisted for seven months. He has no history of recent travel, is afebrile, and has a normal CBC, which does not support a diagnosis of infectious diarrhea.  
❌ Cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: Acute cholecystitis commonly presents with right upper quadrant pain (+/- radiation), fever, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Given the lack of these findings and the chronicity of this patient’s condition, cholecystectomy is not indicated.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status and shortness of breath. He stopped taking his antihypertensive medications due to side effects and has not seen his primary physician since then. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on 5L nasal cannula. The patient has labored breathing. He is oriented to person only. Pulmonary examination reveals bilateral rales. Fundoscopic examination is significant for papilledema. The electrocardiogram shows evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy without ST elevations or depressions or T-wave abnormalities. Lab results show serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL (1.7 mg/dL baseline) and hematuria on urinalysis. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a hypertensive emergency as evidenced by a severely elevated blood pressure (220/120 mmHg) and evidence of end-organ damage, including neurological (altered mental status, papilledema), cardiovascular (respiratory distress, bilateral rales), and renal impairment (serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL). Treatment with intravenous labetalol should be initiated immediately.

A hypertensive emergency is characterized by severe hypertension (BP > 180/120 mmHg) with evidence of end-organ damage. In the case of a hypertensive emergency, it is crucial to lower blood pressure promptly to prevent further damage; however, it must be done in a controlled manner to avoid ischemic events. In general, the goal is to reduce the mean arterial pressure (MAP) by no more than 25% within the first hour, followed by a gradual reduction toward 160/100-110 mmHg over the next 2-6 hours. Intravenous antihypertensives (labetalol, esmolol, nicardipine, and hydralazine) should be administered based on the presence of specific comorbid conditions and the side effect profiles of the medications.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform rapid sequence intubation:
Incorrect: This patient should be closely monitored for respiratory failure, but blood pressure control is the immediate priority. Rapid sequence intubation may be considered if there is impending respiratory failure.  
❌ Administer IV furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic indicated in the setting of acute heart failure with volume overload. It is not the best initial treatment for hypertensive emergencies.  
❌ Administer oral lisinopril:
Incorrect: Oral ACE inhibitors like ramipril are first-line treatment for long-term blood pressure control, but they are generally not used to treat hypertensive emergencies due to their slow onset of action. Intravenous medications are preferred for rapid control of blood pressure.  
❌ Obtain a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head:
Incorrect: This patient has altered mental status and papilledema, which are findings consistent with hypertensive encephalopathy caused by a hypertensive emergency. Obtaining brain imaging may delay blood pressure control with antihypertensive therapy, which is the immediate priority.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a past medical history of essential hypertension for 10 years presents to the clinic for follow-up. The patient’s blood pressure has been consistently elevated despite being on a thiazide diuretic, a calcium channel blocker, and an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. He reports medication compliance and adherence to a low sodium diet. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs. BMI is 23 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 156/96 mmHg, heart rate is 85/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a well-nourished male in no distress. Cardiovascular examination is normal without evidence of heart failure. No abdominal bruits are heard. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on this patient's evaluation?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Hemoglobin
14.1 g/dL  
Leukocyte count  
6,500/mm3  
Platelet count  
350,000/mm3  
Sodium
147 mEq/L  
Potassium
2.9 mEq/L  
Chloride
97 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate  
31 mEq/L  
Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL

choices.text: Plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity ratio >20
Narrowing of the aortic arch on chest X-ray
High serum cortisol after dexamethasone suppression test

questions.solution:
This patient presents with resistant hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive medications and implementing lifestyle modifications. In addition, he has evidence of hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis on laboratory evaluation. This clinical presentation is suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism, which is a common cause of secondary hypertension. It can be diagnosed with a plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity ratio >20 and a PAC >15 ng/dL.

Primary hyperaldosteronism, also known as Conn syndrome, is characterized by overproduction of aldosterone from the adrenal glands. Overproduction can be due to an adrenal adenoma (aldosterone-producing adenoma [APA]) or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. This results in hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. The most appropriate screening test for primary hyperaldosteronism is the plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) to plasma renin activity (PRA) ratio. A PAC:PRA ratio > 20 along with a PAC > 15 ng/dL is suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism. If the ratios are sufficiently elevated, then confirmatory testing should be done with an adrenal CT scan to distinguish between an aldosterone-producing adrenal adenoma and bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity ratio >20:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Narrowing of the aortic arch on chest X-ray:
Incorrect: This finding is associated with coarctation of the aorta, a congenital condition typically diagnosed in infancy or early adolescence. It is not a common cause of hypertension in older patients.  
❌ Multiple renal cysts on ultrasound:
Incorrect: This finding would suggest polycystic kidney disease (PKD). While treatment resistant hypertension is a common manifestation, PKD typically presents with additional signs, such as flank pain, hematuria, and an elevated creatinine on laboratory evaluation.  
❌ High serum cortisol after dexamethasone suppression test:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of Cushing syndrome, which can cause treatment resistant hypertension. Cushing syndrome is usually accompanied by other signs, such as central obesity, skin changes, and glucose intolerance, which are not present in this case.  
❌ High plasma free metanephrines:
Incorrect: This finding would suggest a pheochromocytoma, a tumor of the adrenal medulla that can cause resistant hypertension. However, these tumors also produce other symptoms, such as headaches, palpitations, and episodic sweating.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found down outside. The patient is lethargic and cannot provide a history. On arrival, the patient’s temperature is 80 ºF (26.7 ºC), pulse is 36/min, respiratory rate is 6/min, blood pressure is 75/51 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 72% on room air. Serum potassium is 3.1 mEq/L, and serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL. Chest radiograph shows a dense right lower lobe infiltrate. Shortly after bloodwork is obtained, the patient becomes pulseless, and advanced cardiac life support is started. Return of spontaneous circulation is achieved after several minutes. Vital signs are repeated; temperature is 81 ºF (27.2 ºC), pulse is 36/min, respiratory rate is 6/min, blood pressure is 71/49 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 88% on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe hypothermia (temperature < 82 ºF, or 28 ºC) with hemodynamic instability and subsequent cardiac arrest. Warmed IV fluids would not be adequate treatment in this case, and invasive rewarming measures, such as hemodialysis or extracorporeal bypass, should be started. Since this patient also has severe hypoxemia, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) would be preferred to provide cardiopulmonary bypass, warm the blood, and provide oxygenation.

Hypothermia can be classified as mild (90-95 ºF, or 32-35 ºC), moderate (82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC) or severe (<82 ºF, or <28 ºC). Treatment centers around providing supportive care, warming the patient, and treating complications. External rewarming (e.g. heating blankets) should be initiated immediately. Internal rewarming (e.g. warmed IV fluids) should be provided for moderate and severe hypothermia. Patients with severe and/or refractory hypothermia can be treated with invasive rewarming measures. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable or in cardiac arrest, these include ECMO, hemodialysis, cardiopulmonary bypass, or peritoneal or closed thoracic lavage with warmed fluid.  ECMO is typically preferred in cases of severe hypothermia with cardiac arrest.  

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate extracorporeal membrane oxygenation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiate hemodialysis:
Incorrect: This could be an option to provide internal rewarming, especially if the patient has severe acute kidney injury. This patient just had a cardiac arrest and is persistently hypoxemic, so ECMO is more appropriate.  
❌ Initiate room temperature IV fluids  :
Incorrect: Patients with moderate or severe hypothermia should receive warmed IV fluids.  
❌ Initiate warmed IV fluids:
Incorrect: This is appropriate for moderate or severe hypothermia. However, this patient has already suffered a cardiac arrest due to hypothermia and needs more aggressive treatment.  
❌ Apply warming blankets:
Incorrect: This is appropriate for patients with mild hypothermia, but it is not adequate for moderate or severe hypothermia.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man was brought to the emergency department due to dizziness and vomiting for three days. The patient states that when he vomited, it appeared dark and grainy, similar to coffee grounds. He states that his stools have had a sticky consistency. He has not seen a doctor in 10 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Conjunctiva are icteric and pupils are reactive without papilledema. Abdominal exam is significant for a mildly distended abdomen with a fluid wave,  but no tenderness or guarding. Lab results show a moderately elevated AST and Alt and an elevated INR. Lab tests from his last clinic visit 10 years ago are shown below. Endoscopy reveals dilated distal esophageal veins with cherry-red spots. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?  

Laboratory value
Result
HBsAg
+
HBsAb
-
Anti-HBc IgM  
-
Anti-HBc IgG  
+
questions.solution:
This patient is exhibiting signs of portal hypertension secondary to cirrhosis of the liver caused by chronic hepatitis B infection. In patients with portal hypertension from cirrhosis, blood from the portal venous system can be shunted through the periumbilical veins into the umbilical vein and the veins of the abdominal wall. Engorgement of the vessels around the umbilicus is called caput medusae which is a sign of portal hypertension.

Portal hypertension in patients with cirrhosis can lead to esophageal varices. Patients with esophageal varices can experience vomiting of bright red blood if the bleeding is brisk, or darker “coffee ground” emesis if the blood has had time to sit in the stomach.  Melena or hematochezia can occur as the blood moves further through the GI tract.  Coagulopathy can further contribute to bleeding as patients with hepatitis B infection may have elevated PT/INR and PTT as well as thrombocytopenia.

Hepatitis B infection (HBV) will often clear spontaneously after the acute stage.  When surface antibodies do not form within the first six months of infection, the virus can remain circulating in the blood and liver leading to chronic infection.  This ongoing infection predisposes to complications including cirrhosis, liver failure, and hepatocellular carcinoma.  Patients from areas of the world where hepatitis B is endemic are at increased risk of infection as well as those who use IV drugs, practice high-risk sexual habits, receive non-sterile tattoos, or have experienced a needle-stick injury.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rigidity on abdominal exam:
Incorrect: Rigidity and guarding can be seen in acute abdominal processes including infection, bowel perforation, and injury.  Perforation of esophageal varices can occur, but the patient would likely be hemodynamically unstable and have guarding and tenderness on abdominal exam.  
❌ Courvoisier sign:
Incorrect:  Courvoisier sign occurs when the gallbladder is palpably enlarged due to bile obstruction.  
❌ Grey Turner sign:
Incorrect:  Grey Turner sign occurs when there is ecchymosis of the flank due to a retroperitoneal bleed.  Although bleeding retroperitoneal varices can occur, this patient presents with signs of bleeding within the GI tract.  
✅ Tortuous veins around the umbilicus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left lower quadrant abdominal pain:
Incorrect: Pain in chronic hepatitis B with cirrhosis is typically in the upper quadrants, specifically the right upper quadrant.  Pain may be diffuse with ascites but isolated left lower quadrant pain would be atypical and is more likely to signal an alternate condition such as diverticulitis.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the primary care office to be evaluated before his dermatologist starts him on immunosuppressive medications to treat psoriasis.  He has mild fatigue and occasional GI upset but no other concerns.  Past medical history is significant for psoriasis and diet-controlled type II diabetes mellitus.  His father recently died of hepatocellular carcinoma at age 83.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg BMI is 28.  The skin has numerous scaly plaques.  Abdomen is soft and nontender with no masses.  Screening tests are ordered including a colonoscopy and hepatitis B serology.  Laboratory results show a positive HBsAg, negative HBsAb, and positive anti-HBc IgG.  Additional labs can be seen below.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
HBV DNA  
24,000 IU/mL  
HBeAg  
+
ALT
82 IU/L

choices.text: Hepatic elastography and initiation of entecavir
MRI of the liver and initiation of tenofovir
CT scan of the liver and initiation of lamivudine
Ultrasound of the liver and referral for liver transplant
Ultrasound of the liver and serial monitoring of labs

questions.solution:
This patient’s screening Hepatitis B labs are consistent with chronic hepatitis B infection. He should be treated with antiviral therapy given his age, family history of hepatocellular carcinoma, high viral load with active replication, and plans to start immunosuppressing medication.  Patients with chronic hepatitis B should also have a hepatic elastography to assess for fibrosis unless liver biopsy is indicated.

Treatment of hepatitis B infection varies depending on the stage and presenting features of the disease.  Treatment may be purely supportive in mild cases, and in more severe cases treatment may include medications or even liver transplantation.

The need for antiviral medication in chronic hepatitis B infection is determined by assessment of viral load using HBV DNA, viral replication, and hepatitis e antigen and antibody status along with consideration of patient-specific risk factors and the condition of the liver.  High levels of HBV DNA, active viral replication, elevated ALT, family history of hepatocellular carcinoma, age over 40, pregnancy, acute liver failure, presence of cirrhosis, immunosuppression, and coinfection with hepatitis C or HIV are all indications for treatment with antiviral therapy.

When indicated, first-line treatment is with nucleoside inhibitors such as entecavir or tenofovir.  Pegylated interferon alpha may also be considered in the treatment of chronic hepatitis B.  Benefits of therapy include viral suppression, reduced risk of recurrent HBV if a liver transplant is needed, reduced risk of hepatocellular carcinoma, and decreased risk of developing cirrhosis.
