Long-term management of chronic hepatitis B should include regular laboratory monitoring of CBC, CMP, PT/INR, hepatitis B DNA, and e antigen as well as routine surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma with liver ultrasound and measurement of alpha-fetoprotein. Hepatic elastography should be done in all patients to assess for fibrosis unless a liver biopsy is needed.  Counseling on lifestyle modifications should advise against the use of hepatotoxic medications including those sold over the counter, and cessation of smoking.

Protective measures may help limit spread of the virus to others such as hepatitis B vaccination for household contacts and safe sexual practices.  Hepatitis A vaccination should be administered and screening for other blood-borne infectious diseases should be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Hepatic elastography and initiation of entecavir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ MRI of the liver and initiation of tenofovir:
Incorrect: Screening for hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with chronic hepatitis B is necessary and is typically done with ultrasound.  MRI can be used for further evaluation of concerning findings, or if the ultrasound is inconclusive.  
❌ CT scan of the liver and initiation of lamivudine:
Incorrect:  Screening for hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with chronic hepatitis B is necessary and typically done with ultrasound.  CT scan can be used for further evaluation of concerning findings,, or if the ultrasound is inconclusive and the patient has a contraindication to having an MRI.  
❌ Ultrasound of the liver and referral for liver transplant:
Incorrect:  Ultrasound of the liver is indicated for hepatocellular carcinoma screening in patients with chronic hepatitis B, however, liver transplant is not indicated at this time in this stable patient without signs of fulminant hepatic failure.  
❌ Ultrasound of the liver and serial monitoring of labs:
Incorrect: Ultrasound of the liver is indicated for hepatocellular carcinoma screening in patients with chronic hepatitis B; however this patient also requires initiation of antiviral medication given his family history, age, laboratory findings, and plans for use of immunosuppressive medications.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman is seen in the emergency room because of right leg pain and swelling. Her symptoms began ten hours ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, osteoarthritis, and two uncomplicated pregnancies. The patient works as a management consultant and returned from a trip to Singapore two days ago. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 153/86 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a swollen right calf two centimeters greater in circumference than the left calf. Dorsiflexion of the right foot elicits pain in the right calf. The patient is started on unfractionated heparin and is seen at a follow-up appointment one week later. Laboratory testing obtained in the emergency room and at the follow-up visit are shown below. Heparin is discontinued, and an alternative medication is started. Which of the following best describes this new medication's effect on antithrombin, factor IIa, and factor Xa activity?  

Laboratory Value
Results (emergency room)  
Results (current)  
Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL  
13.7 g/dL  
Hematocrit
40.5%  
41.1%  
Leukocyte Count  
9,600/mm3   
8,400/mm3   
Platelet Count  
160,000/mm3   
65,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient has laboratory findings consistent with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Heparin should be immediately discontinued, and the patient should be started on an alternative form of anticoagulation, such as a direct thrombin inhibitor (Option C) or direct factor Xa inhibitors (not listed).

The direct thrombin inhibitors (e.g., dabigatran, bivalirudin) and direct factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban) inhibit the coagulation cascade by binding to their corresponding coagulation factors. The direct thrombin inhibitors bind to free-floating thrombin and those already attached to a forming clot. As a result, the less activated thrombin is available to stimulate platelets, activate other clotting factors, and induce fibrin formation.

Likewise, direct factor Xa inhibitors have the same function on Xa. However, it has a greater effect on anticoagulation since factor Xa is higher in the coagulation cascade. As a result, each molecule of the medication can prevent multiple thrombins from being activated by a factor Xa.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of unfractionated heparin. Unfractionated heparin activates antithrombin III, reducing factor IIa and Xa activity. However, this patient has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, and heparin should be immediately discontinued.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). LMWH activates antithrombin and reduces factor Xa activity. The risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is lower for LMWH. However, given that HMWH and LMWH have cross-reactivity, Patients with HIT should also avoid the latter..   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Medications that reduce antithrombin III and increase factor IIa activity would promote blood clotting. In contrast, this patient has a deep vein thrombosis and should be continued on an anticoagulant.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has laboratory findings consistent with HIT. Factor IIa inhibitors can be used as an alternative to heparin in patients with HIT. As its name implies, the medication reduces factor IIa activity but does not affect antithrombin III and factor Xa activity.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a rash on his nose. A month ago, the patient noticed several small spots on his nose that have progressively enlarged but are not pruritic or painful. Past medical history is significant for primary syphilis and anal gonorrhea, both of which were adequately treated with antibiotics a few years ago. The patient has had 4 female sexual partners over the past year. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination findings are shown below. HIV testing is positive. CD4+ count is 150/mm3, and HIV viral load is 47,000 copies/mL. In addition to antiretroviral therapy, which of the following medications should be added to this patient’s medication regimen?  

.
Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with HIV is presenting with Kaposi sarcoma. He has a CD4+ cell count of less than <200/mm3 but more than >50/mm3 and should, therefore, receive prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii and Toxoplasma gondii with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).   

TMP-SMX is a combination of antimetabolite drugs that sequentially block the synthesis of bacterial folic acid synthesis (act synergistically) and is bactericidal against susceptible organisms (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella, Salmonella, and Shigella). It is most commonly used to treat simple urinary tract infections. Other indications include pneumonia and sinus infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae and Moraxella catarrhalis, respectively, as well as the prevention of Pneumocystis jiroveci and Toxoplasma infections (in organ and stem cell transplant recipients and HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 counts less than 200/mm3).    

The sulfonamides (e.g., sulfadiazine, sulfasalazine, sulfacetamide, and sulfadoxine) are active against Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms, Chlamydia, and Nocardia. Specific indications include: 
  •  Sulfadiazine with pyrimethamine for the treatment of acute toxoplasmosis 
  •  Sodium sulfacetamide for the treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis and as adjunctive therapy for trachoma 
  •  Sulfasalazine for the treatment of ulcerative colitis and enteritis 


Option Analysis

❌ Penicillin:
Incorrect: Penicillin is indicated for the prophylaxis of acute rheumatic fever in patients with streptococcal pharyngitis, pregnant women carrying group B streptococcus infection, and strep pharyngitis in children with prior rheumatic fever.  
❌ Rifampin :
Incorrect: Rifampin chemoprophylaxis is indicated in close contact with patients with meningococcal infection and should be given as early as possible following exposure. It does not prevent the development of opportunistic infections in patients with HIV.  
❌ Azithromycin :
Incorrect: Azithromycin is occasionally indicated in HIV patients with a CD4+ count <50/mm3 to prevent opportunistic infection with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). This was previously administered to all individuals with a CD4+ count <50/mm3, but recent guideline changes now recommend not giving it to all patients, and only for patients residing in areas with high rates of MAC infection.   
✅ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mefloquine:
Incorrect: Mefloquine is effective for the prevention of malaria due to chloroquine-sensitive, and chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum, as well as the other malaria species that cause human malaria. It does not prevent the development of opportunistic infections in patients with HIV.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of gum bleeding for the past 2 days. He was recently diagnosed with bronchopneumonia and started on targeted therapy when the sputum gram stain showed partially acid-fast filamentous-branching gram-positive rods. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and aortic valve replacement. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, warfarin, and an antibacterial drug for pneumonia. The patient goes for a daily 30-minute walk in the mornings. He does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Oropharyngeal examination shows oozing blood from the gums. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Current INR is 3.5 (goal INR 2-3). Which of the following most likely precipitated this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely receiving treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) for bronchopneumonia secondary to Nocardiosis (partially acid-fast filamentous-branching gram-positive rods). He is also on warfarin therapy for aortic valve replacement and has a supratherapeutic INR (therapeutic INR for aortic valve replacement is 2-3) and bleeding from the gums. This complication most likely resulted from the interaction between TMP-SMX ( a cytochrome P45 system inhibitor) and warfarin (metabolized by CYP450 system). Moreover, sulfonamides displace the protein-bound warfarin in blood.  



Option Analysis

❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Certain macrolides, including erythromycin and clarithromycin, are CYP 450 inhibitors, which can result in warfarin accumulation and increase INR. Azithromycin, however, does not affect warfarin function.  
❌ Exercise:
Incorrect: Exercise has not shown to alter the physiologic function and metabolism of warfarin.  
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin is a cytochrome oxidase inducer and would increase the metabolism of warfarin leading to thrombotic complications and a subtherapeutic INR (unlike this patient’s supratherapeutic level). Moreover, it is not effective against Nocardia.  
✅ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amikacin:
Incorrect: Amikacin is an aminoglycoside that inhibits protein synthesis by the inhibition of the initiation complex. It is, however, not used in the treatment of nocardiosis. In addition, it does not interact significantly with cytochrome oxidase systems and would not alter warfarin metabolism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute urinary retention and low back pain. The patient was performing dead-lifts at the gym when he felt the weight was too heavy and suddenly fell backwards to the floor. He has since had right low back and flank pain. The patient went home and took several analgesics but became increasingly concerned when he was unable to urinate. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 167/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 99/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears uncomfortable. Abdominal exam is significant for suprapubic fullness. The patient has no step offs or deformities overlying the lumbar spine. The patient is unable to ambulate due to pain and weakness in the legs. Bladder scan reveals >1L.  Which of the following additional findings would most likely be present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute urinary retention in the setting of severe back pain and injury, and lower extremity weakness which is concerning for cauda equina syndrome. Decreased anal sphincter tone, lower extremity weakness, and saddle anesthesia (numbness around the groin and buttocks) can be signs and symptoms of cauda equina syndrome.

Urinary retention refers to the inability to voluntarily empty the urinary bladder. It can be acute or chronic, and range from partial to complete urinary retention. Urinary retention has multiple causes including spinal cord compression or injury, medication side effects, urethral obstruction, and urinary tract infections.

Patients who present with urinary retention should be assessed for chronicity of symptoms followed by a detailed history and assessment for neurological red flags such as lower extremity weakness and decreased anal sphincter tone that would require immediate evaluation and intervention. Patients should be asked about risk factors for urinary retention such as medications (e.g. anticholinergic agents, antipsychotics, opioids), history of anatomic obstruction such as benign prostatic hyperplasia, or elements that suggest urinary tract infection (e.g. dysuria). Typical physical examination findings associated with urinary retention include suprapubic fullness and tenderness.

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased anal sphincter tone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enlarged prostate:
Incorrect: While BPH is a common cause of acute urinary retention, in this patient with acute low back pain, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness, cauda equina syndrome is more likely.  
❌ Miosis:
Incorrect:  Miosis, is a common ocular finding that occurs with opiate use which can lead to urinary retention. In this patient with acute low back injury, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness, cauda equina syndrome is more likely.  
❌ Hematuria:
Incorrect: Hematuria can occur in patients with underlying urinary tract infection or in patients with bladder masses, but these causes of urinary retention would be less likely than cauda equina syndrome in this patient with acute low back injury and urinary retention.  
❌ Frequent use of diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Anticholinergic agents such as diphenhydramine can result in acute urinary retention; however, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe vomiting and right upper quadrant pain that has been ongoing for the past five hours. The symptoms started shortly after dinner. The patient has experienced two similar episodes previously, which were adequately managed in the emergency department. He takes no medications and drinks 3-4 beers on weekends. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Body mass index is 36 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the epigastrium and right upper abdominal quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound reveals no evidence of gallstones or biliary ductal dilatation. Laboratory results are shown below. In addition to weight loss, which of the following drugs will be most effective in preventing similar symptoms from developing in the future?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Glucose
120 mg/dL
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)
140 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
30 mg/dL
Triglycerides (TGs)
1400 mg/dL
Lipase
600 U/L
Hemoglobin A1c
5.9%
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and a history of similar prior episodes. Laboratory testing reveals a severely elevated triglyceride (TG) level. In combination, these findings are most suggestive of acute pancreatitis. In addition to dietary modifications, the patient should be started on fibrate therapy to reduce the risk of future episodes.

Fibrates are lipid-lowering drugs that activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα), a major lipid metabolism regulator. PPARα decreases very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis and increases lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in adipose tissues. LPL, in turn, hydrolyzes the TGs in chylomicrons and VLDLs to free fatty acids (FFA), thus lowering triglyceride levels. Moreover, fibrates increase the synthesis of HDLs, facilitating the transfer of TGs from chylomicrons and VLDL to HDL. However, unlike statins, fibrates have little effect on decreasing LDL cholesterol.

As a result, the overall effects of fibrate therapy are a major decrease in TG, a moderate increase in HDL, and a moderate decrease in LDL levels.  

Option Analysis

❌ Niacin:
Incorrect: Niacin inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue and decreases VLDL synthesis. It has a limited effect on serum triglyceride levels, most likely responsible for causing this patient’s pancreatitis and associated symptoms.  
❌ Ezetimibe:
Incorrect: Ezetimibe inhibits cholesterol absorption at the intestinal brush border. It reduces liver cholesterol stores and decreases biliary bile content. Ezetimibe’s major role is to decrease LDL cholesterol levels instead of triglyceride levels.  
✅ Fenofibrate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cholestyramine:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of acute pancreatitis, likely secondary to hypertriglyceridemia. Cholestyramine is a bile acid resin that decreases LDL cholesterol levels by preventing bile acid reabsorption in the intestines. It slightly increases, rather than decreases, triglyceride levels.  
❌ Alirocumab:
Incorrect: Alirocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the enzyme proprotein convertase subtilisin Kexin 9 (PCSK9) and increases the degradation of low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDL-R) on hepatocytes. It leads to an overall decrease in serum LDL levels and is indicated in patients with elevated LDL cholesterol levels, not hypertriglyceridemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate dyslipidemia. His fasting lipid profile was obtained a week ago and revealed an elevated triglyceride level. He is asymptomatic during this visit. Past medical history is significant for aortic valve replacement and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, regular insulin, and atorvastatin. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus in his mother. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient’s most recent INR is 1.5, and serum creatinine is 1.2 mg/dL. A decision is made to start the patient on fenofibrate to manage his triglyceride level. Which following interventions should be done before starting this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has an elevated triglyceride level and is started on fenofibrate, a triglyceride-lowering medication. However, he is also on warfarin therapy due to a history of aortic valve replacement. Fibrates impair warfarin metabolism, and the two drugs used in combination can increase the risk of bleeding. Therefore, the warfarin dose should be reduced by 20-30% in this patient before initiating fibrate therapy. The mechanism of this interaction is unclear but is thought to result from the inhibition of CYP2C9 (enzyme for warfarin metabolism) and the displacement of protein-bound warfarin by fibrates.

Fibrates can result in several additional adverse effects, including:  

  • Gastrointestinal disturbances 
  • Gallstones: Fibrates inhibit cholesterol 7ɑ-hydroxylase, an enzyme that synthesizes bile acids. This effect results in the supersaturation of cholesterol within the gallbladder and the formation of gallstones. 
  • Hepatotoxicity: Fibrates can irritate the liver and cause mild but reversible elevations in liver aminotransferase. 
  • Myopathy: Fibrates (particularly gemfibrozil), when given in combination with statins, can potentiate the effect of statins (by inhibiting its excretion) on muscle breakdown.  
  • Nephrotoxicity 

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain gallbladder ultrasound:
Incorrect: Although fibrates can increase the risk of developing gallstones by inhibiting cholesterol 7ɑ-hydroxylase, a baseline ultrasound is not recommended in asymptomatic individuals.  
❌ Obtain liver function test:
Incorrect: A baseline liver function test is recommended before initiating statins (not fibrates). Although fibrates can cause changes in hepatic aminotransferases, this side effect is quite rare.  
❌ Measure serum creatinine phosphokinase level  :
Incorrect: Fibrates can potentially cause myopathy, which can present as an elevation in serum creatinine phosphokinase. However, serum creatinine phosphokinase levels do not need to be routinely obtained before starting fibrate therapy.  
✅ Decrease the warfarin dose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discontinue atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Although a combination of statin and fibrate enhances the risk of developing myopathy, it is rarely seen with the combination of atorvastatin and fenofibrate. Moreover, discontinuing the statin is not recommended for this patient as it would increase his risk of cardiovascular mortality.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man is diagnosed with Gram-positive bacteremia and started on Antibiotic X. The drug is administered intravenously and requires a plasma concentration of at least 20 mg/L to achieve therapeutic effects. Additional information regarding Antibiotic X’s pharmacokinetics is listed below. Unfortunately, Antibiotic X can lead to severe side effects. As a result, the ordering physician wants to administer the lowest possible dose. Suppose the patient's body weight is 75 kg. Which of the following would be the smallest loading dose of Antibiotic X that can achieve therapeutic levels?  

Pharmacokinetic Parameter
Value
Volume of distribution  
0.4 L/kg  
Dosing interval  
6 hours  
Bioavailability*  
100%  
Elimination rate  
2.6 L/h  
*For intravenous administration
questions.solution:
This patient has Gram-positive bacteremia and is started on Antibiotic X, administered via an intermittent dosing regimen. In other words, the medication is administered at regular time intervals. In emergency cases, a loading dose (a large dose given at the beginning of treatment) can be administered to help the medication rapidly achieve target concentrations. Maintenance doses, given at scheduled intervals, can be subsequently administered to help keep the drug level at a steady state. The loading dose can be calculated via the equation above.

The first step in determining the loading dose of Antibiotic X for this patient would be to calculate the patient’s volume of distribution, which equals 0.4 L/kg*75 kg, or 30 L. Afterwards, the loading dose can be calculated as follows:

   Loading dose = (20 mg/L * 30 L) / 100% = 600 mg / 1 = 600 mg

Therefore, a loading dose of at least 600 mg would be required for Antibiotic X to reach therapeutic levels in this patient.
 

Option Analysis

❌ 300 mg:
Incorrect: This patient has a volume of distribution of 30 L (0.4 L/kg*75 kg). Given Antibiotic X is intravenously administered and has a bioavailability of 100%, a loading dose of 600 mg would be necessary to achieve therapeutic levels. In contrast, a 300 mg loading dose would be insufficient.  
❌ 450 mg:
Incorrect: This patient has a volume of distribution of 30 L (0.4 L/kg*75 kg). Given Antibiotic X is intravenously administered and has a bioavailability of 100%, a loading dose of 600 mg would be necessary to achieve therapeutic levels. In contrast, a 450 mg loading dose would be insufficient.  
✅ 600 mg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 850 mg:
Incorrect: A minimum loading dose of 600 mg is required for Antibiotic X to reach therapeutic levels in this patient. A loading dose of 850 mg would be excessive and increase the risk of side effects.  
❌ 1500 mg:
Incorrect: A minimum loading dose of 600 mg is required for Antibiotic X to reach therapeutic levels in this patient. A loading dose of 1500 mg would be excessive and increase the risk of side effects.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of lethargy and confusion. The patient's partner reports that she was unable to get the patient out of bed this morning and that she has been refusing all of her medications over the past several weeks. The patient has a past medical history of atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 88/60 mmHg, pulse is 119/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears ill and is unable to provide clinical history. Physical examination demonstrates dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and delayed capillary refill.  Initial fingerstick blood glucose is 680 mg/dL and serum osmolality is 380 mOsm/kg. Venous blood gas shows a pH of 7.37. The patient is given isotonic saline boluses followed by an infusion and intravenous insulin. The patient's initial laboratory findings are shown below, and repeat blood glucose at 1 hr is 550 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Serum chemistry

Sodium
129 mEq/L
Potassium
3.2 mEq/L
Chloride
97 mEq/L
Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL
HCO3
19 mEq/L
BUN
25

Laboratory value
Result
Urinalysis

Color
Dark
Specific gravity
1.013
Glucose
Large
Blood
Negative
Leukocyte esterase
Negative
Nitrites
Negative
Leukocytes
1-2/hpf
Erythrocytes
1-2/hpf
Dysmorphic RBCs
Absent
Casts
None
Ketones

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with findings consistent with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), including blood glucose >600 mg/dL, elevated serum osmolality, evidence of profound dehydration, and the absence of metabolic acidosis and ketonuria. This patient’s potassium level is low, and given that she will continue to receive intravenous insulin, prompt administration of potassium is necessary. Insulin shifts potassium into cells; therefore with continued insulin infusion, potassium will decrease further, possibly precipitating arrhythmias.

Once HHS is diagnosed, management involves administration of intravenous normal saline and insulin. Patients should have their chemistry panel followed, and potassium repletion should be given if the serum potassium is <5.3 mEq/L while insulin is being given. In addition, patients should have corrected sodium levels calculated and have normal saline switched to 0.45% normal saline if the sodium level is normal or elevated. Blood glucose should be checked hourly, and insulin should be titrated to maintain a gradual decrease in serum levels. Once the blood glucose level falls to 250 to 300 mg/dL (13.9 to 16.7 mmol/L), the IV saline solution can be switched to dextrose in saline, and the insulin infusion rate can be decreased.

Option Analysis

✅ Administer supplemental potassium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ No change in current management:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of hypokalemia, and continued administration of insulin without potassium repletion could precipitate dangerous arrhythmias.  
❌ Continue normal saline:
Incorrect: Administration of 0.45% saline (half-normal saline) is indicated in patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) after initial fluid resuscitation if the patient’s corrected sodium levels are within or above the reference range. This patient's corrected sodium level is 141, so normal saline should be switched to 0.45% saline.  
❌ Bolus intravenous insulin:
Incorrect: This patient has had an adequate decrease in blood sugar following insulin infusion. An additional bolus of intravenous insulin is not required and, in fact, may worsen their current hypokalemia by possibly precipitating dangerous arrhythmias.  
❌ Switch to subcutaneous insulin:
Incorrect: This patient's blood sugar following initial therapy is still >300 mg/dL; therefore, she should continue to receive intravenous insulin infusion.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the office for the evaluation of abnormal lipid profile. He does not have any active complaints at this visit. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia. Current medication includes lisinopril. Approximately 6 months ago, he was started on a low-fat diet to help him lose weight and improve dyslipidemia. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and myocardial infarction in his father. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. A repeat lipid panel obtained last week reveals low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels of 250 mg/dL. Chart review reveals the patient was unable to tolerate statin therapy in the past due to myopathy. The physician recommends the initiation of ezetimibe. Which of the following best describes the most likely mechanism of action of ezetimibe?

choices.text: Inhibition of lipolysis in adipose tissue
Inhibition of intestinal bile acid reabsorption

questions.solution:
This patient with elevated LDL cholesterol levels, not improved by dietary changes, is started on ezetimibe, a lipid lowering drug. It prevents cholesterol absorption at the intestinal brush border by inhibiting Niemann-Pick C1 like 1 (NPC1L1) protein, which is a critical mediator of cholesterol absorption. This results in a significant reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels. However, little to no effect is observed on very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) or high-density lipoproteins (HDL) levels. It is usually indicated in patients with hyperlipidemia in combination with statins or as a monotherapy to prevent the side effects of high dose statins (e.g., myopathy, deranged liver aminotransferase). Moreover, it can also be combined with fenofibrate to treat mixed hyperlipidemia. Side effects of ezetimibe include gastrointestinal (GI) upset, headache and, rarely, liver damage or myalgias.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of lipolysis in adipose tissue:
Incorrect: Niacin, a lipid lowering drug, acts to prevent lipolysis by inhibiting hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue. Its overall effect is a major increase in HDL and a decrease in LDL. Ezetimibe has no direct effect on lipolysis in adipose tissue.  
❌ Inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase:
Incorrect: Statins are lipid-lowering drugs that competitively inhibit HMG CoA reductase, an enzyme which normally converts HMG CoA to mevalonate. This leads to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and increase in LDL recycling. Although ezetimibe helps reduce LDL levels, it does not directly affect HMG CoA reductase.  
❌ Inhibition of intestinal bile acid reabsorption:
Incorrect: Bile acid resins (e.g., cholestyramine, colestipol) are lipid lowering drugs that act by binding the bile acids (not cholesterol) in the intestine to prevent its reabsorption at the intestinal brush border.  
✅ Inhibition of intestinal cholesterol absorption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of low-density-lipoprotein receptor (LDL-R) degradation:
Incorrect: PCSK9 inhibitors act by inhibiting the degradation of LDL-R, facilitating the removal of LDL from the bloodstream. Alirocumab is a common example of this drug.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of his abnormal lipid panel and is currently asymptomatic. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, and an episode of pancreatitis 6 months ago. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in father and chronic renal failure in mother. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily, drinks 2 glasses of beer on weekends and does not use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. His BMI is 33.5 kg/m2. Physical examination is noncontributory. Fasting laboratory workup at today’s visit is shown below. The patient is recommended to maintain a low-fat diet to reduce weight, and fenofibrate is added to his medication regime. Which of the following best describes the effect of fenofibrate therapy on serum LDL, HDL and TGs?  

Laboratory value
Results
Glucose
120 mg/dL
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)  
160 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
30 mg/dL
Triglycerides
700 mg/dL
Hemoglobin A1c
6.6 %
questions.solution:
This patient with moderate-to-severe hypertriglyceridemia (TG >500 mg/dL) and a past medical history of an episode of pancreatitis is likely to benefit from fibrate therapy.

Fibrates activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) which is a major regulator of lipid metabolism. PPARα decreases the liver's very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) levels and increases the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) in the adipose tissues. LPL in turn hydrolyzes the triglycerides in chylomicron and VLDL to free fatty acids (FFA), thus lowering triglyceride levels. The FFA can be used for energy or converted back to TGs. Finally fibrates also increase the synthesis of HDL by facilitating the transfer of TGs from chylomicrons and VLDL to HDL. Unlike statins, fibrates have little effect on LDL, whereas, statins are not as effective in lowering TGs. Therefore, both can be combined to treat mixed dyslipidemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Statins inhibit the action of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase, which normally converts HMG CoA to mevalonate. This leads to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and increase in low density lipoproteins (LDL) recycling by the up-regulation of LDL receptors on hepatic cells. It has a moderate effect on TG levels.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) tend to decrease LDL cholesterol by preventing bile acid reabsorption in the intestine (enterohepatic circulation). It slightly increases the levels of TGs rather than decreasing it.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These changes are observed with fish oil and marine omega-3 fatty acids. It decreases the transport of free fatty acids to the liver and inhibits the activity of TG-synthesizing enzymes. It decreases TGs only at high doses.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: A significant increase in HDL is observed with the use of niacin. A major decrease in TG is not seen.

questions.text: A 88-year-old man presents to the emergency department for new-onset confusion. The patient's daughter reports he was in his usual state of health until today when he was noted as “acting funny.” The patient has a past medical history of hypertension,  hyperlipidemia, diabetes, chronic back pain, coronary artery disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medications include hydrocodone, aspirin, prazosin, amlodipine, simvastatin, metformin, and sildenafil. He is normally alert, awake, and oriented to time, place, and person and requires only some assistance with activities of daily independent living. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.7°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 130/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals an elderly male who appears confused. He states the year is “1964” and “Gerald Ford is the president of the United States.'' Neurologic examination is otherwise unremarkable. Abdominal examination reveals suprapubic tenderness to palpation, for which he is provided 2 mg of intravenous morphine. Urinalysis demonstrates 3+ bacteria with positive nitrite and leukocyte esterase. During his stay, he attempts to get out of bed several times and begins shouting at the nursing staff. Several attempts at verbal de-escalation, redirection, and reorientation are unsuccessful. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents for evaluation of new-onset confusion in a possible urinary tract infection (suprapubic tenderness with bacteriuria and pyuria on urinalysis). His presentation is consistent with agitated delirium, unresponsive to redirection and reorientation. Due to the threat to self, providers, and staff, the next best management step is treating this patient’s agitation, which according to the Beers criteria, includes first-generation antipsychotics like haloperidol.    

The Beers criteria refer to a continuously updated list of potentially inappropriate medications for geriatric patients, primarily due to high risk for adverse events, including delirium, falls, urinary retention, and constipation. According to the most recently updated version of the Beers criteria, general medication classes to avoid in patients in the elderly includes benzodiazepines, antimuscarinic medications (including first-generation antihistamines), opiates, alpha-blockers, NSAIDs, and proton pump inhibitors. A review of this patient’s medication list reveals prescriptions for two medication classes (opiate and alpha-blocker).  

Option Analysis

✅ Haloperidol :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Lorazepam :
Incorrect: Administration of lorazepam will likely augment this patient’s delirium. Beer’s criteria recommend avoiding concurrent administration of benzodiazepines and opiates.   
❌ Diphenhydramine :
Incorrect: According to Beer’s criteria, first-generation antihistamines should generally be avoided in patients with delirium, as the antimuscarinic effects of this medication may worsen symptoms.  
❌ Midazolam :
Incorrect: Administration of midazolam will likely augment this patient’s delirium. Beer’s criteria currently recommend avoidance of concurrent administration of both benzodiazepines and opiates.   
❌ Tramadol :
Incorrect: Tramadol, a medication with several mechanisms of action, should be avoided in geriatric patients due to the risk of hyponatremia from a syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found altered at home with scattered pill bottles at the bedside. He endorses hearing a persistent “ringing sound” in the ears and has several episodes of nausea and vomiting while being triaged. Past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease, stroke, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), respirations are 26/min, pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. A medication overdose is suspected, and the patient is empirically administered sodium bicarbonate to enhance renal drug excretion. Which of the following medications did this patient likely ingest?
questions.solution:
Several medications (e.g., phenobarbital, methotrexate, aspirin) are weak acids. Aspirin is an example of a weak acid in both a charged (deprotonated) and uncharged (protonated) form. The uncharged molecule can quickly move across cellular barriers like the blood-brain barrier. As a result, the uncharged form of the drug can cross the blood-brain barrier, accumulate in the brain, and result in altered mental status and cerebral edema. Moreover, the uncharged form of salicylate can be reabsorbed from the renal collecting system, thereby preventing drug elimination and perpetuating its harmful effects in the setting of an overdose.      

Treatment of overdose with weak acids is often achieved via alkalinization through sodium bicarbonate administration. By increasing systemic pH, salicylate converts to its charged (deprotonated form) and thus cannot rapidly diffuse into the central nervous system, as charged molecules do not easily diffuse across the blood-brain barrier. Alkalinization also results in the trapping of salicylate anions within the renal tubule, preventing back-diffusion across the renal epithelium into c circulation.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.   


Option Analysis

✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amitriptyline:
Incorrect: Amitriptyline is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate can be used to enhance cardiac stabilization in patients with tricyclic antidepressant overdose. However, it is not used to improve renal excretion.  
❌ Methylphenidate:
Incorrect: Methylphenidate is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. Administration of ammonium chloride is used to enhance the excretion of weak base drugs.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. As a result, ammonium chloride (not sodium bicarbonate) can be administered to enhance drug excretion. Moreover, β-blocker overdose is characterized by bradycardia, not tachycardia.
❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. Overdose with atropine is characterized by antimuscarinic symptoms such as tachycardia, increased body temperature, cutaneous flushing, and urinary retention. Furthermore, ammonium chloride (not sodium bicarbonate) can be administered to enhance the excretion of weak base drugs.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset left back pain and hematuria. The patient states that since the early morning, she has been having intense pain in the left mid-back that comes in waves. She has no nausea or vomiting. Past medical history includes hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. The patient is currently in pain. Urinalysis findings are shown below. Non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates a 2 mm obstructing stone mid-ureter on the left.  Which of the following historical or physical exam findings would be most consistent with the underlying diagnosis?  

Laboratory value
Result
Urinalysis

Color
Clear
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
Negative
Blood
Large
Leukocyte esterase  
Negative
Nitrites
Negative
Leukocytes
1-2/hpf  
Erythrocytes
25-50/hpf  
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent
Casts
None
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and urinalysis findings that are concerning for nephrolithiasis, which is confirmed with non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis that shows a renal stone on the left. Left flank (or costovertebral angle) tenderness would be an expected physical examination finding.

Nephrolithiasis, also known as renal calculi or renal (or kidney) stones, is a painful condition where crystals form in the kidney that potentially lead to urinary tract obstruction.  Renal stones usually form when urine becomes oversaturated with minerals and salts, including calcium, oxalate, and uric acid. Common renal stone types include calcium oxalate-, calcium phosphate-, uric acid-, cystine-, and struvite stones. Patients classically present with the acute onset of flank pain, which may radiate to the groin. Patients may have associated hematuria, dysuria urgency, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination may reveal unilateral flank or costovertebral angle tenderness. Patients often appear uncomfortable from the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Left flank tenderness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Suprapubic tenderness:
Incorrect:  Suprapubic tenderness is typically suggestive of bladder inflammation or other lower urinary tract pathology, such as cystitis. This patient’s urinalysis is not indicative of an infection, and CT shows a left kidney stone.  
❌ High fever:
Incorrect:  Fever can be seen with renal stones, it typically indicates pyelonephritis, or infection of the kidney, which can be a complication of renal stones. However, there is no infection evident on urinalysis and there is no evidence of pyelonephritis on CT.  
❌ Bradycardia:
Incorrect:   Bradycardia is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis. Tachycardia is more likely to be seen as a consequence of pain.  
❌ Abdominal distension:
Incorrect:   Abdominal distention is not a typical finding in nephrolithiasis, however, it may be seen if there is associated nausea and vomiting, which this patient does not have.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right flank pain for the past 6 hours and 3 days of dysuria and urinary frequency. The patient has a past medical history of recurrent urinary tract infections, hypertension, and diabetes. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 176/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 101/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable and is vomiting into an emesis basin. She is started on IV normal saline, IV ketorolac, and ondansetron. A CBC and basic metabolic panel are pending. Urinalysis findings are shown below. Non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows an obstructing stone in the right ureter. What type of crystals are most likely to be identified on urine microscopy?  

Laboratory value
Result
Urinalysis

Color
Clear
pH
8.1  
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
Negative
Blood
Large
Leukocyte esterase  
Large
Nitrites
Present
Leukocytes
50-100/hpf  
Erythrocytes
25-50/hpf
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent
Casts
None
Gram stain  
Gram-negative rods

choices.text: Amorphous wedge-shaped crystals in rosette pattern

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms and physical examination findings consistent with nephrolithiasis and a concurrent urinary tract infection. Additionally, the patient’s urine pH is > 8, making this likely to be a struvite stone. On urine microscopy, struvite stones appear as coffin lid-shaped crystals.

Nephrolithiasis, also known as renal calculi or renal stones, is a painful condition where crystals form in the kidneys. Common renal stone types include calcium oxalate-, calcium phosphate-, uric acid-, cystine-, and struvite stones. Struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones are strongly associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs) with urease-producing organisms (e.g. Proteus species). Hence, they are sometimes called “infection stones.” Struvite stones form within the lumen of the renal pelvis and can extend into one or more of the renal calyces. They are typically large and are at risk of causing obstruction. Therefore, urological consultation for stone removal is necessary to prevent complications.

Identifying the stone type can assist in determining treatment and prevention. Renal stone composition analysis; urine microscopy; and 24-hour urine collection for pH, calcium, oxalate, citrate, uric acid, and phosphorus should be performed. The following table shows the findings and treatments associated with the different types of renal stones.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Coffin lid-shaped crystals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hexagon-shaped crystals:
Incorrect: Hexagon-shaped crystals are seen in patients with cystine stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.  
❌ Rhomboid-shaped crystals:
Incorrect: Rhomboid-shaped crystals are seen in patients with uric acid stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.
❌ Amorphous wedge-shaped crystals in rosette pattern:
Incorrect: Amorphous wedge-shaped crystals in a rosette pattern are seen in patients with calcium-phosphate stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.  
❌ Envelope-shaped crystals:
Incorrect: Envelope or dumbbell-shaped crystals are seen in patients with calcium oxalate stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for four months of persistent lower back pain. She reports that the pain is not related to any specific activity, and it does not improve with over-the-counter pain relievers. The pain wakes her up at night. She also has had increasing fatigue and unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 142/85 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals pallor. Palpation of her spine elicits tenderness over the lumbar vertebrae without deformity. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Which of the following tests will establish the most likely underlying diagnosis?

 Laboratory test  Result 
 Hemoglobin  10.2 g/dL 
 White Blood Cell Count  7,900/mm3 
 Platelet Count  350,000/mm3 
 Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Calcium  12 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  2.0 mg/dL 
 Serum total protein  8 g/dL 
 Serum albumin  3.1 g/dL

choices.text: CT scan of the axial skeleton

questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent nocturnal lower back pain, fatigue, unintentional weight loss, anemia, renal insufficiency, and hypercalcemia likely has multiple myeloma (MM). Additionally, the discrepancy between her total serum protein and albumin level indicates the presence of a monoclonal protein, which is typical of MM. Bone marrow biopsy is necessary to make the diagnosis of MM.  

Multiple myeloma (MM) is a malignancy of plasma cells that accumulate in the bone marrow.  While tests like serum protein electrophoresis can detect monoclonal proteins and CT scans can reveal osteolytic lesions, the gold standard for diagnosing MM is a bone marrow biopsy. This test is necessary for direct visualization of the malignant plasma cells. A definitive diagnosis of MM requires the presence of ≥10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow or a biopsy-proven plasmacytoma, in addition to evidence of end-organ damage (SLiM-CRAB criteria).  



Option Analysis

✅ Bone marrow biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum protein electrophoresis:
Incorrect: While serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) is often the initial test performed to detect a monoclonal protein spike (M-spike) when MM is suspected, it does not provide information on the percentage of clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, which is necessary to make the diagnosis of MM.
❌ 24-hour urinary protein measurement:
Incorrect: This test assesses for the presence of Bence Jones proteins, which are free light chains commonly seen in patients with multiple myeloma. The presence of these proteins can not be used to diagnose MM as they can be present in other conditions like Waldenström macroglobulinemia. Bone marrow biopsy is necessary to make the diagnosis.
❌ Peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: A peripheral blood smear can sometimes show rouleaux formation due to elevated serum proteins in MM. However, clonal plasma cells (the hallmark of MM) are usually not found in the peripheral blood, and bone marrow biopsy is necessary to establish the diagnosis.
❌ CT scan of the axial skeleton:
Incorrect: While a CT scan of the axial skeleton can reveal lytic bone lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma, lytic lesions can be caused by other diseases as well. Bone marrow biopsy is necessary to make the diagnosis of MM.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic for follow-up after being discharged from the hospital for acute chest syndrome. He was diagnosed with sickle cell disease (SCD) in childhood. Additional past medical history includes frequent hospitalizations for painful episodes and a cholecystectomy at age 21 due to chronic cholelithiasis. He takes folic acid daily. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination shows pallor, scleral icterus, and the absence of a palpable spleen on abdominal examination. Laboratory results are shown below. Hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals 85% hemoglobin S and 15% hemoglobin F. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

 Laboratory test  Results 
 Hemoglobin  8.8 g/dL 
 WBC  12,000/mm2 
 Platelets  370,000/mm2 
 Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.1 mEq/L 
 Chloride  102 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  24 mEq/L 
 Total Bilirubin  3.5 mg/dL 
 Direct Bilirubin  0.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation, including frequent painful episodes, acute chest syndrome, and chronic cholelithiasis, is consistent with sickle cell disease (SCD)--confirmed by the presence of 85% hemoglobin S and 15% hemoglobin F on hemoglobin electrophoresis. This patient should be started on preventative therapy with hydroxyurea to reduce the frequency of painful episodes.    

Management of SCD, especially in those with severe manifestations, includes administration of disease-modifying therapy with hydroxyurea. Hydroxyurea reduces the concentration of hemoglobin S by increasing the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF). This results in decreased frequency of vaso-occlusive events and reduced morbidity from complications like acute chest syndrome.      

In addition to hydroxyurea, patients should also be advised about lifestyle modifications to reduce exposure to potential triggers (e.g. cold weather). Folic acid supplementation should be provided not just due to the increased cell turnover from chronic hemolysis, but also to counter the side effects of hydroxyurea that can precipitate megaloblastic anemia. Given the functional asplenia associated with SCD, patients should be immunized against encapsulated organisms. Chronic transfusions should be considered for patients with frequent acute painful episodes despite being on hydroxyurea. Genetic counseling should be offered to family members.  

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate hydroxyurea therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiate chronic transfusions :
Incorrect: Chronic red blood cell transfusions can be used to treat certain patients with severe disease who have frequent acute painful episodes despite taking hydroxyurea. This patient should first be started on hydroxyurea first.
❌ Administer penicillin:
Incorrect: Prophylactic penicillin is crucial for children under 5 years of age with sickle cell disease (SCD) to protect against invasive pneumococcal disease. It is not indicated in this adult patient without evidence of infection.
❌ Recommend lifestyle modifications only:
Incorrect: Avoiding certain environmental triggers such as cold temperatures and high altitudes can mitigate vaso-occlusive episodes; however, this patient with severe disease and frequent episodes should be started on a disease-modifying medication such as hydroxyurea.
❌ Administer low-dose aspirin :
Incorrect: Platelet inhibition with aspirin has shown no evidence of clinical benefit in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband for worsening confusion and lethargy over the past 24 hours. He found multiple empty bottles of acetaminophen on the kitchen counter. The patient states that she was trying to relieve her headache. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg, pulse is 95/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, she is drowsy but arousable. Her pupils are 3 mm and reactive. She exhibits asterixis with outstretched arms. Abdominal examination is significant for right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain. Laboratory evaluation shows AST 4500 U/L, ALT 5300 U/L and prolonged INR. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with increasing confusion and lethargy, asterixis, significantly elevated liver enzymes, and a prolonged INR. This clinical presentation, in addition to the discovery of multiple empty bottles of acetaminophen, is suggestive of acetaminophen overdose leading to acute liver failure (liver toxicity and hepatic encephalopathy). N-acetylcysteine (NAC) should be given immediately as it is the antidote to acetaminophen poisoning.

Acetaminophen overdose is a major cause of drug-induced liver injury. When taken in excess, hepatic stores of glutathione, a crucial antioxidant, become depleted. This leads to the accumulation of a harmful metabolite that inflicts damage on hepatocytes. The early stage of overdose manifests as nausea, vomiting, and a general sense of unwellness. As liver damage progresses, clinical features such as hepatic encephalopathy become evident. The administration of N-acetylcysteine (NAC) as soon as possible is crucial. NAC is a precursor to glutathione and promotes non-toxic metabolic pathways, thereby preventing and diminishing liver injury.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer N-acetylcysteine (NAC):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is not effective for acetaminophen poisoning, as acetaminophen is metabolized by the liver and not excreted by the kidneys.
❌ Administer activated charcoal:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal can limit acetaminophen absorption if given within 4 hours of ingestion. However, its effectiveness diminishes with delayed presentation as seen in this patient.  
❌ Administer lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is a synthetic sugar used as an osmotic agent to treat hepatic encephalopathy by promoting the excretion of ammonia in the intestines. However, giving N-acetylcysteine immediately is the priority as it can decrease further liver injury and improve mortality in patients with acetaminophen overdose.  
❌ Consult surgery for liver transplantation:
Incorrect: Although the high INR indicates liver synthetic dysfunction and this patient with liver toxicity and encephalopathy has acute liver failure, liver transplantation is not the immediate next step in management. N-acetylcysteine (NAC) treatment remains the priority as it can markedly alter the prognosis and improve mortality from acetaminophen overdose.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought into the intensive care unit for septic shock due to malaria. He is currently on mechanical ventilation via an endotracheal tube, and is sedated on propofol. Medications administered include chloroquine, heparin, and propofol. Which of the following is true regarding the volume of distribution (VD) and lipophilicity of these medications?

choices.text: Chloroquine has a low VD since it is hydrophobic
Heparin has a low VD since it is hydrophobic
Heparin has a high VD since it is hydrophilic
Propofol has a low VD since it is lipophilic
Propofol has a high VD since it is lipophilic

questions.solution:
Lipophilicity affects the volume of distribution of medications. The more hydrophobic (lipophilic) a medication, the more easily it can diffuse through the lipid bilayer of cell membranes and distribute throughout the body, especially in adipose tissue. Medications that are very hydrophobic (lipophilic) tend to have high volumes of distribution. For example, propofol is very lipophilic and its volume of distribution can approach 60 L/kg in adults. This explains why propranolol, unlike many other beta-blockers, can be used to treat essential tremor and performance anxiety – it is much more lipophilic than other beta-blockers and easily diffuses across the blood-brain barrier.  

On the other hand, medications that are very hydrophilic (lipophobic) tend to stay in the bloodstream, as they do not readily cross cell membranes. For example, heparin’s volume of distribution is around 0.1 L/kg in adults.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chloroquine has a low VD since it is hydrophobic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Chloroquine is actually very hydrophobic (lipophilic) and thus has a very high VD.
❌ Heparin has a low VD since it is hydrophobic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Heparin is actually very hydrophilic (lipophobic) and thus has a low VD.
❌ Heparin has a high VD since it is hydrophilic:
Incorrect: Medications with a high VD  are generally hydrophobic (lipophilic), since hydrophobic molecules can easily cross lipid membrane layers and distribute widely throughout tissue. Heparin is actually very hydrophilic (lipophobic) and thus has a low VD.
❌ Propofol has a low VD since it is lipophilic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD  are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Propofol is actually very hydrophobic (lipophilic) and thus has a very high VD.
✅ Propofol has a high VD since it is lipophilic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of progressive fatigue, confusion, and a rash over her lower extremities. She reports a severe headache and dyspnea. Her past medical history is notable for systemic lupus erythematosus with alopecia and arthritis which has been well-controlled for the past five years with hydroxychloroquine. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 95/55 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Examination reveals pallor and a petechial rash on her legs bilaterally. She has no alopecia and no joint tenderness or swelling. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits, but the patient is confused. Laboratory evaluation is significant for hemoglobin of 6.9 g/dL, platelet count of 25,000/mm<sup>3</sup>, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 400 U/L, and schistocytes on peripheral smear. IV fluids are initiated. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with confusion, headache, fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes seen on peripheral smear), and neurological dysfunction, likely thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy characterized by abnormalities in the vessel wall of arterioles and capillaries that lead to microvascular thrombosis. Patients typically present with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), thrombocytopenia, neurologic abnormalities, and renal involvement. All patients with presumed or confirmed TTP require plasma exchange.

TTP arises from severe deficiency or dysfunction of the ADAMTS13 enzyme, which is responsible for cleaving large multimers of von Willebrand factor. Without the action of this enzyme, unusually large von Willebrand factor multimers accumulate and lead to spontaneous platelet aggregation, resulting in microvascular thrombosis, hemolysis, and ischemic end-organ damage. Immediate plasma exchange is the treatment for TTP. It removes the autoantibodies that inhibit ADAMTS13 and replenishes the patient's system with functional ADAMTS13 from donor plasma. This halts the pathologic process, preventing further microvascular thrombosis and organ damage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Plasma exchange:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Packed red blood cell transfusion:
Incorrect: While this patient has a hemoglobin <7 g/dL, transfusing her will not treat the underlying cause of her condition. Additionally, providing packed red blood cell transfusions without addressing the underlying diagnosis of TTP can exacerbate microvascular thrombosis.  
❌ High-dose corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids may be used as adjunctive therapy for TTP, but plasma exchange is the mainstay of treatment.  
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: While thrombocytopenia and anemia might raise concerns about bone marrow disorders, this patient's presentation with fever, hemolytic anemia, confusion, thrombocytopenia, and schistocytes on peripheral smear strongly suggests TTP. A bone marrow biopsy is not indicated.  
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Incorrect: IVIG is not the primary treatment for TTP. It might be considered in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) but not in the setting of TTP.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the clinic reporting recurrent episodes of fatigue over the past several months. She mentions that her stamina has deteriorated, particularly during her weekly runs. Her past medical history is notable for recurrent episodes of mild jaundice during her childhood, and she recalls being told to avoid certain medications. Family history reveals that both her mother and her only sibling have had episodes of anemia and jaundice. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 100/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination is notable for mild scleral icterus and tachycardia but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. Direct Coombs test is negative. Which of the following is most likely to establish the underlying diagnosis?  

Laboratory test  
Results
Hemoglobin (Hb)  
9.8 g/dL  
Hematocrit (Hct)  
29%
White Blood Cells (WBC)  
6,500/mm3
Platelets (Plt)  
250,000/mm3
Reticulocyte Count  
8%
Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)  
88 fL
Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC)  
38 g/dL
Total Bilirubin  
2.6 mg/dL
Unconjugated Bilirubin  
1.9 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  
300 U/L
Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of recurrent episodes of fatigue, combined with her family history and the evidence of hemolytic anemia with increased MCHC on laboratory findings, is consistent with a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis (HS). The osmotic fragility test can be used to diagnose HS.

HS is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by anomalies in red blood cell (RBC) membrane proteins. These anomalies lead to the formation of spherically shaped RBCs, which differ from the usual biconcave shape. The structural rigidity of these spherocytes makes them more susceptible to premature sequestration and destruction in the spleen, resulting in hemolysis.

Clinically, patients with HS can present with anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly. They also exhibit increased reticulocyte counts as the bone marrow increases RBC production to compensate for ongoing hemolysis. One of the hallmarks of HS on laboratory findings is an elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). Spherocytes have a reduced surface area compared to normal red blood cells due to their spherical shape. This decreased surface area results in a higher concentration of hemoglobin within the cell, contributing to the elevated MCHC. The osmotic fragility test can be used to confirm the diagnosis of HS.  

Option Analysis

✅ Osmotic fragility test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Incorrect: This test evaluates the types and proportions of hemoglobin in blood, primarily diagnosing conditions like sickle cell anemia or thalassemias. This patient's familial history and laboratory values do not suggest a hemoglobinopathy.  
❌ Lead level:
Incorrect: Elevated lead levels are associated with anemia due to impaired hemoglobin synthesis, often presenting with a low MCV. This patient's normal MCV, hemolytic anemia, and family history make HS more likely.  
❌ G6PD assay:
Incorrect: The G6PD assay identifies glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. While the patient's history of avoiding certain medications might suggest a concern for G6PD deficiency, the condition is X-linked recessive and primarily affects males. Additionally, the family history and her laboratory findings of elevated MCHC align more closely with hereditary spherocytosis.  
❌ Blood smear:
Incorrect: A peripheral blood smear can identify various red cell morphologies. In HS, spherocytes might be seen, but their presence alone is not diagnostic. The definitive test for HS, given the clinical picture, is an osmotic fragility test.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of peptic ulcer disease unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors and H2 receptor antagonists. The patient mentions that his father had a similar problem in his 30s and underwent surgery for a "neck tumor,” but the patient is unsure of the details. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears well-developed and is not in acute distress. There is mild epigastric tenderness on palpation. Initial laboratory studies are listed below. Which of the following additional family histories would be consistent with this patient’s most likely diagnosis?  

Serum Value
Result
Calcium
Elevated
Gastrin
Elevated
Parathyroid hormone  
Elevated

choices.text: Brother treated for a pituitary adenoma
Mother with surgery for thyroid cancer
Cousin with marfanoid habitus and multiple mucosal neuromas

questions.solution:
The combination of the patient's symptoms of severe peptic ulcer disease, elevated gastrin level, hypercalcemia, and a family history of similar symptoms and potential parathyroid tumor in his father aligns with the typical presentation of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). The presence of additional endocrine tumors in first-degree relatives, such as a pituitary adenoma in his brother, would be a strong indicator of MEN1.

MEN1 is a hereditary syndrome characterized by the predisposition to develop tumors in multiple endocrine glands. The classic triad of MEN1 includes parathyroid tumors leading to primary hyperparathyroidism, pancreatic islet cell tumors which may produce hormones (e.g., gastrin, glucagon, insulin), and pituitary tumors (e.g., non-functioning adenomas, prolactinomas).

Since a wide range of tumors may be involved, the diagnosis requires a high clinical suspicion, a detailed personal and family history, and a thorough history and physical examination. These can help guide further diagnostic considerations and potential genetic testing for the MEN1 mutation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Brother treated for a pituitary adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mother with surgery for thyroid cancer:
Incorrect: Medullary thyroid carcinoma is seen in MEN2. However, this patient’s elevated calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, as well as elevated serum gastrin level, are more suggestive of MEN1 which is not associated with thyroid cancer.  
❌ Cousin with marfanoid habitus and multiple mucosal neuromas:
Incorrect: While this family history could be characteristic of MEN2B, this patient’s family history of a “neck tumor” (parathyroid likely) in his father along with the patient’s elevated serum gastrin, calcium, and parathyroid hormone levels are more suggestive of MEN1.  
❌ Aunt diagnosed with endometrial cancer:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is suggestive of MEN1 (likely parathyroid tumor and gastrin-producing pancreatic tumor). The MEN syndromes do not include endometrial cancer.  
❌ Grandfather with chronic bronchitis:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is suggestive of MEN1. Respiratory conditions are not related to this syndrome.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of a neck mass that has been gradually increasing in size over the last six months. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg. The patient has a marfanoid habitus with mucosal neuromas noted on the lips and tongue. The thyroid gland is enlarged. Subsequent fine-needle aspiration biopsy of a thyroid nodule reveals medullary thyroid carcinoma. Genetic testing confirms a RET mutation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s marfanoid habitus, mucosal neuromas, medullary thyroid cancer, and RET mutation are diagnostic of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN2B). Surgical consultation for thyroidectomy is the most appropriate next step in management.

Medullary thyroid cancer in MEN2B is highly aggressive and often presents at a young age. It is also the main cause of mortality in MEN2B, if not treated promptly. The current standard of care is a total thyroidectomy. This surgery is recommended at the time of diagnosis due to the aggressiveness and early spread of the disease. Early intervention is associated with significantly improved outcomes. A RET inhibitor, such as vandetanib, may be considered for progressive or metastatic disease.

Screening for pheochromocytoma would also be important. If found, tumor resection after appropriate alpha- and beta-adrenergic blockade would be indicated. Patients should be monitored closely with annual hormone levels and imaging studies, as indicated. At-risk family members should also be encouraged to seek genetic counseling.  

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical consultation for thyroidectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radioactive iodine ablation therapy:
Incorrect: Radioactive iodine ablation therapy is not effective for medullary thyroid cancer, as these cells lack the iodine uptake mechanism seen in other thyroid cancers.  
❌ Vandetanib:
Incorrect: Vandetanib (a RET inhibitor) may be considered in the management of progressive or metastatic medullary thyroid carcinoma, but it is not the initial first-line treatment.  
❌ Levothyroxine:
Incorrect: Levothyroxine therapy for thyroid suppression is typically used in the management of certain thyroid cancers that rely on TSH for growth. Medullary thyroid cancer does not originate from thyroid hormone-producing cells, so levothyroxine is not an effective treatment.  
❌ Close monitoring:
Incorrect: This patient was diagnosed with medullary thyroid cancer which appears to be growing. Surgical intervention is warranted and monitoring without surgery is inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic because of shortness of breath that has progressively worsened over the past few weeks. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic calculous cholecystitis. The patient was recently diagnosed with new-onset diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and olmesartan/amlodipine. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 90 bpm, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient’s skin appears bronze. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S3 gallop with a pansystolic murmur over the mitral area. Auscultation of the chest reveals bilateral rales extending from the bases to the mid-lobar regions. There is 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. The basic metabolic panel is shown below. Which of the following historical elements would be expected given this patient’s most likely underlying condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  10.5 g/dl  
 Leukocyte count  4500 /mm3 
 Platelets  165,000/ mm3 
 INR   1.9 
 Creatinine  1.1 mg/dl 
 Albumin   2.3 g/dl 
 Bilirubin (Total)  1.5 mg/dl 
 Iron   200 mcg/dL 
 Serum ferritin  430 ng/mL 
 Transferrin serum iron saturation (TSAT)  65% (normal: 20-50%) 
 AST  98 U/L 
 ALT   100 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of new-onset heart failure and diabetes mellitus associated with bronze skin; and elevated liver enzymes, ferritin level, and transferrin saturation. The most likely diagnosis is hemochromatosis, which can be associated with a family history of liver disease since primary hemochromatosis is associated with a genetic mutation in the HEF gene.    

Hemochromatosis (i.e., iron overload) can be classified based on the etiology as primary (i.e., genetic mutation) or secondary (i.e., associated with alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, HCV infection, thalassemia, sickle cell disease, multiple blood transfusions, or excessive oral iron supplementation).  

Primary hemochromatosis is caused by an autosomal recessive mutation in the HFE gene which is responsible for controlling iron absorption from the small intestine. Iron accumulation leads to long-term oxidative stress, subsequently inducing irreversible organ damage. There are rare cases of non-HFE hereditary hemochromatosis which can be tested for if there is high suspicion and HFE gene testing is negative.  

Signs and symptoms of hemochromatosis result from iron accumulation in several organ systems, which can be seen in this patient. Iron deposition in the skin can result in bronze discoloration of the skin. Iron deposition in the pancreas can lead to diabetes mellitus, and iron deposition in the myocardium can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy. Other manifestations of hemochromatosis include arthropathy (2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal joints), and liver cirrhosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of liver disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of IV drug use :
Incorrect: History of prior IV drug use is a significant risk factor for chronic viral hepatitis; however, given this patient's findings consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy, bronze skin,and alterations in iron metabolism (i.e., high iron and transferrin saturation), hemochromatosis is more likely the cause of his elevated liver enzymes.
❌ History of chronic alcohol use:
Incorrect: Chronic alcoholic consumption is associated with abnormalities of liver enzymes and functions; however, it is not associated with an elevation in the TSAT. Also, alcoholic liver disease is typically associated with an AST/ALT ratio of 2:1 or greater which is not seen in this patient.
❌ History of lipid-lowering drug use:
Incorrect: Statins (e.g., atorvastatin) are associated with variable degrees of hepatotoxicity ranging from asymptomatic elevations in the liver enzymes to fulminant hepatitis; however, this medication is not associated with abnormalities in the iron profile, bronze skin, new-onset diabetes, and dilated cardiomyopathy.
❌ History of autoimmune disease:
Incorrect: Autoimmune hepatitis is associated with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain. Additionally, it is associated with a marked rise in serum AST and ALT levels which is not seen in this patient, and it would not account for the abnormal iron studies.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the hospital with four days of erythema, pain, and swelling of the right leg. The patient's medical history includes hypertension and major depressive disorder. Current medications include carvedilol and fluoxetine. Medication allergies include doxycycline, penicillin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Temperature is 100.4 ºF (38 ºC), heart rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 138/79 mmHg. On physical examination, there is erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the right leg extending from a 2 cm wound at the lateral malleolus up to the tibial plateau. Wound culture is positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is treated with intravenous vancomycin and is transitioned to oral linezolid on the day of discharge.
