He is counseled on risks and possible side effects of this medication. Which of the following side effects may occur due to drug-drug interactions?
questions.solution:
This patient on fluoxetine has evidence of right leg cellulitis and a wound infected with methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA). Several oral antibiotics can be used to treat MRSA, such as doxycycline, linezolid and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Linezolid works well against gram-positive bacteria (including MRSA); however, linezolid also has weak monoamine oxidase inhibitory (MAOI) activity. For this reason, linezolid can increase levels of norepinephrine and serotonin, which can lead to serotonin syndrome.  

Serotonin syndrome is due to abnormally high levels of serotonin, and generally occurs in patients taking multiple serotonergic medications (e.g., linezolid, MAOI, SNRI, SSRI). It is a clinical diagnosis and often manifests with agitation, clonus, hyperreflexia and hyperthermia. Other clinical manifestations include diaphoresis, dry mucous membranes, and overactive bowels. Treatment is centered on stopping the offending medication and providing supportive care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Agitation and hyperreflexia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bradykinesia and micrographia:
Incorrect: These are features that can be seen with drug-induced Parkinsonism or Parkinson disease. Linezolid does not cause Parkinsonism.
❌ Involuntary mouth movements:
Incorrect: Tardive dyskinesia can result from overuse or use of multiple anti-dopaminergic medications.
❌ Muscle breakdown:
Incorrect: Rhabdomyolysis has been rarely associated with daptomycin, an intravenous agent that can be used to treat methicillin-resistant S. aureus. Linezolid is not associated with rhabdomyolysis.
❌ Sunburn:
Incorrect: Photosensitivity can occur in patients taking doxycycline, another agent that can be used to treat methicillin-resistant S. aureus. Linezolid is not associated with severe/more frequent sunburns (photosensitivity).

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the clinic with bilateral knee, wrist, and hand pain and swelling over the past year. She experiences morning stiffness lasting over 30 minutes. Past medical history is significant for subclinical hyperthyroidism, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. She takes lisinopril and metformin. BMI is 32 kg/m². Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 78/min, blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral knee effusions, with tenderness and limited range of motion. Both wrists and multiple metacarpophalangeal joints on both hands are enlarged and tender to palpation. Laboratory evaluation is unremarkable. X-ray of the right knee is shown below. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient’s underlying condition?


Taken from openi
questions.solution:
This patient's knee, wrist, and hand pain; along with morning stiffness, and chondrocalcinosis on knee imaging is suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD) or pseudogout. In CPPD, calcium pyrophosphate crystals deposit in the joints and soft tissue causes joint pain and swelling. It most commonly affects the knees, wrists, and ankles. It predominantly affects older patients (age > 60 years); therefore, this patient’s age over 60 years is the most likely contributing risk factor.  

Pseudogout, or calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), may be asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging. It also can present as acute or chronic joint pain and swelling. It typically presents as acute monoarticular or polyarticular joint pain and swelling. However chronic pseudogout can involve the bilateral wrists and small joints of the hands and has been called “pseudo-rheumatoid arthritis" (pseudo-RA) when there is a non-erosive, inflammatory arthritis with CPP crystals found in joint fluid. Patients with chronic pseudogout can also present with chronic, degenerative arthritis, resembling osteoarthritis.  

Hypomagnesemia, hyperparathyroidism, and hemochromatosis have been associated with CPPD. Other important risk factors include trauma or surgery to the involved joints, as well as bisphosphonate use.  

Option Analysis

✅ Age over 60 years:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subclinical hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Hypothyroidism, and not hyperthyroidism, is associated with the development of CPDD.
❌ BMI >30 kg/m2:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Obesity is not a known risk factor for CPPD.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Studies have not shown an association between diabetes mellitus and CPPD.
❌ Female sex:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Biological males and females are affected equally by CPPD.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic due to intermittent blood in his urine. The patient first noticed it 3 months ago, and it is becoming more frequent. The patient has also unintentionally lost 20 pounds over the past 3 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and current medications include amlodipine and carvedilol. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 50 years. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen shows a 4 cm mass in the left kidney. A biopsy is taken and shows renal cell carcinoma. CT of the chest is subsequently performed and shows multiple metastatic lesions in the bilateral lungs. The patient is started on a medication that stimulates cytotoxic T-cell proliferation and activation. Which of the following medications is being given to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presented with gross hematuria and unintentional weight loss, has been diagnosed with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC typically occurs in patients older than 50 (median age around 64 years old), and is more common in men than women. Smoking is a known risk factor for RCC.    

Aldessleukin, a recombinant interleukin-2,  is an immunomodulating agent used in the treatment of metastatic RCC and melanoma. It exerts its antitumor effects by stimulating IL-2 receptors, leading to activation and proliferation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes and natural killer cells. This helps the immune system fight against cancerous cells. Recombinant IL-2 can also promote the secretion of secondary cytokines, further improving the immune response.  

The side effects of recombinant interleukin-2 are usually dose-dependent, and can be reversed with dose reduction or stopping the medication. These side effects include hypotension, peripheral edema, and weight gain. Additionally, some patients have experienced neurotoxicity or acute kidney injury as a result of using recombinant IL-2.  

Option Analysis

✅ Aldesleukin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Basiliximab:
Incorrect: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody against the interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor. By blocking IL-2R, it prevents the proliferation of lymphocytes and suppresses the immune response. 
❌ Anakinra:
Incorrect: Anakinra is an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist. It blocks and prevents the proliferation of lymphocytes and depresses their cytotoxic ability. 
❌ Infliximab:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody that works against soluble tumor necrosis factor-alpha. It suppresses the immune response and lymphocyte activation and is used in certain autoimmune disorders (e.g. Crohn’s disease)
❌ Etanercept:
Incorrect: Etanercept is a fusion protein that binds to and sequesters tumor necrosis factor alpha, thereby preventing its action in stimulating the immune response and leukocyte activation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to his cardiologist for a follow-up appointment after being prescribed a new medication several weeks ago. Symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity swelling have improved. However, he has noticed that his chest wall has been more tender than usual. Moreover, the patient has had difficulty achieving an erection. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for bilateral gynecomastia. Which medications were most likely prescribed to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of heart failure, presents several weeks after initiating a new medication. His history and physical examination demonstrate gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction, which are concerning for antiandrogenic side effects. Of the medications listed, only spironolactone carries this side effect profile.    

Spironolactone works primarily as a competitive aldosterone receptor antagonist in the cortical collecting tubule. It induces diuresis while preserving plasma potassium levels. In addition to this mechanism, spironolactone carries moderate anti-androgen effects via the blockade of androgen receptors. This blockade can result in gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido, and mood changes in men. When used in women, anti-androgen effects can result in breast enlargement and menstrual disturbances.  

Despite these side effects, spironolactone’s anti-androgenic effects make it a useful medication in treating several clinical conditions and heart failure. It is often used to treat acne vulgaris and hirsutism in women and acts as hormone therapy for transgender females. 

Option Analysis

✅ Spironolactone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic often prescribed for treating heart failure and hypervolemia. It does not carry anti-androgenic properties that would cause gynecomastia and erectile dysfunction.
❌ Carvedilol:
Incorrect: ꞵ-blockers are often employed in treating heart failure and can cause depression. However, they are not known to cause gynecomastia. 
❌ Milrinone:
Incorrect: Milrinone is another medication often used in the treatment of heart failure and pulmonary hypertension that works via activation of protein kinase A and inhibition of PDE3, which leads to increased inotropy and chronotropy. 
❌ Eplerenone :
Incorrect: Eplerenone, like spironolactone, works as a competitive aldosterone antagonist. However, it lacks the anti-androgenic properties associated with spironolactone.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of new-onset gait difficulties. The patient received a right-sided gluteal intramuscular injection at her orthopedist's office three days ago for shoulder pain. She does not have bowel or bladder symptoms or lower extremity pain. She never had trouble walking before and had no gait problems at her appointment three days ago. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient leans toward her right side with ambulation. When asked to stand on the right leg, the patient’s left pelvis tilts downwards. Intragluteal injection at which of the following anatomic sites is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Superior portion of the posterior thigh

questions.solution:
This patient’s gait disturbance is consistent with a Trendelenburg gait, characterized by a contralateral hip drop of the unaffected side while walking due to the weakness of the gluteus medius. This muscle is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1), which was most likely injured secondary to intramuscular injection over the superomedial quadrant of the right buttock.  

The superolateral quadrant of the buttock serves as the safest site for dorsogluteal injections. It can be located by dividing the buttock into four using a cross shape and administering the injection in the upper outer quadrant. This region, however, is at some risk of superior gluteal or sciatic nerve injury. Most intragluteal injections target the ventrolateral gluteal area, which is in a triangle formed by the anterior superior iliac spine and the iliac crest.

Option Analysis

❌ Superolateral quadrant of the buttock:
Incorrect: The superolateral quadrant of the buttock is the safest gluteal region to administer intramuscular injections.
❌ Inferolateral quadrant of the buttock:
Incorrect: The inferolateral quadrant is a high-risk area for potential sciatic nerve injury. Sciatic nerve injury presents with knee flexion and ankle plantarflexion weakness, paresthesias, and loss of sensation rather than Trendelenburg gait.
✅ Superomedial quadrant of the buttock:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferomedial quadrant of the buttock:
Incorrect: The inferomedial quadrant is a high-risk area for potential sciatic nerve injury. Sciatic nerve injury presents with knee flexion and ankle plantarflexion weakness, paresthesias, and loss of sensation rather than Trendelenburg gait.
❌ Superior portion of the posterior thigh:
Incorrect: The superior portion of the posterior thigh is a high-risk region for sciatic nerve injury due to its large size as it passes into the thigh. Sciatic nerve injury presents knee flexionankle plantarflexion  weakness, paresthesia, and loss of sensation rather than a Trendelenburg gait.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with fatigue and intermittent joint pain over the past few months. Recently, she has noticed oral ulcers. She takes no regular medications and has no known allergies. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg, heart rate is 78/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals skin pallor and three oral ulcers. She has tenderness and swelling over multiple metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of the hands bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation is notable for positive antinuclear antibodies and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Nodules over the extensor surfaces of the elbows
Well-defined, erythematous plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces of the elbows
Tender, erythematous nodules on the shins

questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of fatigue, joint pain, and oral ulcers coupled with her laboratory findings strongly suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). One of the classic dermatological manifestations of SLE is a discoid rash, which is considered chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus. The lesions of discoid lupus erythematous are typically erythematous indurated plaques with scale that may lead to scarring. They occur most often on sun-exposed areas, such as the face, neck, and scalp.

SLE is a complex, multisystem autoimmune disorder characterized by a wide range of clinical features. Key dermatological manifestations include the characteristic malar rash, appearing as butterfly-shaped erythema over the cheeks and bridge of the nose sparing the nasolabial folds, and discoid lupus erythematous. Joint symptoms are prevalent, with patients frequently experiencing pain and swelling, particularly in the small joints of the hands. Hematological abnormalities in SLE include anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Lupus nephritis is considered a severe complication of SLE and patients present with, manifests as proteinuria and hematuria. It can progress to renal failure. Neurological symptoms are varied but can include seizures and cognitive disturbances. Additionally, SLE can cause serositis (i.e. pericarditis and pleuritis), oral ulcers, alopecia, and photosensitivity.

Option Analysis

✅ Discoid rash on the scalp:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Splinter hemorrhages under the fingernails:
Incorrect: Splinter hemorrhages appear as small red or brown lines under the nails caused by small blood clots that have traveled to the small vessels. They are indicative of endocarditis and not systemic lupus erythematosus.  
❌ Nodules over the extensor surfaces of the elbows:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous nodules on extensor surfaces are characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis, not systemic lupus erythematosus.  
❌ Well-defined, erythematous plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces of the elbows:
Incorrect: Erythematous plaques with silvery scale on extensor surfaces are a classic presentation of psoriasis and not systemic lupus erythematosus.  
❌ Tender, erythematous nodules on the shins:
Incorrect: Tender, erythematous nodules on the shins known as erythema nodosum are associated with inflammatory conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, infections, and sarcoidosis. This would be an uncommon presentation for systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the pulmonology clinic as a referral for persistent shortness of breath. Over the past year, the patient has developed worsening dyspnea with exertion and a persistent dry cough. He has no associated fevers, chills, or orthopnea. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. He has worked in a quarry for the past forty years. Vital signs are within normal limits. On lung auscultation there are fine inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function testing shows restrictive lung disease with reduced diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO). Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the chest shows nodular opacities in the upper lung zones with eggshell calcifications of hilar lymph nodes. A diagnostic bronchoscopy is scheduled. Which of the following histologic features is most likely to be found on bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with shortness of breath, dry cough, restrictive lung disease and reduced diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) on pulmonary function tests likely has silicosis. The most common types of pneumoconiosis include asbestosis, silicosis, coal worker pneumoconiosis, berylliosis, and hard metal pneumoconiosis. These can be distinguished by the findings on chest computed tomography (CT) and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), as well as by the type of environmental exposure. This patient’s work in a quarry (e.g. sandblasting) and CT imaging of the chest showing nodular opacities in the upper lung zones with eggshell calcifications of hilar lymph makes silicosis most likely. BAL in patients with silicosis will show silica-laden macrophages.    

Asbestosis is suggested by lower lung zone reticular opacities on chest CT and asbestosis bodies on BAL. Coal worker pneumoconiosis is suggested by upper lung zone nodular opacities with black-pigmented macrophages on BAL. Berylliosis is suggested by perilymphatic nodular opacities and lymphocyte predominance on BAL. Finally, hard metal pneumoconiosis is suggested by ground glass opacities and multinucleated giant cells on BAL.  

Option Analysis

✅ Silica-laden macrophages:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Asbestosis bodies:
Incorrect: These would be seen in asbestosis, which is most often seen in patients exposed to asbestos through work in construction or shipbuilding. CT imaging would show reticular opacities in the lower lung zones and pleural plaques. This patient who has worked in a quarry has upper lung zone nodular opacities and calcified hilar lymph nodes consistent with silicosis which would have silica-laden macrophages on BAL.
❌ Black-pigmented macrophages:
Incorrect: These would be seen in coal worker pneumoconiosis in patients who have worked in coal mines. CT imaging may be similar to that seen in silicosis (both can have upper lung zone nodular opacities) but eggshell calcifications in the hilar lymph nodes would not be seen in coal worker pneumoconiosis.
❌ Lymphocyte predominance:
Incorrect: This would be seen in berylliosis from working in aerospace engineering or computers. CT imaging would also show nodular opacities, but in berylliosis the opacities are generally seen in a perilymphatic distribution and are not associated with eggshell calcifications.
❌ Multinucleated giant cells:
Incorrect: These would be seen in hard metal pneumoconiosis from working in diamond polishing or drilling. CT imaging would show diffuse ground glass opacities which this patient does not have. This patient who has worked in a quarry has upper lung zone nodular opacities and calcified hilar lymph nodes consistent with silicosis which would have silica-laden macrophages on BAL.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by EMS for evaluation of altered mental status. His spouse reports that he has been confused for the last two days. He began experiencing abdominal pain and malaise two weeks ago after returning from a vacation in Mexico. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and blood pressure is 138/84 mmHg. On exams the patient is awake and alert but oriented only to the person. Scleral icterus is noted for jaundice of the skin. There is no papilledema. There is abdominal tenderness in the right upper quadrant. His hands display a flapping motion when he extends his arms and cocks his hands back at the wrists. Head CT is normal, and toxicology screen is negative. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value  
Result
AST
1,702 units/L  
ALT
2,112 units/L  
Total bilirubin  
14.3 mg/dL  
INR
2.2  
Anti-HAV IgM  
positive
Anti-HEV IgM  
positive
HSV PCR  
negative

choices.text: Transfer to a liver transplant center

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, abdominal pain, jaundice and asterixis. Additionally, multiple hepatic lab abnormalities and the presence of anti-HAV IgM and anti-HEV IgM, suggest fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy from acute coinfection with Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E viruses. There is no specific treatment for this viral coinfection and patients should be transferred to liver transplant centers while being given supportive care. This patient likely acquired the coinfection from contaminated food or water during his trip to Mexico.

Hepatitis A virus and Hepatitis E virus are common causes of acute viral hepatitis in resource-limited areas of the world. They typically lead to a self-limited or even asymptomatic illness that resolves spontaneously; however, either virus or coinfection with both can lead to fulminant hepatic failure. When toxin accumulation from liver failure leads to neuropsychiatric symptoms, it is referred to as hepatic encephalopathy. Symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy include cognitive changes, mood changes, asterixis, coordination or balance problems, muscle twitching and problems with executive functioning.  Laboratory results in severe disease typically include extreme elevations of liver transaminases (typically in the thousands), coagulopathy with an INR ≥ 1.5, and elevated bilirubin.

There is no specific treatment for Hepatitis A or Hepatitis E. Management of patients with hepatic failure from either virus or from coinfection with both consists of aggressive supportive care and coordination with a liver transplant team as quickly as possible. Even patients who do not meet criteria for transplant at the time of presentation should be transferred to a liver transplant center, as patients can deteriorate rapidly.

Option Analysis

✅ Transfer to a liver transplant center  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer mannitol:
Incorrect: Mannitol is used to manage increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which is a potential complication of acute liver failure. This patient does not have evidence of increased ICP and instead has hepatic encephalopathy and fulminant liver failure from Hepatitis A and E coinfection requiring transfer to a liver transplant center.  
❌ Administer N-acetylcysteine:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is used in the management of hepatic encephalopathy secondary to acetaminophen overdose. This patient does not report a history of acetaminophen ingestion. He has hepatic encephalopathy and fulminant liver failure from Hepatitis A and E coinfection, which requires transfer to a liver transplant center.  
❌ Administer acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is used in the management of hepatic failure caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV). This patient’s HSV PCR is negative. He has hepatic encephalopathy and fulminant liver failure from Hepatitis A and E coinfection, which requires transfer to a liver transplant center.  
❌ Chelation therapy:
Incorrect: Chelation therapy is used when acute liver failure is secondary to the accumulation of heavy metals such as with copper build up in Wilson disease. This patient’s liver failure is caused by acute coinfection with Hepatitis A and E and chelation would not help. He requires transfer to a liver transplant center.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow up. At her initial visit a week ago, routine labs were ordered which revealed an elevated alkaline phosphatase level, which was then confirmed with repeat testing. Review of systems is significant for mild pruritus. She has no family history of liver disease. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings are shown below. Right upper quadrant ultrasound shows a normal appearing gallbladder and biliary tract. Which of the following additional signs or symptoms would most likely be present given this patient’s likely underlying condition?  

Laboratory value   
Result
Complete Blood Count   

Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count  
5500/mm3   
Platelet Count  
200,000/mm3   
Serum Chemistry   

Sodium
142 mEq/L  
Potassium
4.2 mEq/L  
Chloride
95 mEq/L  
Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL  
Alanine aminotransferase  
20 U/L  
Aspartate aminotransferase  
21 U/L  
Serum albumin  
4 g/dL  
Serum total bilirubin  
0.8 mg/dL  
Total protein  
6 g/dL
Alkaline phosphatase level  
220 U/L
Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA)  
positive

choices.text: Epigastric pain radiating to the back

questions.solution:
This patient who presents with an elevated alkaline phosphatase level and mild pruritus likely has cholestasis. Given normal ultrasound, the biliary obstruction is likely to be intrahepatic, making primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) likely. Patients with PBC can be asymptomatic, or they may present with fatigue, pruritus, and right upper quadrant pain.

PBC is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small and medium intrahepatic bile ducts. Autoimmune destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts leads to cholestasis. PBC is more prevalent in women, with a female-to-male ratio of 9:1. While it is often asymptomatic, patients can present with fatigue and pruritus. Fatigue is one of the most common early symptoms of the disease. As the disease progresses, patients may experience pruritus, which is due to the accumulation of bile salts in the skin. Studies have recently shown that the fatigue seems to stem from muscle mitochondrial dysfunction, due to the autoimmune destruction of mitochondria that characterizes the condition.

Physical examination findings in the early stages of PBC may be unremarkable, but as the disease progresses, signs of chronic liver disease, such as jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes) and hepatomegaly may be seen. In later stages, patients can have signs of liver cirrhosis like ascites and spider angiomata (small, spider-like blood vessels on the skin).

Typically, alkaline phosphatase levels are elevated in PBC. If they exceed 1.5 times the upper limit of normal, a positive antimitochondrial antibody (AMA) test result can establish the diagnosis without the need for a liver biopsy. The primary treatment for PBC is ursodeoxycholic acid, which is associated with histologic improvement, increased survival rates, and reduced reliance on liver transplantation.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Fatigue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cold intolerance:
Incorrect: Cold intolerance is typically associated with hypothyroidism. While liver diseases can affect overall metabolism, cold intolerance is not a symptom of PBC.  
❌ Edema:
Incorrect: Edema may be a sign of late stage liver disease and cirrhosis in PBC; however, this patient has only mild symptoms and lab work shows no evidence of significant liver damage, therefore she most likely has early-stage disease.  
❌ Epigastric pain radiating to the back:
Incorrect: This type of pain is more indicative of gastrointestinal conditions like pancreatitis or peptic ulcer disease. PBC primarily affects the liver and does not typically cause this specific pattern of abdominal pain, although some patients may experience intermittent right upper quadrant abdominal pain.  
❌ Exertional chest pain:
Incorrect: Exertional chest pain is commonly associated with cardiac conditions, such as angina pectoris, resulting from reduced blood flow to the myocardium. It is not a symptom typically associated with PBC, which primarily involves the liver and biliary tract.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for tuberculosis screening before starting a new job as a part-time nurse at a prison. He currently has a right sided headache with photophobia, a cough that he says is no different from his chronic cough, and low back pain. Past medical history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, coronary artery disease, and migraines. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, fluticasone-salmeterol, sumatriptan and verapamil. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 86/min, blood pressure is 128/83 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has a dry cough. He is alert and oriented and there are no focal neurological deficits. There is no nuchal rigidity. Cardiac auscultation is within normal limits. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation. There is tenderness to palpation along the lumbar paravertebral musculature but none along the spinous processes. A serum interferon gamma release assay is positive. Chest radiograph is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who is starting a job as a health care worker in a prison was scheduled to have screening for tuberculosis given that his occupation puts him at high risk for tuberculosis (TB) exposure. The interferon-gamma release assay is positive, but he has no new pulmonary or other symptoms of tuberculosis infection, and his chest x-ray is normal; therefore, he has tuberculosis infection or latent TB.

Tuberculosis is an infection due to the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It frequently results in pulmonary disease (pulmonary tuberculosis) but can cause an asymptomatic state called latent tuberculosis. It can also cause systemic infection that can lead to extrapulmonary tuberculosis.

Screening for tuberculosis infection should be performed in certain populations who are at high risk of developing tuberculosis and therefore would benefit from treatment. This includes patients who are at risk of developing a new infection (close contact with people with untreated TB and healthcare workers who may have occupational exposures). Patients at high risk of reactivation or TB disease progression, like patients with underlying immunosuppression and patients at moderate or slightly increased risk of reactivation who live in areas where TB is prevalent, should also be screened. For patients at risk,  interferon-gamma release assay or tuberculin skin test should be performed to confirm the presence of tuberculosis. Chest radiography should be performed if either test is positive, in order to differentiate between pulmonary tuberculosis and latent tuberculosis. Patients with latent tuberculosis generally do not have any significant physical exam or chest x-ray findings.  

Option Analysis

✅ Latent tuberculosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pulmonary tuberculosis:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest radiograph shows no evidence of active pulmonary tuberculosis, and he has no new pulmonary symptoms. He has a chronic cough secondary to COPD.  
❌ Spinal tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Spinal tuberculosis may present with back pain, spasms, tenderness to palpation along the spinous processes, and possibly neurologic deficits. This patient may have back pain and spasms, but there is no tenderness and no neurologic deficits.  
❌ Tuberculous pericarditis:
Incorrect: Patients with tuberculous pericarditis may present with sharp chest pain, shortness of breath, signs such as jugular venous distention, and a pericardial friction rub. This patient does not have these symptoms, and he has no cardiac abnormalities on exam.  
❌ Tuberculous meningitis:
Incorrect: Patients with tuberculous meningitis may present with headache and photophobia. However, they will generally have nuchal rigidity and neurologic deficits which this patient does not have. He is likely experiencing a migraine headache.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic with a one-week history of asymmetric joint pain that is most severe in the left knee and ankle as well as painful urination. He has no history of illness. He is sexually active with female partners and reports having unprotected intercourse recently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a warm, tender, swollen left knee and tenderness of the left ankle. Additionally, there is non-purulent conjunctivitis, white urethral discharge, and a rash on the palms and soles as seen in the image below. Laboratory studies are remarkable for an elevated ESR. An effusion is seen on X-ray of the knee. Rheumatoid factor is ordered, a genital swab is sent for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), and arthrocentesis of the left knee is performed. Which of the following test results is most likely?


Image courtesy of Wikimedia

choices.text: Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  10,000 cells/microL  Synovial culture  Negative
Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Gram positive cocci
Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Positive  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of asymmetric joint pain, dysuria, and unprotected intercourse. Coupled with the joint exam findings, conjunctivitis, and skin findings that are consistent with keratoderma blennorrhagicum, reactive arthritis is the most likely diagnosis. Laboratory studies would most likely demonstrate a negative rheumatoid factor, synovial fluid consistent with an inflammatory arthritis with a negative Gram stain, and nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) that is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis.    

In reactive arthritis, basic blood work may reveal a mild leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g. ESR, CRP). Radiographs of affected joints are generally nonspecific and are most often used to rule out other conditions (e.g. fracture, ankylosing spondylitis) but may demonstrate an effusion, periostitis, or calcaneal enthesitis and spurring. Additional studies may demonstrate a negative ANA and rheumatoid factor as well as HLA-B27 positivity in some individuals, which is a predisposing factor for reactive arthritis.  

For patients with joint effusions, arthrocentesis should be performed to rule out septic arthritis (e.g. gonococcal arthritis). In reactive arthritis, synovial studies are consistent with an inflammatory process (WBC count between 2,000–20,000 cells/microL), and Gram stain and culture are negative. As part of the workup, evaluating for a previous or current enteric or genitourinary infection can be helpful, though negative studies do not rule out the diagnosis of reactive arthritis. This evaluation may include a genital swab or stool cultures, based on the presenting signs and symptoms.  

Option Analysis

✅  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  10,000 cells/microL  Synovial culture  Negative:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Positive  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  15,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory studies is most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. However, the patient’s presentation of asymmetric arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is more consistent with reactive arthritis.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Gram positive cocci :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory studies is more consistent with septic arthritis. However, the patient’s presentation of asymmetric arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is more consistent with reactive arthritis.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  1,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings would be more consistent with a noninflammatory joint condition, such as osteoarthritis. However, the patient’s presentation of asymmetric arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is more consistent with reactive arthritis.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Positive  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative :
Incorrect: While the positive NAAT would be consistent with reactive arthritis from urethritis, which is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, the positive rheumatoid factor and significantly elevated synovial WBC count are not consistent with reactive arthritis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-week history of asymmetric joint pain, particularly in her right knee and left ankle and foot. She had a recent episode of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, which resolved on its own. She has no significant past medical history or family history of autoimmune disorders. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. On examination, the right knee is swollen and warm. Laboratory tests are listed below. STI screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for managing this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory study  Result 
 ESR  72 mm/hr 
 CRP  3.97 mg/dL 
 ANA  Negative 
 Rheumatoid factor  Negative 
 HLA-B27  Positive 
 Synovial WBC count  10,000 cells/microL 
 Synovial Gram stain and culture  Negative
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing asymmetric oligoarthritis associated with a recent GI infection. This is most indicative of reactive arthritis, and the best next step in management is the use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as naproxen.  

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy. Patients present with joint inflammation after an enteric or genitourinary tract infection. Common causative organisms include Chlamydia trachomatis, Salmonella spp., and Shigella spp. Most associated gastrointestinal infections are self-limited and do not require treatment. However, if Chlamydia or Neisseria gonorrhoeae are identified on testing, appropriate antibiotic therapy should be initiated.    

NSAIDs are first-line therapy for managing the symptoms and inflammation of reactive arthritis. Patients often need two to four weeks of therapy. If symptoms do not respond, corticosteroids (either systemic or intra-articular) may be used. In cases that persist for ≥ 6 months, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) should be considered, including methotrexate and sulfasalazine. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors are used in rare cases that are resistant to all other therapies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Oral naproxen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral prednisone:
Incorrect: Systemic corticosteroids are not the first-line treatment for reactive arthritis. Oral prednisone would be appropriate if symptoms persist despite NSAID therapy.
❌ Intra-articular triamcinolone:
Incorrect: Intra-articular corticosteroids are not the first-line treatment for reactive arthritis. Intra-articular corticosteroids would be appropriate if symptoms persist despite NSAID therapy.
❌ Oral doxycycline:
Incorrect: Oral doxycycline is used to treat Chlamydia trachomatis infections in patients with reactive arthritis. However, this patient’s testing does not indicate a current Chlamydia infection.
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is not a first-line treatment for reactive arthritis. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs are reserved for cases that persist for ≥ 6 months.

questions.text: A 28-year-old biologically male patient presents to the urgent care clinic for sexually transmitted infection testing. His partner tested positive for Chlamydia trachomatis yesterday, and they have recently had unprotected vaginal intercourse. He does not have current symptoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Chaperoned examination of the genital region is within normal limits. The patient is offered empiric treatment but declines, electing to wait until the test results are back. Which of the following symptoms is the patient most likely to exhibit if he has contracted his partner’s infection?
questions.solution:
The majority of patients who develop chlamydia infections are asymptomatic and have no signs or symptoms of infection. This patient with a known sexual exposure to Chlamydia trachomatis should be tested and encouraged to take empiric treatment, since symptoms are not likely to develop despite active infection and loss to follow up may occur. All sexual partners of people who have tested positive for Chlamydia should be tested and treated after a known exposure, regardless of symptom status.  

Chlamydia trachomatis is acquired through sexual contact with an infected person, and it is the most common bacterial sexually transmitted infection. The infection can also be passed from mother to infant during childbirth. Sexually active young people are at the highest risk of contracting chlamydia, as are men who have sex with men.   

When present, genitourinary symptoms of chlamydia in a biologically male patient can include urethral discharge, dysuria, pyuria, prostate swelling and pain, or testicular swelling and pain, depending on whether the infection is in the urethra, prostate, or testicle. In biologically female patients, chlamydia may lead to urethritis or cervicitis, causing dysuria, pyuria, vaginal discharge, and post-coital or non-menstrual vaginal bleeding. Both men and women may experience lower abdominal pain, and women may develop pelvic inflammatory disease. Lymphogranuloma venereum is an uncommon but invasive genital ulcer disease caused by chlamydia infection that can lead to lymphadenopathy and proctocolitis. Chlamydia may also infect non-genitourinary sites and can lead to conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and proctitis.  Pneumonia can occur in infected neonates.

Option Analysis

✅ No symptoms:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Testicular pain:
Incorrect: Chlamydia trachomatis can cause infection of the epididymis or testicles and can lead to testicular pain and swelling; however, this is rare.  The majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic. 
❌ Lower abdominal tenderness:
Incorrect: Chlamydia infections can lead to lower abdominal tenderness in both men and women; however, the majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic. 
❌ Prostate tenderness:
Incorrect: When Chlamydia trachomatis infects the prostate it can lead to prostatitis, presenting as a firm, tender, and edematous prostate; however, the majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic.
❌ Urethral discharge:
Incorrect: Urethritis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis may present with urethral discharge, dysuria, or pyuria; however, the majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a syncopal episode at work. The patient works in a warehouse. According to his co-worker, the patient was moving heavy boxes when he suddenly collapsed and fell to the floor, after which he regained consciousness within 20 seconds. The patient was alert and oriented immediately after regaining consciousness. He had no chest pain or palpitations prior to the episode. Over the past year, the patient has had transient episodes of lightheadedness related to exercise. He has a remote history of syncope during a wrestling match in high school that was believed to be caused by orthostatic hypotension. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mmHg while supine and 124/70 mmHg while standing. On examination, the patient has no murmurs and lungs are clear to auscultation. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with left-axis deviation and inverted T waves in V<sub>2</sub>-V<sub>4</sub>. Complete blood count, serum electrolytes, and cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation, including his young age, syncope during exertion, and ECG findings of ventricular hypertrophy (left-axis deviation, inverted T waves in V2-V4), raises concern for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).

HCM is characterized by asymmetric left ventricular hypertrophy and can lead to outflow obstruction, arrhythmias, ischemia, and death. Syncope in individuals with HCM can occur due to several mechanisms.

1. Obstruction of left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT). Thickening of the heart muscle around the left ventricle can obstruct the outflow of blood from the left ventricle, especially during exercise or exertion, leading to a sudden drop in blood pressure and syncope.

2. Arrhythmias associated with HCM, including atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia can lead to a rapid decrease in cardiac output and cause syncope.

3. Ischemia: The thickened heart muscle in HCM may require more oxygen, and narrowed coronary arteries, which are often found in HCM patients, can limit oxygen supply to the heart muscle. During increased physical activity, the heart muscles may become ischemic, leading to symptoms like chest pain and syncope.

The physical examination can be normal in HCM, as it is in this patient, or it may reveal a nonspecific fourth heart sound, a systolic murmur, or an LV lift. Patients with left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction might have a sharp, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur. This murmur usually starts just after the first heart sound (S1) and is most audible at the apex and lower left sternal edge. Various physical examination techniques can alter the level of obstruction, leading to a variation in the loudness of the murmur. Diagnosis is made with echocardiography, which typically demonstrates asymmetric LV hypertrophy primarily affecting the interventricular septum, dynamic LVOT obstruction, LV diastolic dysfunction, and left atrial dilation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ambulatory ECG monitoring:
Incorrect: Ambulatory ECG monitoring is helpful for diagnosing intermittent arrhythmias and could detect paroxysmal atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia which can lead to syncope. However, this patient’s presentation, history, and ECG findings suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy which should be assessed further with an echocardiogram.
❌ Pacemaker placement:
Incorrect: Pacemaker placement is indicated in cases of significant bradyarrhythmias or heart block, where the heart’s natural pacemaker is unable to maintain an adequate heart rate. This patient’s heart rate and EKG pattern are more suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and there is no evidence of bradyarrhythmia or heart block.  
❌ Coronary angiography:
Incorrect: Coronary angiography is used to evaluate for coronary artery disease, particularly in patients presenting with chest pain or ischemic changes on ECG. This patient's age, lack of chest pain, and ECG findings are more consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  
✅ Echocardiography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral rehydration and reassurance:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration and reassurance may be appropriate for syncope due to orthostatic hypotension from dehydration or vasovagal episodes, but this patient's recurrent exercise-related symptoms and specific ECG findings point towards hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which should be assessed further with an echocardiogram.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician due to fatigue and low energy for the past two months. The patient tells the physician she can barely perform her daily activities and her work performance has declined. In addition, the patient reports that when she goes to the bathroom early in the morning, her urine is red in color. Last year she was diagnosed with Budd-Chiari syndrome and was prescribed anticoagulants. The patient’s labs show pancytopenia. Early morning urinalysis is positive for blood, but microscopy reveals no blood. Flow cytometry was performed and it showed decreased CD55 and CD59. The physician decides to start the patient on eculizumab. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: It binds to and blocks the activation of C5 complement protein
It binds soluble tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and prevents the activation of its receptor
It Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor
It binds to integrins in blood vessel walls and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation.

questions.solution:
This patient has anemia, venous thrombosis (e.g. Budd-Chiari syndrome), and pancytopenia. In addition, flow cytometry reveals decreased expression of CD55 and CD59, indicating paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is a rare hematopoietic stem cell disorder that manifests with hemolytic anemia, bone marrow failure, and thrombosis. Hemolysis in PNH is directly mediated by the complement system and is due to a mutation in the PIGA gene that results in the absence of GPI anchor expression erythrocytes. Deficiency of GPI on erythrocytes results in the inability of complement inhibitors CD55 and CD59 to function properly. Since CD55 and CD59 protect RBCs from complement damage, their absence results in excessive hemolysis of RBCs by the complement system.

Eculizumab is the first-line treatment for PNH. It is a human monoclonal antibody that binds to and blocks the activation of C5, thereby inhibiting the formation of membrane attack complexes (MAC). By doing so, eculizumab compensates for the absence of complement inhibitors (e.g. CD59) on the erythrocytes and therefore protects them from intravascular hemolysis by MAC.

The use of eculizumab in patients with PNH has been shown to improve anemia, inhibit intravascular hemolysis and decrease the need for transfusions; reduce the risk of venous thrombosis, and improve overall quality of life.  

Option Analysis

✅ It binds to and blocks the activation of C5 complement protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It binds soluble tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and prevents the activation of its receptor:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF and is used in inflammatory disorders like rheumatoid arthritis. It has no role in the management of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.  
❌ It Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor:
Incorrect: IL-17A inhibitors are medications that can be used in the management of severe psoriasis.  
❌ It binds to integrins in blood vessel walls and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation.:
Incorrect: Natalizumab binds to integrins on the endothelial cells of blood vessels, thereby inhibiting leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation. It is a drug used to treat Multiple Sclerosis.  
❌ It inhibits interleukin 12/23:
Incorrect: Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits interleukin-12/23. It can be used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to her physician for joint pain. The patient was diagnosed with psoriasis two years ago and was started on methotrexate. However, her skin lesions have not improved. Currently, the patient is having pain in the joints of both hands and fingers. Physical examination reveals inflammation of the distal interphalangeal joints, in addition to signs of joint destruction. The physician discusses a new medication with the patient called secukinumab. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor
Inhibits the interaction of Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) with its receptors
Inhibits C5 complement protein and the activation of membrane attack complexes
It binds integrins of the blood vessel wall and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing joint pain as a result of psoriatic arthritis. The physician decided to start the patient on secukinumab, which is an interleukin-17A (IL-17A) inhibitor.

IL-17A inhibitors belong to a new class of medication, which are monoclonal antibodies that prevent the interaction of IL-17A with its receptors. Examples include secukinumab, brodalumab, and ixekizumab.  These medications were introduced after the discovery of the role of Th-17 cells in the pathogenesis of many inflammatory disorders. Th-17 produces IL-17, which is a proinflammatory cytokine that once produced, stimulates the recruitment of neutrophils and other inflammatory cells and induces sustained chronic inflammation. IL-17A has been implicated in the pathogenesis of many immune-mediated disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, crohn’s disease, and multiple sclerosis.

IL-17A inhibitors are currently under investigation and their uses are promising. One of the indications of Il-17A inhibitors is moderate to severe psoriasis, with or without arthritis. Additionally, there are studies underway to determine their efficacy in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disorder.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits the interaction of Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) with its receptors:
Incorrect: Anti-TNF monoclonal antibodies can be used in the treatment of psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. Examples include adalimumab and infliximab. However, secukinumab is an IL-17A inhibitor.  
❌ Inhibits C5 complement protein and the activation of membrane attack complexes:
Incorrect: Eculizumab binds to and inhibits C5, thereby inhibiting the activation of membrane attack complexes.  
❌ Inhibits interleukin-12/23:
Incorrect: Ustekinumab inhibits interleukin-12/13  
❌ It binds integrins of the blood vessel wall and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation:
Incorrect: Natalizumab binds integrins on the endothelial cells of the blood vessels and thereby inhibits the use of integrins by leukocytes to cross to the inflammation site.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. The patient was insufflating a white powder earlier in the evening, and his symptoms developed shortly after that. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 201/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals diaphoresis and mydriasis. Which of the following medications is contraindicated, given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain and significant vital sign derangements, which are suggestive of hypertensive emergency in the setting of alleged cocaine use. ꞵ-blockers like labetalol are contraindicated in managing these patients due to the risk of unopposed α-stimulation.

Indirect sympathomimetics like cocaine work by indirectly increasing the concentration of endogenous catecholamines within the synaptic cleft. In the case of cocaine, the concentration of neurotransmitters, including dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, and serotonin, are elevated. Peripherally, these catecholamines can stimulate postsynaptic α1- and α2-adrenoceptors, resulting in smooth muscle contraction and vasoconstriction. When this occurs in the coronary vasculature, patients often present with symptoms reminiscent of an acute coronary syndrome.

When a β-blocker is administered, the β2-vasodilator influence opposing α-adrenoceptor-mediated vasoconstriction is removed, potentially worsening blood pressure and its subsequent effects on the coronary vasculature.  

Option Analysis

✅ Labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: GABA-agonists such as lorazepam, midazolam, and diazepam are indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies induced by cocaine use.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin has been shown to have beneficial effects in managing acute coronary syndrome and should be administered to patients with an underlying suspicion of this condition. It is not contraindicated for patients with chest pain secondary to cocaine use.  
❌ Midazolam:
Incorrect: GABA-agonists such as lorazepam, midazolam, and diazepam are indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies induced by cocaine use.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is a potent direct-acting vasodilator. It is not the first-line medication to manage hypertensive emergencies secondary to amphetamine use. However, the medication is also not contraindicated.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of nausea and vomiting after swallowing several packets of acetaminophen tablets. The patient swallowed the pills 5 hours ago. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder which is being treated with fluoxetine. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows minimal epigastric tenderness. Serum acetaminophen levels are elevated, and the appropriate therapeutic medication is initiated. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this therapy?

choices.text: Increased conversion of NH3 to ammonium NH4+ in the colon
Induction of vomiting and purging of acetaminophen
Reduction in the absorption of ingested acetaminophen

questions.solution:
Acetaminophen poisoning is the most common cause of acute liver failure in the United States. The recommended maximum daily dose for healthy adults is 3 grams, with higher doses leading to increased risk of toxicity. N-acetylcysteine is the antidote if treatment is sought within 8 hours of ingestion. If a patient presents within 4 hours of ingestion, gastric decontaminating agents, such as oral activated charcoal, is indicated to decrease absorption from the stomach and small intestine.

Normally, the small amounts of toxic NAPQI produced via microsomal metabolism (CYP-450 enzymes) after therapeutic doses of acetaminophen are detoxified by binding to glutathione. NAPQI depletes glutathione, and once glutathione is depleted to approximately one-third of normal levels, NAPQI binds crucial cellular proteins. This results in hepatic cell death, necrosis, and subsequent fulminant liver failure. The amino acid, cysteine, is the main factor limiting the synthesis of glutathione. N-acetylcysteine is a cysteine precursor that is hydrolysed intracellularly to cysteine, thereby replenishing intracellular glutathione.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Increased conversion of NH3 to ammonium NH4+ in the colon:
Incorrect: Gastric lavage, commonly referred to as 'stomach pumping', is a technique in which stomach contents are removed by repeated administration and aspiration of fluid through an orogastric. It is no longer in routine and it has been replaced in most circumstances by the use of activated charcoal.  
❌ Induction of vomiting and purging of acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Ipecac syrup is a cough syrup that used to be widely administered to induce vomiting. It is no longer recommended in the management of acute toxin ingestion.  
❌ Inhibition of enzyme cytochrome P-450:
Incorrect: Cimetidine, a CYP-450 inhibitor, inhibits the breakdown of acetaminophen into the toxic metabolite NAPQI. Although treatment was useful in animal models, it had minimal effects in a clinical trial where patients were treated with N-acetylcysteine.  
❌ Reduction in the absorption of ingested acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal reduces the absorption of acetaminophen if given within four hours of ingestion. This patient is presenting 5 hours after overdosing, which makes another therapeutic option more beneficial.  
✅ Replenishment of intracellular amino acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the physician for a follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic primary hypogonadism one year ago after experiencing erectile dysfunction and decreased energy. He was then started on androgen replacement using intramuscular testosterone cypionate. Currently, he is feeling better, with improvement in his energy levels and sexual function. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is expected to be seen in this patient due to his treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient is being treated for hypogonadism using testosterone cypionate, a testosterone derivative used in androgen replacement therapy. It can cause an elevation in hematocrit as a side effect.

Testosterone derivatives are a group of androgenic hormones that have the structure of testosterone. Testosterone cypionate is one of these derivatives used intramuscularly, while fluoxymesterone and methyltestosterone are oral ones. Testosterone derivatives are usually used in androgen replacement therapy in patients with primary or secondary hypogonadism. It can also stimulate anabolism in patients with severe catabolic states (e.g. burn patients).

Side effects of testosterone derivatives are common. First, these drugs stimulate erythropoiesis, leading to increased erythrocyte production and hematocrit. Furthermore, they can increase the growth of the prostate gland as testosterone will be converted to dihydrotestosterone, which directly stimulates the growth of the prostate gland. Because of this effect, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can increase in patients taking testosterone derivatives, and sometimes there is a slightly increased risk of prostate cancer. Other side effects include increased LDL and decreased HDL, gynecomastia, gonadal atrophy, and infertility.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated hematocrit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated follicle stimulating hormone:
Incorrect: This patient is expected to have a decreased follicle stimulating hormone after starting testosterone treatment because it causes feedback inhibition of the gonadotrophs in the pituitary gland, leading to suppression of FSH release.  
❌ Elevated high-density lipoprotein (HDL):
Incorrect: Patients taking testosterone are expected to have an increased LDL and decreased HDL.  
❌ Decreased prostate gland size:
Incorrect: Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha reductase enzyme. DHT then stimulates the growth of the prostate gland. Therefore, patients on testosterone replacement therapy usually have an increase in the size of the prostate gland.  
❌ Galactorrhea:
Incorrect:  Although testosterone hormone supplementation can lead to gynecomastia due to peripheral aromatization to estrogens, it is not associated with galactorrhea.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate nocturia and difficulty urinating. The patient has had these symptoms for a year, and it has been worsening. Currently, the patient wakes up three times a night to urinate. In addition, the patient noticed that it takes longer than usual for him to start urinating. Digital rectal examination reveals symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodularity. Urinalysis is within normal limits, and urinary culture is negative. The physician decided to start the patient on tamsulosin and finasteride. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of finasteride?

choices.text: Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone
Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland
Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra
Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum

questions.solution:
This patient with urinary flow obstruction (urinary hesitancy and straining) and irritative symptoms (frequency and nocturia) most likely have benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It is a common disease in the elderly that occurs due to overgrowth of the prostate gland, leading to obstruction of the prostatic urethra and urinary symptoms. Finasteride is sometimes used in the treatment of BPH.

Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is an androgen that stimulates the growth of the prostate gland and is also associated with male pattern hair loss (i.e. androgenetic alopecia). Finasteride inhibits the conversion of testosterone to DHT by blocking the action of enzyme 5-alpha reductase, leading to decreased growth and, ultimately, shrinkage of the prostate gland, thereby reducing the blockage on the urethra. However, these effects usually take months to develop; therefore, finasteride's effects will only be seen after continuous use for a long period. Finasteride can also be used in the treatment of androgenetic alopecia.

Side effects of finasteride are common and include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and gynecomastia. In addition, some patients may also experience orthostatic hypotension. Finally, patients taking finasteride at high doses may develop infertility, which in severe cases, may be irreversible.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland:
Incorrect: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist usually used in metastatic prostate cancer. It is not frequently used in benign prostatic hyperplasia because of its feminization effects. Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor.  
❌ Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra:
Incorrect: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonists (e.g. tamsulosin) are the first-line treatment of BPH, and they work via relaxing the smooth muscles in the prostatic urethra and prostate glands, thereby resolving the urinary blockage. However, finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, not an alpha-1 receptor antagonist.  
❌ Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum:
Incorrect: Certain medications inhibit testosterone synthesis (e.g. ketoconazole). However, finasteride does not inhibit testosterone synthesis and sometimes increased testosterone levels can be seen in patients taking finasteride.  
❌ Inhibits the synthesis of gonadotropins:
Incorrect: Use of Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (e.g. Leuprolide) can lead to suppression of production of gonadotropins, leading to decreased testosterone production. However, finasteride does not inhibit the synthesis of gonadotropins.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician to evaluate palpitations, excessive sweating, and increased anxiety. The symptoms began four months ago. She consumes two cups of coffee per day. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she uses an albuterol inhaler. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg. Physical exam is notable for diffusely enlarged, symmetrical, and non-tender thyroid. The remainder of the head and neck exam is non-contributory. TSH receptor antibody levels are elevated. The patient is started on a medication that reduces the peripheral conversion of T<sub>4</sub> to T<sub>3</sub> and inhibits thyroid peroxidase function. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?

choices.text: Diffuse skin blistering and epidermal detachment

questions.solution:
This patient has Graves disease and was started on a thionamide. Thionamides (e.g., methimazole, propylthiouracil) work by preventing thyroid hormone synthesis via inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. In addition, propylthiouracil (PTU) prevents the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 via inhibition of 5’-deiodinase.

Side effects include pruritic skin rash, vasculitis, hypothyroidism, lupus-like syndrome, agranulocytosis, and hypoprothrombinemia. Thionamides are also associated with hepatotoxicity, which is more common with PTU use. These side effects are reversible, meaning they resolve once the medications are discontinued.

It is important to note that methimazole and PTU are used in pregnancy even though they can cross the placenta. During the first trimester, when organogenesis is taking place, and the fetus is susceptible to drug-induced damage, PTU is preferred. The rationale is that PTU is less likely to cross the placenta due to its extensive plasma protein binding. On the other hand, methimazole is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is associated with aplasia cutis, a condition characterized by the absence of portions of skin. During the second and third trimesters, once organogenesis is complete, methimazole is preferred due to its lower risk of hepatotoxicity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Resting heart rate of 52/min:
Incorrect: Bradycardia, defined as a heart rate less than 60/min, is a side effect of beta blockers. Beta-blockers can be used to manage hyperthyroidism by inhibiting sympathetic activation of the beta-adrenergic receptors. Beta-blockers can also inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 at high doses. However, this medication class does not affect thyroid peroxidase function.  
❌ Subjective sensation of dry mouth:
Incorrect: Xerostomia, a sensation of oral dryness, is a side effect of radioactive iodine therapy. This occurs since the radioactive iodine can also be uptaken by the salivary glands, resulting in their damage. However, radioactive iodine does not directly inhibit thyroid peroxidase function or peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.  
❌ Random plasma glucose of 250 mg/dL:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids can cause insulin resistance and lead to glucocorticoid-induced diabetes mellitus. The medication suppresses immune system function and prevents the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, corticosteroids do not affect thyroid peroxidase function.  
✅ Aspartate aminotransferase level of 180 U/L:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse skin blistering and epidermal detachment  :
Incorrect: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS) are immune-mediated skin conditions that result in blistering and epidermal detachment. TEN (affecting > 30% of skin) can be thought of as a severe form of SJS (affecting ≤ 30% of skin). It would be atypical for a propylthiouracil, which functions via the mechanisms of action described in the question stem, to cause SJS or TEN.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of back pain that began 12 hours ago. The patient was picking up a bag of groceries when her symptoms started. She was recently diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her medications include abemaciclib and anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 155/78 mmHg. Physical exam reveals focal tenderness over the lumbar spine. The pain is exacerbated with flexion and extension of the spine. No neurologic deficits are noted in the lower extremities. Imaging is ordered and shown below. Her most recent lab results showed a leukocyte count of 3,600/mm3. Administration of which medications would have most likely prevented this patient’s condition?
 
Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has an L1 spinal compression fracture in the setting of anastrozole use. Anastrozole is a type II aromatase inhibitor (AI) that prevents the conversion of androgens to estrogen. It is used to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

Since estrogen helps sustain bone density, patients on AIs are deprived of its protective effects. This can increase their risk of developing osteopenia, osteoporosis, and arthralgias. Osteopenia/osteoporosis predisposes patients to develop fractures. Bisphosphonates, which reduce bone reuptake by interfering with osteoclast activity, should be administered together with AIs in patients with osteopenia/osteoporosis to prevent such events.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: Vancomycin can be used to prevent or treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria. Vertebral osteomyelitis can cause focal tenderness over the spine. However, this patient’s MRI shows loss of height in the L1 vertebra, which is more consistent with a compression fracture.  
❌ Piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad-spectrum antibiotic with gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic coverage. However, piperacillin-tazobactam would not be useful in preventing a vertebral compression fracture.
✅ Alendronate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raloxifene:
Incorrect: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It is an estrogen antagonist in the breast and endometrium but an estrogen agonist in the bones. Raloxifene can be used for breast cancer and osteoporosis prevention. Its efficacy in providing osteoporosis prophylaxis for patients taking aromatase inhibitors is not well documented.  
❌ Denosumab:
Incorrect: Denosumab can reduce the risk of osteoporosis and spinal compression fractures. However, bisphosphonates (e.g. alendronate) are the first-line option for preventing osteoporosis and fractures in patients taking an aromatase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of shortness of breath. The patient reports exertional shortness of breath for the past 2 days to the extent that he is now unable to perform his daily activities. He does not have chest pain but reports noticing whitish sputum with cough. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Family history is unremarkable. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history. BMI is 32 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a markedly increased anterio-posterior chest diameter. Breath sounds are decreased with scattered wheezes bilaterally. Addition of which of the following to the patient’s medication regime will most likely improve his current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The mainstays of treatment are bronchodilators, especially antimuscarinic agents (e.g., ipratropium).

Antimuscarinics for COPD are usually given via inhalers where they enter the lungs and bind to M3 muscarinic receptors on the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles. This blocks acetylcholine from binding to the receptors, leading to less smooth muscle constriction. Ipratropium and tiotropium are the most commonly used muscarinic antagonists for asthma and COPD. They are sometimes given with long-acting β-adrenergic agonists (LABAs) for severe symptoms as the combination produces an additive effect, leading to stronger and longer-lasting bronchodilation.

Side effects include tachycardia, dry mouth, restlessness, pupil dilation, and urinary retention. They are contraindicated in individuals with narrow-angle glaucoma as they relax the ciliary muscles, which worsen the obstruction of aqueous humor drainage.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ipratropium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic agonist mainly used in the management of nasal congestion. This patient’s productive cough is most likely due to COPD.  
❌ Bromocriptine:
Incorrect: Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist and can be used in the management of prolactinomas, Parkinson’s disease or restless leg syndrome. It is not indicated in patients with COPD.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a beta-adrenergic blocker which may exacerbate pulmonary symptoms in patients with COPD via bronchoconstriction and therefore should be avoided.
❌ Clonidine:
Incorrect: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the management of hypertension. It is not indicated in patients with COPD.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman is brought by ambulance to the emergency department for evaluation of dizziness and heavy menstrual bleeding. The patient's menstrual period began the night before, and she has soaked 8 pads since then. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable, and she does not have abdominal pain or cramping. Menarche was at age 13, and she typically has regular menstrual periods lasting 4 days with mild bleeding. She takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows petechiae on the lower extremities and small, scattered ecchymoses. Pelvic examination reveals fresh blood in the vaginal canal. Urine pregnancy test is negative, and pelvic ultrasound does not show any abnormalities. Laboratory studies are shown below. Coagulation studies are within normal limits. Peripheral smear shows numerous giant platelets. HIV and hepatitis C testing is pending. After initial stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation, which of the following is the most appropriate management?

 Laboratory Test  Result 
 Hemoglobin  8.1 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  5,500/μL 
 Platelet count  12,000/μL 
 Creatinine  0.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with active heavy menstrual bleeding, tachycardia and borderline low blood pressure is at risk of impending hemorrhagic shock. Physical examination shows petechiae and ecchymosis. Laboratory findings show severe thrombocytopenia without leukopenia and anemia that can be explained by bleeding. At this time, she can be presumptively diagnosed with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) and treated with intravenous glucocorticoids.    

ITP is an autoimmune condition characterized by a dysregulated immune system that produces autoantibodies against platelets. Acute management of hemodynamically unstable patients with a presumptive diagnosis of ITP involves ABCDE assessment for stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. Intravenous glucocorticoids should be administered to inhibit the production of anti-platelet autoantibodies. Intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG), which bind and inactivate antibodies already present in the circulation, are typically also given.
