On physical examination, the patient appears pale. Oral examination shows glossitis. There is decreased sensation to light touch and vibration in the bilateral lower extremities and diminished reflexes in the bilateral lower extremities. Cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable. Epigastric tenderness to palpation is present. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     9.0 g/dL   
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)     112 fL   
 Vitamin B12     145 pg/mL
questions.solution:
The patient who presents with chronic epigastric pain, a history of autoimmune disease (Hashimoto thyroiditis), progressive fatigue, and neurologic findings (e.g., tingling in the lower extremities, decreased sensation, diminished reflexes) most likely has autoimmune gastritis. Laboratory findings of macrocytic anemia and low vitamin B12 levels support the diagnosis of autoimmune gastritis.        

Autoimmune gastritis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by the immune system-mediated destruction of parietal cells of the stomach. This results in a deficiency of intrinsic factors and decreased production of hydrochloric acid, subsequently causing malabsorption of vitamin B12 and macrocytic anemia. Positive anti-parietal cell and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are hallmark diagnostic markers of autoimmune gastritis.        

When evaluating a patient with gastritis, historical features, and physical examination findings can help differentiate between various etiologies. Common symptoms include upper abdominal pain, indigestion, and, in some cases, nausea, vomiting, and bloating. Physical exams can show epigastric tenderness. It is helpful to distinguish between acute/persistent gastritis that is present for ≤ 30 days and chronic gastritis that is present for > 30 days.        

A history of significant physiological stress, such as trauma or surgery, points towards stress gastritis. Chronic NSAID or alcohol use suggests chemical gastritis, while infectious gastritis is typically associated with signs and symptoms of infection, such as fever and malaise. In contrast, autoimmune gastritis is suggested by a history of autoimmune diseases and neurological symptoms. Patients with H. pylori gastritis often present with loss of appetite, frequent belching, and weight loss.   

Option Analysis

❌ Stress gastritis :
Incorrect: Stress gastritis typically occurs in critically ill patients experiencing severe physiological stress (e.g., trauma, surgery, sepsis), and not in a stable patient in the outpatient setting who have chronic symptoms (> 30 days). This patient's history of autoimmune disease and findings of vitamin B12 deficiency is more consistent with autoimmune gastritis. 
❌ Chemical gastritis:
Incorrect: Chemical gastritis is usually associated with chronic use of NSAIDs, alcohol, or other irritants, which this patient does not use. The laboratory finding of vitamin B12 deficiency and history of autoimmune disease makes autoimmune gastritis more likely. 
❌ Infectious gastritis:
Incorrect: Patients with Infectious gastritis often present with acute symptoms such as fever, nausea, and vomiting. There are no indications of an active infection or relevant travel history in this case.  
✅ Autoimmune gastritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Helicobacter pylori gastritis:
Incorrect: While H. pylori can cause chronic gastritis, the finding of vitamin B12 deficiency and history of an autoimmune condition is more consistent with autoimmune gastritis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for an annual visit. Two days ago, while he was running, he slipped and fell, cutting his left hand on a metal grate. He cleaned and bandaged the wound at home. He received his last vaccinations prior to starting college at age 18. He had all the recommended vaccinations up to that time. He has no other medical concerns. He reports that he has been eating well and exercising 3-4 times per week. He does not smoke, drinks alcohol socially, and does not use other recreational substances. He has been in a monogamous relationship with his wife for 8 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. There is a 3 cm well-healing laceration that is clean with mild erythema and no purulence or discharge on the left palmar surface. Which of the following is this patient most at risk of developing if he is not given the appropriate vaccinations at this visit?
questions.solution:
This 33-year-old patient, who is otherwise healthy, presents for routine evaluation with his primary care physician. A core component of annual primary care evaluation is ensuring patients are up-to-date on the vaccination schedule. This patient has a 2-day-old clean superficial wound and his last Tdap was given over 10 years ago; therefore, Tdap vaccination is recommended now. Tdap vaccination is administered to help prevent tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. Infection with tetanus can lead to a severe form of tetanus known as generalized tetanus. The most common symptom in patients with generalized tetanus is trismus (lockjaw) and patients commonly have tonic contractions of muscles and intermittent intense painful muscular spasms.        

Immunity to tetanus and diphtheria wanes in adults. Unpredictable acute injuries are the main cause of tetanus in the United States. Therefore, Tdap immunization should be reviewed for any patient who presents with an acute injury or wound. For patients with clean minor wounds who have received three or more doses of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine, another dose should be given only if the last dose was given 10 or more years ago. For patients with wounds that are more severe than a clean and minor wound (i.e. wounds contaminated with dirt, feces, soil, or saliva; puncture wounds; avulsions; wounds resulting from missiles, crushing, burns, or frostbite) who have received three or more doses of a tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine, another dose should be given only if the last dose was administered five or more years ago. Additionally, Tdap vaccination is recommended for pregnant women during each pregnancy       

Option Analysis

✅ Painful muscle contractions and spasms:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Painful, vesicular rash:
Incorrect: The risk of shingles increases with age, with most cases occurring in patients over the age of sixty. Patients who are immunocompromised are also at increased risk. Vaccination is indicated for patients aged 50 and older. Given this patient’s age and lack of risk factors, he is not at significant risk for shingles, and vaccination is not recommended now. 
❌ Anogenital warts:
Incorrect: Routine HPV vaccination is recommended at 11 to 12 years to prevent infection with human papillomavirus (HPV), which is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes anogenital and oropharyngeal warts and can lead to orogenital cancers. This patient has had all routine childhood vaccinations and is not at increased risk; therefore, a vaccination to prevent this disease is not indicated now. 
❌ Jaundice, nausea, and vomiting:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A and B vaccinations are part of the routine childhood vaccinations to prevent infection and the development of liver disease. Hepatitis A vaccine is recommended for adults with certain risk factors, including international travelers and men who have sexual contact with other men. Hepatitis B vaccination is recommended for patients who have never received the vaccination or have had incomplete vaccinations or for certain high-risk patients. This patient received all childhood immunizations and is not at increased risk. 
❌ Swelling of the epiglottis :
Incorrect: The Hib vaccine, which protects against Haemophilus influenzae, is part of routine childhood vaccinations. Infection with H. influenzae can lead to invasive syndromes including meningitis, bacteremia, epiglottitis, and septic arthritis. It is not routinely recommended for adults unless they have certain risk factors such as asplenia or hematopoietic stem cell transplant. This patient is not at increased risk.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with a 4-month history of low back pain. He describes the pain as a dull, aching sensation that worsens with prolonged standing or walking and improves with rest. The pain is localized to his lower back and does not radiate to his legs. There has not been recent trauma or heavy lifting. There is no numbness, tingling, or weakness in his lower extremities, and he has not had bowel or bladder incontinence, fever, or weight loss. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both well-controlled with amlodipine and metformin, respectively. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient has a normal gait but appears uncomfortable when standing upright. There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar paraspinal muscles and the lumbar spinous processes. Range of motion is limited, especially in lumbar extension and rotation, which reproduces his pain. Neurological examination is unremarkable, with normal strength, sensation, and reflexes in the lower extremities. Straight leg testing is negative bilaterally. An x-ray is performed and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image by Nevit Dilmen, crop and annotation by Mikael Häggström, M.D. Licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
The patient's chronic, non-radiating low back pain that worsens with extension and rotation, combined with a normal neurological examination and absence of red flag symptoms, is suggestive of spondylosis. Spondylosis is a degenerative condition characterized by the wear and tear of the intervertebral discs and facet joints, commonly presenting with pain that worsens with specific movements and improvement with rest. The radiograph obtained in this patient demonstrates osteophytes, which are classic findings in spondylosis. Other findings consistent with spondylosis include decreased intervertebral disc space, and facet joint hypertrophy.

The diagnostic workup for an adult with mechanical back pain begins with taking a detailed history and physical examination to identify the nature and characteristics of the pain, along with any red flag symptoms. Plain X-rays can detect bony abnormalities like spinal fractures, spondylolysis, and spondylolisthesis. Spondylolysis often presents with a "Scotty dog" sign on oblique X-rays, while spondylolisthesis shows vertebral displacement. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard for evaluating soft tissue structures and differentiating between causes of low back pain. Findings associated with spinal stenosis include narrowing of the spinal canal with neural impingement. Findings associated with disc herniation include protrusion or extrusion of intervertebral discs causing nerve root compression. Findings seen with spondylosis include degenerative changes like disc space narrowing, osteophytes, and facet joint hypertrophy. MRI is critical in the workup of low back pain with red flag features and should be performed urgently when any red flags are present. Muscle strain or sprain is typically diagnosed clinically with a history of recent overuse or injury and physical exam findings of localized tenderness and muscle spasm without neurological deficits.    

Option Analysis

✅ Spondylosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Muscle strain:
Incorrect: Patients with muscle strain generally present with acute, diffuse back pain following overexertion or injury, often with paraspinal muscle spasms. This patient's history of chronic pain and the absence of a precipitating event make muscle strain less likely. 
❌ Cauda equina syndrome  :
Incorrect: Patients with cauda equina syndrome typically present with severe low back pain, saddle anesthesia, bowel or bladder incontinence, and significant neurological deficits. This patient does not exhibit any of these symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ S1 spinal fracture:
Incorrect: Spinal fractures typically present with acute onset of severe, localized pain following trauma or in patients with risk factors for osteoporosis. The patient’s chronic, activity-related pain without a history of trauma or osteoporosis risk factors is more indicative of a degenerative condition like spondylosis.  
❌ L5-S1 disc herniation:
Incorrect: Disc herniation commonly causes acute radicular pain, numbness, tingling, and possibly weakness in the extremities, usually associated with a positive straight leg raise test. The patient’s chronic pain is localized without radicular symptoms, making disc herniation less likely.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office due to dry cough, malaise, fatigue and arthralgias for the past month. He has also experienced unintentional weight loss over the past 3 months. He has no shortness of breath. His past medical history includes a history of chronic rhinosinusitis. He does not drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, or use recreational drugs. He is comfortable and in no respiratory distress. Vitals are within normal limits. Pulmonary auscultation reveals occasional rhonchi and no wheezing. There are no heart murmurs, the tip of the spleen is not palpable, palpable purpura is present on the lower extremities, and no joint swelling is appreciated. Laboratory results are shown below. Urinalysis is positive for blood and protein, and urine sediment analysis reveals multiple red blood cells casts. Given the most likely underlying condition, which of the following additional features is most likely to be present? 

 Laboratory Study     Results    
 Hemoglobin     9.5 g/dL    
 Leukocytes     5,500/mm3    
 Platelets     610,000/mm3    
 Creatinine     2.1 mg/dL    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     80 mm/hr
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with systemic vasculitis. He has a history of chronic rhinosinusitis, with a recent onset of fatigue and weight loss, cough, and arthralgias. He has rhonchi, palpable purpura, elevated inflammatory markers, and lab work consistent with anemia, and renal involvement, making granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) the most likely diagnosis. Patients with GPA frequently have ear, nose, and throat involvement, and saddle nose deformity can be seen due to bone and cartilage destruction from granulomatous inflammation and necrosis.        

GPA is a small-vessel vasculitis that can affect almost any tissue and can present similarly to microscopic polyangiitis (MPA). In addition to nonspecific constitutional symptoms, renal involvement, and lower respiratory involvement, patients with GPA often present with ear, nose, and throat signs and symptoms, such as recurrent sinus infections, nasal congestion, epistaxis, nasal crusting, and saddle nose deformity. Chest imaging showing lung nodules and positive PR3-ANCA would further support the diagnosis.        

Vasculitides share many similar features, including nonspecific systemic symptoms like fever, weight loss, and fatigue. Certain findings can aid in differentiating the specific type of vasculitis, as detailed in the chart below.    



Option Analysis

❌ Jaw claudication:
Incorrect: Jaw claudication is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) which is a large-vessel vasculitis that typically does not occur in patients under 50 years of age.
❌ Limb claudication:
Incorrect: Limb claudication is seen with Takayasu arteritis. It is not seen in patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which is the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ New diagnosis of severe asthma:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss or allergic granulomatosis) is a vasculitis that is associated with severe adult-onset asthma, and prominent peripheral blood eosinophilia, and vasculitis. Asthma is always present in the prodromal phase of the disease. This patient with fatigue and unintentional weight loss, arthralgias, chronic sinusitis, and pulmonary and renal involvement most likely has granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) which is not associated with asthma. 
✅ Saddle nose deformity:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Digital ulcers and gangrene:
Incorrect: Digital ulcerations and gangrene are characteristic of thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger disease), which is a medium-vessel vasculitis that is strongly associated with smoking. It is not typically seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with systemic symptoms, arthralgias, chronic sinusitis, and pulmonary and renal involvement.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of pain and ulcerations on his fingertips. He has a past medical history of asthma, seasonal allergies, and tobacco use disorder. He has smoked 1 pack per day for the past 30 years. He does not use alcohol or other recreational substances. He has no respiratory symptoms, hemoptysis, joint pains, oral or genital ulcers, or recent visual changes. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals digital ulcers and gangrene on several fingertips. Pulses in his lower extremities are diminished, and there are multiple tender superficial nodules along the veins in his arms and legs bilaterally. Laboratory results are shown below. Angiography of the upper and lower extremities shows segmental arterial occlusions with corkscrew collaterals. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory study     Result    
 Creatinine     0.8 mg/dL    
 Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)     Negative    
 Anti-myeloperoxidase (anti-MPO) antibodies     Negative    
 Antiproteinase-3 antibodies     Negative    
 Anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies     Negative
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation, including digital ulcers and gangrene, superficial thrombophlebitis, and significant smoking history along with his angiographic findings is highly suggestive of thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO; also referred to as Buerger disease).        

TAO primarily affects young, male smokers and involves segmental inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries and veins of the upper and lower extremities, leading to vascular occlusion and ischemia. Vascular imaging may be helpful but is not necessary for diagnosis. Findings suggestive of TAO include segmental occlusion and corkscrew collaterals on angiography. While a biopsy can confirm the diagnosis, it is rarely needed if clinical criteria are met. These criteria include age under 50 years, current or recent tobacco use, objective findings of distal extremity ischemia, typical arteriography findings, and exclusion of other potential diagnoses. The cornerstone of management is smoking cessation to reduce symptoms and prevent major amputations.   

Option Analysis

❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis typically present with upper respiratory tract symptoms, renal involvement, and positive PR3-ANCA. They typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans.
❌ Behçet disease:
Incorrect: Behçet disease is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and a positive pathergy test. They typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans. 
❌ Giant cell arteritis:
Incorrect: Giant cell arteritis (GCA) usually affects older adults and presents with symptoms including headache, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances. It is often associated with polymyalgia rheumatic with shoulder and hip involvement. Patients with GCA typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans. 
✅  Thromboangiitis obliterans:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a vasculitis associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, and eosinophilia. Patients typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with 3-months of greasy, foul-smelling stools that are difficult to flush and constant epigastric pain. He has had increased gas and abdominal and a 10-pound weight loss since the symptoms started. He has not had any recent travel, new medications, or dietary changes. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals epigastric tenderness and hyperactive bowel sounds. Fecal pancreatic elastase-1 is 180 mcg/g (normal range >500 mcg/g). Which of the following additional features is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of steatorrhea and weight loss with a low fecal elastase level is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. Chronic pancreatitis impairs the pancreas's ability to produce digestive enzymes, leading to malabsorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. A history of alcohol use disorder is a significant risk factor for chronic pancreatitis, as chronic alcohol consumption can lead to repeated inflammation and damage to the pancreas over time.        

Historical factors can help differentiate between causes of chronic diarrhea and guide further evaluation. For example, a history of heat intolerance might suggest hyperthyroidism, which can cause increased bowel motility, leading to diarrhea. The presence of an eczematous rash could point to celiac disease with dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gluten sensitivity and malabsorption. A family history of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) might indicate Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, which may present with bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Recent use of antibiotics may lead to antibiotic-associated diarrhea or Clostridium difficile infection, which is characterized by watery stools and abdominal cramping.    



Option Analysis

❌ Heat intolerance:
Incorrect: Heat intolerance is associated with hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism can cause chronic diarrhea, but given this patient’s steatorrhea and low fecal elastase, chronic pancreatitis is more likely to be the cause of his symptoms, and it is often associated with alcohol use disorder.  
❌ Eczematous rash:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic gastroenteritis is a cause of chronic diarrhea, and patients with this condition typically present with a history of asthma, eczema, or food sensitivities. This patient’s steatorrhea and low fecal elastase are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis which is often associated with alcohol use disorder.  
✅ History of alcohol use disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent antibiotic use:
Incorrect: Antibiotic use can lead to antibiotic-associated diarrhea or Clostridium difficile infection. This patient’s prolonged symptoms of steatorrhea with low fecal elastase on stool testing are more suggestive of chronic pancreatitis, which is associated with alcohol use disorder.  
❌ Episodic cutaneous flushing  :
Incorrect: Episodic cutaneous flushing is associated with carcinoid syndrome, which causes watery diarrhea. This patient’s steatorrhea associated with low fecal elastase is more suggestive of chronic pancreatitis, which is associated with alcohol use disorder.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. The symptoms have been worsening gradually over the past several months. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder and asthma. Current medications include albuterol and sertraline. The patient’s temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 137/85 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 81% on ambient air. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in mild distress. Cardiovascular examination is notable for jugular venous distension. Scattered expiratory wheezes are heard bilaterally on auscultation of lungs. Abdominal examination reveals a liver edge that is palpable inferior to the rib cage. There is mild lower extremity pitting edema bilaterally. ECG shows right axis deviation. Echocardiography reveals right ventricular dilation with increased wall thickness. The patient is admitted and, after further work-up, started on sildenafil. Which of the following is a common adverse effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with progressive exertional dyspnea and right axis deviation on ECG, in combination with right ventricular dilation and increased wall thickness on echocardiography, is suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. After further workup, the patient is started on sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor. The other important medication of this class is tadalafil.   

PDE-5, which is normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP, is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors, with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP and increase in nitric oxide activity in vascular smooth muscle cells. The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and an increase in the blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis. That is why most of the PDE-5 inhibitors are FDA-approved for the use in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension and erectile dysfunction.   

Common side effects include facial flushing, headache, dyspepsia, hearing loss, and hypotension (in combination with nitrates or alpha-blockers). Sildenafil cross-reacts with the PDE-6 inhibitor in the retina and can cause transient blue vision. Rarely, nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) is also seen.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hepatotoxicity :
Incorrect: Bosentan, an endothelin-receptor antagonist can help improve symptoms in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Major adverse effects include hepatotoxicity and peripheral edema. Patients should be monitored monthly with liver function tests. PDE-5 inhibitors do not usually cause hepatotoxicity. 
✅ Blue-tinged vision :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Serotonin syndrome :
Incorrect: Sildenafil is not a serotonergic drug. Using this in combination with sertraline is not associated with any adverse effects. 
❌ Priapism :
Incorrect: Priapism refers to prolonged erection lasting more than four to six hours and can occur in men who use intrapenile alprostadil. It is uncommon with intravenous or oral administration. 
❌ Severe hypotension :
Incorrect: PDE-5 inhibitors, when used in combination with nitrates, can lead to severe hypotension due to the accumulation of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. However, this patient is not taking nitrates and is unlikely to develop severe hypotension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of six months of progressive shortness of breath. The patient’s past medical history is significant for acute submassive pulmonary embolism that was treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator nine months ago. She was taking oral contraceptive pills at the time and presented after a six-hour-long drive. After further workup, the diagnosis of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension is made. Based on cardiothoracic surgery evaluation, she is deemed to not be a surgical candidate for thromboembolectomy. The physician discusses starting a new medication that is a soluble guanylyl cyclase stimulator and helps improve exercise capacity, pulmonary hemodynamics, and time to clinical worsening. Which of the following is the most likely medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressive shortness of breath after recovering from acute pulmonary embolism recently is concerning. She is diagnosed with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). Management of CTEPH typically includes thromboembolectomy. However, if the patient is not a surgical candidate (as in this case), they should be evaluated for medical management.        

Riociguat is a stimulator of soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC). The agent exhibits a dual mode of action; it sensitizes sGC to endogenous nitric oxide (NO), and it also directly stimulates sGC independently of NO. This drug has been shown to increase the walking distance and decrease the time to clinical worsening for patients with CTEPH; it is the only FDA-approved medication for this disease.   

Option Analysis

❌ Omalizumab :
Incorrect: Omalizumab is a IgE binding monoclonal antibody that decreases airway inflammation and is effective in the treatment of asthma that is unresponsive to other medications. It plays no role in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). 
❌ Filgrastim :
Incorrect: Filgrastim is a granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) that is effective in the management of leukopenia. It does not affect soluble guanylyl cyclase. 
❌ Degarelix :
Incorrect: Degarelix is a GnRH agonist that is sometimes used in the management of prostate cancer. It has no role in CTEPH. 
❌ Tizanidine :
Incorrect: Tizanidine is a centrally-acting alpha-2 agonist that is indicated in the management of muscle spasticity, multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and cerebral palsy. It is not indicated in CTEPH. 
✅ Riociguat :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of several weeks of vague abdominal pain and increased fatigue. The pain is localized to the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and is non-radiating. He has not had chest pain, fever, or cough. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and a mildly distended soft abdomen. The liver edge is hard and is palpated 8 cm below the costal margin. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. Laboratory results are shown below. Chest X-ray is unremarkable. CT scan of the abdomen is shown. After an appropriate workup, a definitive diagnosis is established. The patient declines surgery and wishes to continue with pharmacological therapy. In addition to 5-fluorouracil, a topoisomerase I inhibitor is added to the regimen. Which of the following is the most likely agent that is added? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin     8 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     8000/mm3    
 Platelet count       230,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     68 μm3    
 Serum     
 Creatinine      0.9 g/dL    
 BUN     12 g/dL    
 Alanine aminotransferase      57 U/L    
 Aspartate aminotransferase      38 U/L    


Reproduced by Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain and distention, microcytic anemia, positive fecal blood test, and hepatomegaly has multiple liver lesions on the CT scan, most likely due to undiagnosed colon cancer with metastasis to the liver. A combination of 5-fluorouracil and irinotecan (topoisomerase I inhibitor) represents one of the options of therapy for metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).        

Topoisomerases are enzymes that relieve the DNA supercoiling that occurs during DNA replication as a result of the separation and unwinding of the DNA. Topoisomerase I makes single-stranded nicks to relieve negative supercoiling. Topoisomerase I inhibitors (e.g., topotecan and irinotecan) are synthetic derivatives of 20 (S)-camptothecin, a natural product from the Camptotheca acuminata tree. They bind to and stabilize a transient TOPO I–DNA complex, resulting in double-strand breakage and lethal DNA damage. A few of the important features of topotecan and irinotecan are tabulated above.   

Option Analysis

❌ Etoposide :
Incorrect: Etoposide is a topoisomerase II inhibitor that increases DNA degradation by arresting the cell cycle in G2 and S phases. Although it is used in the management of solid tumors (testicular and small cell lung cancer), it is not indicated in the management of metastatic colorectal cancer. 
✅ Irinotecan :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Topotecan :
Incorrect: Although topotecan is a topoisomerase I inhibitor, it is usually used in the management of ovarian and small cell lung cancer. It is not indicated in this patient. 
❌ Paclitaxel :
Incorrect: Paclitaxel is a microtubule inhibitor that hyper-stabilizes the polymerized microtubules in M phase so that the mitotic spindle cannot break down. It is usually indicated in the management of ovarian cancer. 
❌ Cladribine :
Incorrect: Cladribine is a purine analog that inhibits DNA synthesis by inhibiting DNA polymerase and by inducing DNA strand breaks. It, however, does not affect topoisomerase I and is mainly indicated in the management of hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of left testicular mass. He first noticed the mass 3 weeks ago when he was taking a shower. It is painless and hard in consistency. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for lung cancer in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows firm ovoid left testes with a rubbery enlargement. The right testicle appears normal. Ultrasound of the testes shows a solid left testicular mass. A left orchiectomy is performed. A postoperative histologic and molecular analysis of the testes shows that the cancer cells are sensitive to etoposide. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient with a testicular mass is found to have testicular cancer. The cancer cells are sensitive to etoposide, which is a topoisomerase II inhibitor.       

Topoisomerases are enzymes that relieve the DNA supercoiling that occurs during DNA replication as a result of separation and unwinding of the DNA. Topoisomerase II makes double-stranded nicks to relieve negative supercoiling. Topoisomerase II inhibitors (e.g., etoposide and teniposide) bind to topoisomerase II and DNA to prevent the resealing of the break. The enzyme remains bound to the free end of the broken DNA strand, leading to an accumulation of DNA breaks and cell death. Cells in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle are the most sensitive.        

Topoisomerase II inhibitors are indicated in the management of solid tumors (e.g., testicular and small cell lung cancer), leukemia, and lymphomas. Elimination is mainly through the kidneys, requiring dosage reduction in patients with renal dysfunction. Common adverse effects include myelosuppression, gastrointestinal disturbances, and alopecia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cross-links DNA  :
Incorrect: Platinum agent (e.g. cisplatin) cross-links DNA and is used in the pharmacologic management of testicular cancer. Etoposide does not belong to this class of anticancer drugs. 
❌ Inhibits thymidylate synthase :
Incorrect: 5-fluorouracil inhibits thymidylate synthase to halt DNA synthesis. It is used in the treatment of colon cancer, pancreatic cancer, and actinic keratosis, but not testicular cancer. 
❌ Intercalates into the DNA  :
Incorrect: Dactinomycin intercalates DNA and prevents the synthesis of RNA in the cancer cell. It is usually indicated in the management of childhood tumors (e.g., Wilms tumor, Ewing sarcoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma). 
✅ Inhibits topoisomerase II :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inhibits microtubule formation :
Incorrect: Microtubule inhibitors vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine and vinblastine) bind β-tubulin and inhibit its polymerization into microtubules. They are indicated in the treatment of solid tumors, leukemias, Hodgkin, and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. Etoposide does not belong to this class of anticancer drugs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman comes to the office for a routine follow-up. She has no active complaints except for intermittent abdominal pain. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, and inflammatory bowel disease. Her bone mineral density was -2.0 at her previous visit three months ago. Current medications include glyburide, acetaminophen, azathioprine, calcium, and vitamin D supplements. Family history is significant for bladder cancer in the patient’s father. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Her baseline serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL (eGFR 21 mL/min/1.73 m2) and recent HbA1c is 7.2%. The patient requests the physician to prescribe her pioglitazone, which has caused significant improvement in her neighbor’s blood glucose levels. Which of the following is a potential contraindication for initiating this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus requests therapy with pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione. Pioglitazone is known to increase the risk of fractures and is contraindicated in patients with low bone mineral density (2.0, indicative of osteopenia).        

Thiazolidinediones, also known as glitazones (e.g., rosiglitazone and pioglitazone), bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR)-ɣ in adipose tissue, pancreatic beta cells, and vascular endothelium and regulates the transcription of many insulin-responsive genes. The net effect is increased insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues and reduced blood glucose levels.        

Glitazones also increase the synthesis of proteins involved in lipid metabolism, with a resultant decrease in triglycerides and an increase in both high-density lipoprotein and low-density lipoprotein. They are generally used as a second or third-line therapy in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Still, They can be used as initial therapy when first-line agents are contraindicated.        

Contraindications to glitazone use include:      

  •  Heart failure or fluid overload  
 
  •  History of fracture or at high risk for fracture (e.g. postmenopausal woman with low bone density)  
 
  •  Liver disease  
 
  •  History of bladder cancer  
 
  •  Type 1 diabetes  
 
  •  Pregnancy  
Side effects include osteopenia, increased risk of fractures, hepatitis (or transaminitis), edema, weight gain, bladder cancer (pioglitazone), myocardial infarction (rosiglitazone), and heart failure.  


Option Analysis

✅ High risk of fracture :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Impaired renal function :
Incorrect: Impaired renal function (estimated glomerular filtration rate [eGFR] <30 mL/min/1.73 m2) is a contraindication to metformin use, as it increases the risk of lactic acidosis. Pioglitazone can be administered to patients with chronic kidney disease. 
❌ Inflammatory bowel disease :
Incorrect: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a contraindication to using an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor (e.g. acarbose). Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione and is not contraindicated in patients with IBD. 
❌ Type 2 diabetes mellitus :
Incorrect: Type 1 diabetes mellitus, not type 2, is a contraindication to pioglitazone use since it is efficacious only in patients with DM 2. 
❌ Family history of bladder cancer :
Incorrect: Pioglitazone is known to increase the risk of bladder cancer and is contraindicated in patients with active bladder cancer. However, a family history of this disease is not a contraindication to its use.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for a routine follow-up. He has no active complaints, except for intermittent pain in his lower extremities. Past medical history is significant for type I diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. His home glucose readings demonstrate a constant elevation in postprandial blood glucose levels. HbA1c is 9.1%. Current medications include insulin lispro and lisinopril. The physician decides to add a new injectable medication that controls postprandial hyperglycemia by decreasing gastric emptying, suppressing glucagon release, and promoting satiety. Which of the following is an example of this medication?
questions.solution:
Pramlintide is an amylin analog administered subcutaneously during mealtime and regulates post-meal glucose by decreasing gastric emptying, suppressing glucagon release, and promoting satiety. Unlike other hypoglycemic medications, pramlintide can be used in type I and II diabetes. It is indicated in individuals taking prandial insulin (e.g, insulin, lispro) and must be injected immediately before a meal, at a site separate from that of insulin injection. Nausea is the most common side effect. Hypoglycemia can also occur, but only in the presence of other factors (e.g. mismatched timings with prandial insulin). It should be avoided in patients with gastroparesis history, as it delays gastric emptying. 

Option Analysis

❌ Metformin :
Incorrect: Metformin inhibits mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD), leading to the inhibition of gluconeogenesis by blocking pyruvate carboxylase, the first step of gluconeogenesis. This medication is administered orally and does not affect gastric emptying or glucagon release. 
❌ Canagliflozin :
Incorrect: Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitor that acts on the renal tubule to prevent glucose reabsorption. It is an oral medication that does not affect gastric motility or glucagon release.  
❌ Pioglitazone :
Incorrect: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that binds to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR)-ɣ and increases insulin sensitivity of adipose tissue and muscle. It is contraindicated in patients with type 1 diabetes, as it is only active in the presence of insulin. 
❌ Glyburide :
Incorrect: Glyburide is an insulin secretagogue (sulfonylurea) that inhibits the K-ATP channel of pancreatic beta cells, which results in insulin release in the blood at all glucose levels.  
✅ Pramlintide :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman is referred to the hematology clinic for follow-up due to a history of multiple thromboses and recent treatment for a mesenteric venous thrombosis. At the age of 26, during her second pregnancy, she was on bedrest for seven weeks and developed a right leg venous thrombosis. At the age of 43, she had a left leg venous thrombosis after sustaining a left pelvic and femoral fracture from a motor vehicle accident requiring extensive orthopedic surgery. The patient has never had arterial thrombosis. The patient has no evidence of cirrhosis, autoimmune conditions, or inflammatory bowel disease. She has a cousin with factor V Leiden mutation; however, her parents and siblings have no history of thromboses. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing with a normal cardiopulmonary exam and no peripheral edema. Which of the following factors indicates the need for an evaluation for an underlying hypercoagulable disorder?

choices.text: Prior right leg venous thrombosis following bedrest
Prior left leg venous thrombosis following surgery
Cousin with factor V Leiden mutation

questions.solution:
This 57-year-old woman is referred to the hematology clinic after experiencing multiple thromboses. This patient’s two lower extremity venous thromboses were likely provoked, both by orthopedic injuries, surgery, or immobility. However, thrombosis in the mesenteric vein is considered an atypical location, so this patient should be evaluated for an inherited hypercoagulable disorder.   

Hypercoagulable (or thrombophilic) disorders are conditions that lead to an increased tendency to form thromboses. They can be inherited (e.g., factor V Leiden, prothrombin gene mutations, deficiencies in protein C, S, and antithrombin) or acquired (e.g. antiphospholipid syndrome).   

All patients with thrombosis should be assessed for provoking risk factors, which include conditions that increase the risk of clotting. These may include recent surgery injury or immobilization, active malignancy, or active pregnancy. If no provoking risk factors are present then patients should be screened for hypercoagulable disorder if they are < 45 years of age, have recurrent thromboses, or thromboses in multiple veins and/or unusual sites, or are young and have arterial thrombosis.     

In patients without an underlying medical condition (e.g. cirrhosis), portal, hepatic, and mesenteric vein thromboses are considered unusual and testing for hypercoagulable disorders should be performed. Patients with unexplained arterial thrombosis (e.g., stroke, retinal artery thrombosis) should be screened for antiphospholipid syndrome.   

Option Analysis

✅ Mesenteric venous thrombosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Age of 57 years:
Incorrect: This patient’s age is not, by itself, an indication to screen for hypercoagulability. Young patients with unprovoked thromboses, especially arterial thromboses, should be screened for underlying hypercoagulable disorders. 
❌ Prior right leg venous thrombosis following bedrest:
Incorrect: Recurrent unprovoked venous thromboses or thromboses at unusual sites are indications to screen for a hypercoagulable disorder. This patient’s lower extremity venous thromboses both had obvious provoking factors and were far apart in time, making them less likely to be caused by a hypercoagulable disorder. 
❌ Prior left leg venous thrombosis following surgery:
Incorrect: Recurrent unprovoked venous thromboses or thromboses at unusual sites are indications to screen for a hypercoagulable disorder. This patient’s lower extremity venous thromboses both had obvious provoking factors and were far apart in time, making them less likely to be caused by a hypercoagulable disorder. 
❌ Cousin with factor V Leiden mutation:
Incorrect: Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited hypercoagulable disorder in White individuals. It is autosomal dominant with incomplete penetrance, (i.e., not everyone who inherits the mutation will develop thrombosis). Having a cousin with the condition and no immediate family members with Factor V Leiden or unprovoked thromboses, the diagnosis would be less likely.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit following an opiate overdose requiring intubation. The patient is mechanically ventilated and sedated on a propofol and fentanyl infusion. During rounds, the patient appears increasingly cyanotic. The patient has a history of alcoholism and opiate use disorder and does not take any medication daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate 115/min, blood pressure 136/68 mmHg, respiratory rate 10/min, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation 93% on 100% FIO<sub>2</sub>. The patient is not over-breathing the ventilator. Bilateral breath sounds are present and cardiac examination is within normal limits. The patient has evidence of skin cyanosis. Stat blood gas results are obtained, which show pH 7.27 and a pCO<sub>2</sub> 50. A chest x-ray demonstrates that the endotracheal tube is 2 cm above the carina. Which of the following should be assessed next to help determine the cause of cyanosis and respiratory acidosis in this patient?

choices.text: Endotracheal tube placement via direct laryngoscopy

questions.solution:
This patient is intubated and sedated following respiratory failure secondary to opiate overdose. The patient has evidence of cyanosis on examination with confirmed proper placement of the endotracheal tube, and ABG results demonstrate respiratory acidosis. Given this clinical setting, iatrogenic causes of respiratory acidosis secondary to ventilation should be considered, such as low tidal volumes, low respiratory rate, and equipment failure. A fault in any one of these settings may result in hypercapnia and subsequent acidosis. This patient’s respiratory rate is most likely set too low given his RR of 10 breaths/min and likely resultant respiratory acidosis. 

Many conditions fall can cause respiratory acidosis, including central nervous system (CNS), neuromuscular, obstructive, and parenchymal pulmonary etiologies; however, the presenting symptoms will be similar. Patients with respiratory acidosis may present with cyanosis, a decreased respiratory rate, or shortness of breath. Depending on the degree of hypercapnia, patients may also develop altered mental status and lethargy. Specific etiologies and appropriate treatments can be suggested by the clinical scenario–e.g., ventilated patients may need ventilator settings adjusted. Whereas patients with a focal neurologic deficit should have brain imaging to rule out CNS pathology (e.g., ICH).    

Option Analysis

✅ Ventilator settings:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rate of fentanyl infusion:
Incorrect: This patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a set respiratory rate. The rate of fentanyl infusion will not affect the respiratory parameters and cause a low respiratory rate of 10 breaths/min which is most likely the cause of respiratory acidosis in this patient. 
❌ Ocular examination:
Incorrect: An ocular examination is unlikely to provide useful information regarding the cause of respiratory acidosis in this patient who is sedated on propofol and fentanyl and has a low respiratory rate and raspatory acidosis. 
❌ Reflexes:
Incorrect: Reflexes would not add additional information for this patient who is intubated and sedated with new cyanosis, respiratory acidosis, and a low respiratory rate. 
❌ Endotracheal tube placement via direct laryngoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient has an endotracheal tube that is appropriately positioned on chest x-ray. Direct laryngoscopy is not necessary now and would not add more information. This patient should have the ventilatory settings checked and likely have the respiratory rate increased.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found down outside in a nearby park next to a stone wall. EMS reports that a bystander called after the patient was unable to be aroused. He was given a one-time dose of naloxone intranasally in the field without significant improvement. The patient's past medical history is unknown, but bystanders say he usually sleeps in the park. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate 50/min, blood pressure 162/42 mmHg, respiratory rate 8/min and irregular, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation 93% on room air. The patient is moaning with slurred speech. He has a large hematoma on the right side of his head and significant ecchymoses on the right shoulder, elbow, and hip. He is moving all extremities spontaneously. Pupillary examination reveals normal-sized pupils bilaterally that are equal, reactive, and oval-shaped, Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals irregular respirations, but no murmurs are present. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdominal exam is within normal limits. Point-of-care blood glucose is within normal limits. An arterial blood gas is drawn and shows a pH 7.27 and a pCO<sub>2</sub> 52. Which of the following tests will most likely confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after being found down and is found to have a hematoma on the right side of the head and ecchymoses on the right side of the body. He has respiratory acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis, irregular breathing, bradycardia, and widened pulse pressure (Cushing Triad). These findings are consistent with Cushing triad (bradycardia, Kussmaul respirations, and a widened pulse pressure) along with the finding of bilateral papilledema, are indicative of elevated intracranial pressure. Given the evidence of increased intracranial pressure and signs of head trauma, a computed tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast should be performed to evaluate for and intracranial processes such as traumatic intracranial hemorrhage.

Many conditions can cause respiratory acidosis, including central nervous system (CNS), neuromuscular, obstructive, and pulmonary parenchymal etiologies. Determining a differential diagnosis and subsequent diagnostic workup for patients with respiratory acidosis should be tailored to the underlying history and physical examination findings. For example, for patients with a likely neurological process, the physical exam may reveal decreased respiratory rate, altered mental status, or focal neurological deficits. These patients should undergo further evaluation with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or CT and should be screened for substance intoxication/overdose. Historical and physical examination findings and diagnostic tests associated with the different causes of respiratory acidosis are summarized in the chart above.        

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography (CT) brain without contrast :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chest X-ray:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of Cushing triad and bilateral papillary edema and head trauma, making an intracranial process most likely.  
❌ Serum ethanol level :
Incorrect: Alcohol Intoxication/overdose should be considered in the differential for a patient with undifferentiated respiratory acidosis; however, this patient has evidence of Cushing triad, bilateral papilledema, and head trauma, making an intracranial process most likely. 
❌ Urine drug screen:
Incorrect: Intoxication with recreational substances should be considered in the differential for a patient with undifferentiated respiratory acidosis; however, this patient has evidence of the Cushing triad, papilledema, and head trauma, making an intracranial process most likely. Furthermore, the patient was given naloxone without significant improvement, making acute opiate overdose less likely.  
❌ Ammonia level  :
Incorrect: Hyperammonemia can result in altered mental status and subsequent respiratory acidosis; however, this patient has no findings consistent with end-stage liver disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is taken to the emergency department after being found unresponsive with shallow breathing at a local park. The emergency medical services team reports that a bystander administered intranasal naloxone prior to their arrival, which promptly resulted in the patient regaining consciousness. However, he soon became agitated, reporting severe muscle aches, abdominal cramping, and nausea. The patient is refusing to provide any additional medical history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, heart rate is 118/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is restless, irritable, and diaphoretic. Piloerection is noted on the arms bilaterally and eyes are watery with dilated pupils bilaterally. ECG shows a regular rhythm, with each QRS complex preceded by a normal P wave with a consistent PR interval. Laboratory studies are ordered. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of opioid withdrawal after receiving naloxone. Establishing intravenous (IV) access for administration of fluids and medications to treat withdrawal symptoms is the most appropriate next step in management.

Opioid withdrawal occurs when a person who has developed physical dependence on opioids suddenly reduces or stops using the drug. The severity of withdrawal symptoms can vary depending on the duration and intensity of opioid use and the type of opioid involved. Common symptoms of opioid withdrawal include agitation, anxiety, muscle aches, watery eyes, runny nose (rhinorrhea), excessive sweating (diaphoresis), insomnia, and frequent yawing. Additional findings can include abdominal cramping, diarrhea, dilated pupils (mydriasis), goose bumps, and nausea.

Management of opioid withdrawal in the emergency department focuses on alleviating symptoms and ensuring patient safety. An initial evaluation should include an ABCDE assessment, along with the establishment of IV access for fluid and medication administration, and vital sign monitoring. In patients who present with naloxone-induced withdrawal symptoms after an intoxication event, it is particularly important to monitor their mental and respiratory status for potential reemergence of opioid intoxication effects due to the short duration of action for naloxone. Non-opioid medications (e.g., alpha-2 agonists, antiemetics, antidiarrheals) or buprenorphine (a partial mu agonist) are appropriate options for symptom management.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous access:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral metoprolol  :
Incorrect: Beta blockers, such as metoprolol, are used to control heart rate in certain situations (e.g., atrial fibrillation). However, this patient has sinus tachycardia (based on ECG findings) which is likely due to opioid withdrawal and should be managed by treating the underlying cause. 
❌ Oral methadone :
Incorrect: While methadone is often an option for managing acute opioid withdrawal symptoms, it is not recommended for management of withdrawal symptoms triggered by naloxone. This is because of the potential of rebound opioid intoxication, and the amount of methadone that would be required to overcome naloxone’s antagonistic effect. 
❌ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: Intubation is not indicated in this patient who has an adequate respiratory rate (20/min) and is maintaining an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are reserved for patients who exhibit signs of respiratory failure or who have severely altered mental status and cannot protect their airway. 
❌ Intramuscular naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone was already administered by emergency medical services, which effectively reversed the opioid overdose, as evidenced by the patient regaining consciousness and the onset of withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of nausea, vomiting, muscle aches, and anxiety. The symptoms began a few days after taking her last dose of pain medication before it ran out. She has a past medical history of osteoarthritis and had been prescribed oxycodone for pain management for several years, but her primary care physician recently retired, and she has been unable to get an appointment with a new doctor to refill her prescriptions. She also has a history of hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril. Vital signs are stable, and physical examination reveals a mild tremor, piloerection, and diaphoresis. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing signs and symptoms of opioid withdrawal syndrome after running out of oxycodone which she has been using for pain from osteoarthritis. Opioids are not typically an appropriate long-term treatment for osteoarthritis, and in this case, they should not be restarted. Her withdrawal symptoms and opioid dependence should be managed with buprenorphine. 

Management of opioid withdrawal syndrome depends on the clinical scenario and goals for the patient. For patients who require chronic opioid therapy and who develop symptoms after running out of their prescription, restarting the opioid may be appropriate. However, for patients with opioid use disorder, who should not restart opioids, buprenorphine or methadone should be initiated.

Buprenorphine is a partial opioid receptor agonist with a long half-life and an effective analgesic profile. It has a ceiling effect, which prevents the euphoric effect of opioids and decreases the risk of overdose. Additionally, it is commonly formulated with naloxone, an opioid antagonist, which further prevents agonistic effects at the opioid receptor, and can be used as a deterrent for returning to injection opioids. Patients can be safely weaned off opioids completely by slowly tapering buprenorphine over time.   

Option Analysis

✅ Buprenorphine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Disulfiram  :
Incorrect: Disulfiram is an aversive agent used to help patients with alcohol use disorder stop drinking. It is not used to treat opioid withdrawal syndrome.  
❌ Oxycodone :
Incorrect: Prescribing oxycodone would perpetuate this patient’s dependence on opioids and does not address the management of her withdrawal symptoms or the inappropriateness of opioids for long-term management of osteoarthritis. 
❌ Tramadol :
Incorrect: Tramadol, an opioid analgesic, could potentially lessen withdrawal symptoms but is not the optimal treatment for opioid withdrawal and could contribute to ongoing opioid dependence. 
❌ Naltrexone  :
Incorrect: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist typically used to prevent relapse after detoxification in opioid dependence. Initiating naltrexone in the acute withdrawal phase is inappropriate as it can precipitate severe withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter due to confusion and lethargy for the past two days. The patient has recently been telling her daughter that she has been nauseous with a metallic taste in the mouth. She has chronic kidney disease secondary to hypertension and diabetes mellitus. She has not had any recent falls or head trauma. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 168/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. The patient is disoriented to time and place. On examination, there is periorbital and peripheral edema, dry mucous membranes, and dry skin with bilateral upper extremity excoriations. Lung auscultation reveals bibasilar crackles. There is mild diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following additional historical features is most likely in this patient?  

 Laboratory Test      Result     
 Potassium      6.2 mEq/L     
 Creatinine      6.5 mg/dL (Baseline 2.0 mg/dL)     
 Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)  98 mg/dL     
 Bicarbonate      15 mEq/L     
 Blood glucose      86 (mg/dL)

choices.text: Progressive memory loss over the past year

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic kidney disease who presents with confusion, fluid overload (periorbital and peripheral edema, pulmonary crackles), recent nausea, and a metallic taste in the mouth and is found to have a significantly elevated creatinine level, the most likely diagnosis is acute on chronic renal failure and uremic encephalopathy from the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen. The laboratory findings of elevated BUN and creatinine, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis further support this diagnosis. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can exacerbate renal dysfunction by reducing renal blood flow. 

When patients present with altered mental status (AMS), the history and physical examination can provide clues to the underlying cause. Laboratory testing can further support the diagnosis. The table below shows some of the common causes of AMS and their associated findings.        

Option Analysis

❌ Polyuria and polydipsia:
Incorrect: Polyuria and polydipsia are more commonly associated with hyperglycemia, particularly in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. They are not seen in patients with uremic encephalopathy, which is the most likely diagnosis for this patient given her normal blood glucose. 
❌ Progressive memory loss over the past year:
Incorrect: Progressive memory loss over an extended period is more indicative of a neurodegenerative condition, such as dementia, rather than the acute onset of symptoms seen in this patient who likely has uremic encephalopathy.  
❌ Recent use of opiates:
Incorrect: Opiate use can contribute to altered mental status, particularly through respiratory depression. This patient's fluid overload, dry skin with excoriations, and elevated BUN and creatinine in the context of chronic kidney disease makes uremic encephalopathy the more likely diagnosis. 
✅ Recent use of ibuprofen:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chest pain and palpitations:
Incorrect: Chest pain and palpitations would suggest cardiac etiology, such as ischemic heart disease or symptomatic arrhythmias. In this patient with acute renal dysfunction and altered mentation, uremic encephalopathy is more likely the cause of her altered mental status.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine visit. She is feeling well and has no specific concerns. She is sexually active with both men and women and has been with the same female partner for the past two months. She uses oral contraceptives for birth control and regularly uses condoms. She is up-to-date on vaccinations. A routine pelvic examination is performed. Which of the following findings on the pelvic examination should prompt further evaluation for sexually transmitted infections?

choices.text: A small amount of clear cervical mucus
A moderate amount of thick, white opaque cervical discharge
Mild redness of the cervix without discharge
A palpable, smooth, and mobile ovary
A small amount of thin white vaginal discharge with a mild odor

questions.solution:
A moderate amount of thick, white opaque cervical discharge is indicative of purulent cervical discharge which can be associated with cervicitis. Further investigation for sexually transmitted infections (STI) such as chlamydia or gonorrhea should be pursued in this patient. Chlamydia trachomatis is a common bacterial STI that often presents with minimal or no symptoms but can cause mucopurulent cervicitis--characterized by purulent cervical discharge. Untreated chlamydia can lead to complications like pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), infertility, and chronic pelvic pain. Therefore, further testing, including nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) for chlamydia and gonorrhea, should be performed on all patients with purulent cervical discharge. 

When patients present with signs and symptoms indicative of a sexually transmitted infection, a thorough history should be performed. It allows the clinician to gather essential information about the patient's sexual behaviors, past medical history, and risk factors that may not be immediately apparent, such as having multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use, or history of previous STI infections or exposures. The physical examination helps identify findings that might indicate an underlying infection, such as cervical discharge, genital ulcers, or lymphadenopathy. 

In asymptomatic patients without symptoms or findings consistent with STIs, screening is recommended for high-risk patients to prevent complications from untreated STIs. History should include a detailed sexual, social, and past medical history to assess for risk factors that place patients at increased risk for ЅΤІs, such as history of prior ЅΤI and history of multiple sex partners. In certain patients SТІ ѕϲreening should be performed because the patient belongs to a risk group associated with a high prevalence of ЅΤIs or high morbidity from contracted ЅТІs. This includes patients 15-24 years old, men who have sex with men, and patients with HIV positive status.   

Option Analysis

❌ A small amount of clear cervical mucus:
Incorrect: This is a normal physiologic finding associated with the ovulatory phase of the menstrual cycle. No further workups are necessary.
✅ A moderate amount of thick, white opaque cervical discharge:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mild redness of the cervix without discharge:
Incorrect: Mild erythematous changes of the cervix can be a normal finding and do not necessarily indicate pathology. It can be related to hormonal changes or benign cervical ectropion, where glandular cells of the cervix extend outward onto the vaginal portion of the cervix. No further workups are necessary.  
❌ A palpable, smooth, and mobile ovary:
Incorrect: Palpating a smooth, mobile ovary on bimanual examination is a normal finding. Ovaries should be assessed for size, tenderness, and mobility. In the absence of masses or significant tenderness, a smooth and mobile ovary is typically considered normal, and no further workup is necessary. 
❌ A small amount of thin white vaginal discharge with a mild odor:
Incorrect: A thin white vaginal discharge can be normal, particularly in the absence of a strong odor, itching, or irritation. This type of discharge is often seen with normal vaginal flora or in response to hormonal changes. It may be related to normal leukorrhea, which occurs throughout the menstrual cycle. No further workups are necessary.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a skin lesion on his back. The lesion has been present for nine months without significant change. It was slightly itchy and inflamed after a backpacking trip he took last month, but it has since returned to baseline. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the lesion pictured below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 


Image by Assafn is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license. Reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This patient’s raised, waxy, brown lesion with a “stuck-on” appearance is classic for seborrheic keratosis. These lesions are typically asymptomatic but may become itchy or inflamed due to friction. Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin lesion that does not require intervention unless it causes discomfort or the patient desires removal. However, the abrupt appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, known as the sign of Leser-Trelat, is a rare paraneoplastic phenomenon associated with internal malignancy, and patients should be evaluated further.

Most benign skin lesions can be diagnosed clinically based on a thorough history and physical examination. Benign lesions are usually symmetrical in shape, color, and structure, with a size < 6 mm. They are typically stable over time with little to no change in appearance and without spontaneous bleeding.  

Lesion location and features of a patient’s history can aid in determining the diagnosis. For example, actinic keratoses are common in sun-exposed areas and often are seen in the context of repeated sun exposure. Patients with pyogenic granuloma commonly have a history of pregnancy or treatment with retinoids, chemotherapy, antiretrovirals, or immunosuppressive medication. Sebaceous hyperplasia is associated with hormonal changes, such as menopause, or the use of immunosuppressive therapy or antiretroviral medications. Lentigo often occurs in patients with a history of fair skin, sun damage, phototherapy, or radiation therapy; keloids and dermatofibromas occur in an area of prior skin trauma or inflammation. Lastly, patients with acrochordon (skin tags) may have a history of obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, or hormonal imbalances.   

Option Analysis

✅ Seborrheic keratosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Melanocytic nevus:
Incorrect: A melanocytic nevus (commonly known as a mole) is a flesh-colored, pink, tan, or brown papule that’s dome-shaped or pedunculated and typically soft or rubbery in texture. The pictured lesion has a dull, waxy surface with a “stuck on” appearance, which is classic for seborrheic keratosis.  
❌ Actinic keratosis:
Incorrect: Actinic keratosis presents as a scaly macule, papule, or plaque with a rough texture either with or without erythema. The pictured waxy, brown lesion is not consistent with the appearance of an actinic keratosis and is more suggestive of seborrheic keratosis.  
❌ Malignant melanoma:
Incorrect: A lesion suspicious for malignant melanoma will typically have concerning features from the ABCDE assessment (asymmetry; irregular borders; varying colors; diameter usually > 6 mm; and evolving in size, shape, or color). The pictured lesion lacks these features and has a dull, waxy surface with a “stuck on” appearance that is classic for seborrheic keratosis. 
❌ Pyogenic granuloma:
Incorrect: A pyogenic granuloma typically looks like a red, pedunculated, friable papule on the skin surface. The pictured waxy, brown lesion is not consistent with the appearance of a pyogenic granuloma and is suggestive of seborrheic keratosis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a “lump” on her left arm. She first noticed the painless mass approximately two months ago, and it has grown slowly since that time. There has been no trauma to the area, and she has not had similar symptoms previously. She is not bothered by the mass but would like to know what it is. Vital signs are within normal range. Physical examination reveals a 3 cm soft, non-tender subcutaneous nodule on the posterior aspect of the left upper arm as pictured below. The mass is rubbery in texture and mobile. Which of the following is the best way to diagnose this lesion? 


Image by Jmarchn is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic findings of a lipoma, including the painless nature of the mass, location on the upper extremity, slow growth, rubbery texture, and mobile nature. Lipomas are subcutaneous skin lesions. The diagnosis of a lipoma can be made based on a clinical assessment alone in most cases; ultrasound imaging and biopsy are helpful when concerning features are present.        

The ABCDE assessment (asymmetry; irregular borders; varying colors; diameter usually > than 6 mm; and evolving in size, shape, or color) helps to identify whether a skin lesion is likely to be malignant. Dermatoscopy and biopsy can aid in the diagnosis of lesions on the skin surface, such as melanocytic nevi (flesh-colored, pink, tan or brown papule with soft or rubbery texture) and keratinic lesions (e.g. lentigo, seborrheic keratosis, sebaceous hyperplasia, actinic keratosis, and epidermoid cyst), that have concerning features from the ABCDE assessment. Vascular lesions, such as cherry angiomas (blanching red spot on the skin) and pyogenic granulomas (red growth on the skin surface with recurrent bleeding), can be diagnosed clinically.

Fibrous skin lesions are benign growths, such as keloids, acrochordons, and dermatofibromas, on the skin surface. These can be identified by appearance with the help of history. Keloids are associated with prior skin trauma, and dermatofibromas are linked to skin trauma or inflammation. Acrochordons (skin tags) are typically found on areas of friction near the neck, axilla, or groin in patients with obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, or hormonal imbalances.   

Option Analysis

✅ Clinical assessment  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dermatoscopy:
Incorrect: Dermatoscopy involves using a skin surface microscope to help differentiate benign lesions from dysplastic and malignant lesions. This lesion is below the skin surface; therefore, dermatoscopy would not be helpful.  
❌ Excisional biopsy:
Incorrect: Excisional biopsy may be needed when the diagnosis of a subcutaneous mass is unclear. This mass has classic features and findings of a benign lipoma, and the diagnosis can be made clinically.  
❌ Fine needle aspiration:
Incorrect: Fine needle aspiration collects cells or fluid from a mass to determine whether it is benign or malignant, but it is not necessary in the diagnosis of a classic lipoma.  
❌ Ultrasound:
Incorrect: Ultrasound can be used to aid in the diagnosis of a soft tissue mass when the clinical picture is unclear. This mass has classic findings of a lipoma and can be diagnosed clinically.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family for evaluation of lethargy and hematemesis for the past few hours. He has a known history of chronic liver disease secondary to alcohol use disorder. The patient had several episodes of hematemesis prior to presentation and has become progressively more lethargic. He last drank alcohol that morning. He takes no medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 96/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears somnolent but arousable when called by his name. Dried blood is seen around his mouth and scleral icterus is present. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastrium and spider angioma are present on the abdomen. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory test      Result     
 Hemoglobin      10.2 g/dL     
 White blood cell count      9,000 /µL     
 Platelets      44,000 /µL     
 Prothrombin time (PT) 13 seconds     
 Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 35 seconds

choices.text: CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hemodynamic instability and lethargy from gastrointestinal bleeding (hematemesis) likely secondary to chronic liver disease. The initial step in management for all patients with acute blood loss and hemodynamic compromise is stabilization. Initially, this involves administering intravenous fluids to maintain adequate perfusion to vital organs. Blood product transfusions should be considered dependent on the severity of bleeding. 

The likely source of bleeding in this patient with a history of alcohol use disorder, stigmata of chronic liver disease, low platelets, and coagulation abnormalities is likely undiagnosed esophageal varices or gastric ulcers. Chronic liver disease can increase the risk of bleeding because of coagulation factor deficiencies, thrombocytopenia, and platelet dysfunction. Further management, including endoscopy and electrocautery or banding, can be performed once the patient is hemodynamically stable.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Prophylactic broad-spectrum antibiotics are recommended for patients with cirrhosis and gastrointestinal bleeding before endoscopy is performed. However, the immediate priority for this patient is administration of intravenous fluids for hemodynamic instability. 
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: Endotracheal intubation is not necessary at this time since the patient is maintaining adequate oxygenation and is able to protect his airway, despite being somnolent.  
❌ CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT angiography is not appropriate management for patients with chronic liver disease, acute gastrointestinal bleeding, and hemodynamic instability. Intravenous fluids should be administered, and then when the patient is hemodynamically stable, endoscopy should be performed. 
❌ Emergent endoscopic evaluation:
Incorrect: Endoscopic evaluation would be crucial to identify and manage the source of bleeding in this patient; however, it should be performed after the patient's hemodynamic status is stabilized with IV fluids.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the clinic with spontaneous bruising and nosebleeds over the past two weeks. He reports associated fatigue, decreased appetite, and myalgias. He has a past medical history of chronic kidney disease secondary to diabetes mellitus.
