He has been noncompliant with his medications over the past three weeks and has not been taking any medications. His current medication regimen includes losartan, insulin, and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. He has no prior history of recurrent or excessive bleeding or bruising. On examination, he appears pale with scattered ecchymoses over the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. There is dry crusted blood in both nares. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely cause of bleeding and bruising in this patient? 

 Laboratory Test      Result     
 Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL     
 White blood cell count 6,500 /µL     
 Platelets 190,000 /µL     
 Prothrombin time (PT) 13 seconds     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 35 seconds     
 Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) 85 mg/dL     
 Serum Creatinine 5.2 mg/dL (previously 2.0 mg/dL)     
 Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) 12 mL/min/1.73 m²     
 Fibrinogen 300 mg/dL     
 D-dimer 0.4 mg/L

choices.text: Reduced activation of platelet fibrinogen receptor and dysfunction of platelet granules
Impaired platelet aggregation due to COX-1 inhibition
Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor

questions.solution:
This patient who presents with spontaneous bruising and recurrent epistaxis has not been compliant with his medications and likely has acute chronic kidney disease (CKD). He has an increased creatinine level, elevated BUN, and significantly reduced GFR. In patients with low glomerular filtration rates, impaired platelet function, in part from reduced activation of platelet fibrinogen receptor and dysfunction of platelet granules, can cause easy bleeding and bruising. 

Patients with reduced glomerular filtration rate and platelet dysfunction may have signs of uremia, like a friction rub, but they generally do not have clinical symptoms or signs of uremia.        

Option Analysis

✅  Reduced activation of platelet fibrinogen receptor and dysfunction of platelet granules:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Impaired platelet aggregation due to COX-1 inhibition:
Incorrect: COX-1 inhibition is typically caused by aspirin or NSAID use. It can lead to impaired platelet aggregation, but this patient has not been taking any medications that could cause this. 
❌ Decreased production of clotting factors:
Incorrect: Decreased production of clotting factors is more commonly associated with liver disease and not kidney disease. This patient's normal PT and aPTT also make this mechanism less likely.  
❌ Immune-mediated platelet destruction:
Incorrect: Immune-mediated platelet destruction results in thrombocytopenia; however, this patient has normal platelet count. 
❌ Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor:
Incorrect: Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor is seen with Von Willebrand disease, which is a common hereditary bleeding disorder. This patient has never previously had frequent or recurrent bleeding or bruising. His current symptoms are more likely due to platelet dysfunction from kidney disease.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a witnessed cardiac arrest. The patient developed pulseless ventricular tachycardia in the field and was shocked once with an AED device. Upon arrival, CPR is ongoing, intravenous access is obtained, an airway is established, one milligram of epinephrine is administered intravenously, and the patient is shocked an additional two times due to persistent ventricular tachycardia. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and pulse is 152/min. Which of the following agents is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department after a witnessed cardiac arrest and is given several rounds of CPR, shocks, and epinephrine to treat pulseless ventricular tachycardia. Based on advanced cardiac life support algorithms, the next best step in managing this patient’s condition is the administration of intravenous amiodarone. 

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic agent considered a first-line agent in treating pulseless ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation unresponsive to CPR, defibrillation, and epinephrine. In addition, sotalol can be used to treat ventricular tachycardia. However, sotalol is not considered a first-line agent due to its excessive ꞵ-blocking effects.

Apart from these agents, other class III antiarrhythmic agents, such as ibutilide or dofetilide, can also be used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia.

Finally, class III antiarrhythmic agents (notably amiodarone and sotalol) can also be used in treating supraventricular tachycardias, given their ꞵ-blocking effects.   

Option Analysis

✅ Amiodarone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Diltiazem :
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that is not routinely used for treating ventricular tachycardia and is not included in ACLS algorithms. It is primarily used as a rate control agent for supraventricular tachycardias.  
❌ Flecainide :
Incorrect: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic agent that can be used for ventricular tachycardia. However, it should not be used as a first-line agent.  
❌ Sotalol:
Incorrect: Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic agent that can be used to treat ventricular tachycardia. However, it is not included as a first-line agent in ACLS algorithms.  
❌ Esmolol:
Incorrect: Esmolol is a class II antiarrhythmic agent used for rapid blood pressure management in intracranial hemorrhage and aortic dissection. However, it is not used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter who reports that the patient has been increasingly forgetful and disoriented over the past seven days. The patient has a history of alcohol-related cirrhosis and was recently discharged from the hospital after treatment for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Over the past week, the daughter has noticed that the patient has been sleeping during the day, which is unusual for her. At times she has been difficult to arouse. The patient has also become increasingly irritable and has had trouble completing simple tasks that were previously easy for her. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. She is oriented only to person. Physical examination reveals generalized jaundice, scleral icterus, abdominal distension with shifting dullness, and spider angiomas overlying the upper chest wall. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Flapping tremor of the hands with arm extension
Exaggerated response of deep tendon reflexes
Upward extension of the big toe in response to stroking the sole of the foot
Involuntary pronation of the right arm
Increased muscle tone leading to resistance to passive movement

questions.solution:
The patient presents with altered mental status and is found to have a distended abdomen and stigmata of chronic liver disease on physical exam. These findings are consistent with hepatic encephalopathy. A key physical examination finding in patients with hepatic encephalopathy is asterixis, also known as a "flapping tremor." It can be observed when the patient extends the arms and dorsiflexes the hands, leading to irregular, coarse, non-rhythmic jerking movements. Asterixis reflects a lapse in postural tone control, which is characteristic of metabolic encephalopathies like hepatic encephalopathy.       

When evaluating a patient with suspected hepatic encephalopathy (HE) history taking should focus on recent changes in mental status, including confusion; disorientation; sleep disturbances; abnormal behavior; as well as any difficulties with attention, memory, or performing tasks of daily living. Providers should inquire about precipitating factors, such as recent infection, gastrointestinal bleeding, dehydration, and use of sedatives or diuretics. The physical examination should assess the patient’s level of consciousness, orientation, and ability to follow commands. Signs of chronic liver disease, such as jaundice, ascites, palmar erythema, spider angiomas, and muscle wasting, should be noted as this can also indicate the severity of underlying liver disease. Neurological examination should focus on detecting asterixis and ruling out focal neurologic deficits that may indicate other causes of altered mental status like stroke.   

Option Analysis

✅ Flapping tremor of the hands with arm extension :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Exaggerated response of deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: Hyperreflexia refers to an exaggerated deep tendon reflex and is more commonly associated with upper motor neuron diseases, like with stroke or spinal cord injuries. It is not a typical finding for patients with hepatic encephalopathy. However, asterixis is common with hepatic encephalopathy.  
❌ Upward extension of the big toe in response to stroking the sole of the foot:
Incorrect: The Babinski sign, characterized by dorsiflexion of the big toe and fanning of adjacent toes in response to stroking the lateral aspect of the sole, indicates dysfunction of the corticospinal tract, often due to an upper motor neuron lesion. It is typically associated with conditions like multiple sclerosis, stroke, or spinal cord injury. It is not typical with hepatic encephalopathy, which is more commonly associated with asterixis. 
❌ Involuntary pronation of the right arm :
Incorrect: Pronator drift is a test of upper motor neuron function where the patient extends the arms forward with palms up. A positive test occurs when the patient involuntarily pronates one or both arms and lowers them. It suggests a mild hemiparesis and is more specific to conditions that affect the corticospinal tract, such as stroke. 
❌ Increased muscle tone leading to resistance to passive movement:
Incorrect: Rigidity refers to increased muscle tone leading to resistance to passive movement. It is often seen in patients with extrapyramidal disorders.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman is brough to the emergency department by her family for evaluation of increasing confusion, fatigue, and abdominal distension over the past two days. Her family reports that she has been more forgetful over the past few days and has had difficulty staying awake throughout the day. The patient has a history of cirrhosis secondary to untreated hepatitis C. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is oriented only to person, and the rest of the neurologic exam is nonfocal. The abdomen is tense and mildly tender to palpation with shifting dullness and a fluid wave. The patient exhibits a flapping tremor when asked to extend their arms. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 White blood cell count     13,500/µL    
 Hemoglobin     11.2 g/dL    
 Platelet count     75,000/µL    
 Total bilirubin     3.8 mg/dL    
 AST     72 U/L    
 ALT     56 U/L    
 Serum creatinine     1.6 mg/dL    
 Ammonia     85 µg/dL

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with overt hepatic encephalopathy (HE) and ascites, along with an elevated white blood cell count and fever, raising the suspicion for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Prompt diagnosis of SBP via paracentesis should be made in cases of HE where SBP is a likely precipitant. Prompt administration of antibiotics (e.g. ceftriaxone) is essential to prevent further deterioration.        

SBP refers to an infection of ascitic fluid that can occur in patients with cirrhosis and is often a precipitating factor for HE. The pathogenesis involves bacteria that translocate from intestinal tissue into the ascitic fluid secondary to impaired liver function and immune dysregulation. SBP can exacerbate HE via increasing systemic inflammation and disruption of hepatic metabolism, ultimately increasing the neurotoxic effects of ammonia. While ammonia levels are often elevated in patients with HE, an elevated ammonia level is not necessary to make the diagnosis; and levels may be elevated in patients without HE.       

Covert hepatic encephalopathy (CHE) is characterized by subtle cognitive and psychomotor impairments that are not clinically apparent without specialized testing, such as psychometric tests or critical flicker frequency analysis. Patients with CHE may have mild attention deficits, memory issues, or sleep disturbances but typically maintain normal daily functioning. In contrast, patients with overt hepatic encephalopathy (OHE) present with obvious neuropsychiatric symptoms, such as confusion; disorientation; and in severe cases, stupor or coma. The transition from covert to overt encephalopathy can be suspected based on the onset of noticeable mental status changes and physical exam findings, particularly asterixis (flapping tremor of the hands), which can be identified during a routine clinical examination.   

Option Analysis

✅ Paracentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is used to manage hepatic encephalopathy; however, the immediate priority is to rule out and treat any underlying infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), which could have precipitated the encephalopathy. 
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are essential if spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is confirmed or strongly suspected; however, the diagnosis in this stable patient should be confirmed via paracentesis prior to initiating antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis with contrast:
Incorrect: Imaging may be useful in some cases; however, it is not the first step in managing a patient with suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and encephalitis. Paracentesis is the more direct and immediate diagnostic test. Contrasted studies should be avoided in this patient with signs of acute kidney injury (e.g. elevated creatinine).  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) head without contrast :
Incorrect: A CT head without contrast is generally indicated if there is a suspicion of an intracranial process, such as a hemorrhage or stroke, which is less likely in this context where there are no focal neurologic findings. The clinical presentation of this patient is more suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), making paracentesis the appropriate next step.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis B is admitted to the hospital with confusion, lethargy, and disorientation. He is diagnosed with overt hepatic encephalopathy (OHE) and started on lactulose therapy, titrated to achieve 2-3 soft stools per day. Over the next five days, his symptoms dramatically improve. Vital signs are within normal limits and his physical examination is unremarkable. He is now alert; oriented to person, place, and time; and back to his baseline cognitive function. He is tolerating a regular diet and has no new symptoms. Which of the following is the next step in management upon discharge?

choices.text: Discontinue lactulose and recommend protein restriction

questions.solution:
This patient was hospitalized for overt hepatic encephalopathy and was effectively treated with lactulose. On lactulose, he has had a return to his baseline mental status, and, therefore, should be discharged on lactulose indefinitely. Lactulose remains the cornerstone of treatment for hepatic encephalopathy (HE), even after symptoms have resolved. It helps to prevent the recurrence of encephalopathy by reducing the absorption of ammonia in the gut.       

Lactulose, a nonabsorbable disaccharide, works by lowering ammonia levels in the blood through two mechanisms: it acidifies the colon, converting ammonia to ammonium, which cannot be absorbed; and it promotes the excretion of ammonia through the stool by acting as a cathartic. Lactulose can be continued indefinitely in patients with HE who have had a good response. It is typically titrated to achieve 2-3 soft stools per day, which helps to prevent the recurrence of HE by maintaining low ammonia levels.        

The antibiotic Rifaximin is often used as an adjunct to lactulose in patients with recurrent episodes of HE despite adequate lactulose therapy. It works by reducing the population of ammonia-producing gut bacteria, thereby decreasing ammonia production. While lactulose remains the first-line treatment, rifaximin is added in cases of recurrent or persistent HE to enhance the therapeutic effects and reduce the risk of relapse.        

After adding rifaximin to the treatment regimen, the patient's response should be reassessed after 48 hours. If there is noticeable improvement in mental status, lactulose should be continued indefinitely, and rifaximin should be continued for at least three months. However, if the patient's condition does not adequately improve, it may indicate severe liver dysfunction, necessitating surgical consultation to evaluate for liver transplantation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Continue lactulose indefinitely :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Discontinue lactulose:
Incorrect: Discontinuing lactulose is inappropriate because it increases the risk of recurrent hepatic encephalopathy. Lactulose is essential for maintaining low ammonia levels and preventing future episodes of HE. This patient with HE should continue on lactulose indefinitely. 
❌ Switch to rifaximin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Rifaximin is typically used as an adjunct to lactulose in patients with recurrent episodes of HE or for those who do not respond adequately to lactulose alone. It is not used as monotherapy unless lactulose is poorly tolerated.  
❌ Add rifaximin to lactulose:
Incorrect: Adding rifaximin to lactulose is considered for patients with frequent recurrence of hepatic encephalopathy despite lactulose therapy. This patient has shown significant improvement with lactulose alone; therefore, there is no need to add rifaximin at this time. 
❌ Discontinue lactulose and recommend protein restriction:
Incorrect: Discontinuing lactulose and restricting protein intake is not recommended. Protein restriction can lead to malnutrition. Current guidelines favor maintaining adequate oral protein intake while continuing lactulose indefinitely to prevent encephalopathy.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for assessment of a lesion on the right eyelid. She describes it as slightly uncomfortable but not painful to touch. She has no pain with extraocular eye movements, no discharge, redness, fevers, or vision changes. She does not wear eye makeup. Past medical history is noncontributory. There is no significant family history. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is a nontender firm, dome-shaped nodule with mild erythema on the mid upper eyelid overlying as shown in the image below. Examination of the inner upper eyelid reveals a nontender rubbery nodule. Which of the following features would be consistent with the most likely underlying diagnosis? 


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Associated pain and tenderness to palpation
Improvement with conservative management in less than one week

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of an eyelid lesion without concerning features for a more insidious process (e.g. vision changes, fevers). Given the description of gradual onset and the finding of a firm nontender nodule felt in the inner eyelid, the most likely diagnosis is a chalazion. These lesions result from obstruction of a meibomian gland, leading to the formation of a sterile lipogranuloma. They typically occur in the middle of the upper eyelid and are nontender; they may be erythematous. Chalazia typically resolve with conservative management, like warm compresses, over several months.    

When evaluating patients with eyelid lesions, it is important to assess for erythema, edema, and tenderness to palpation of the eyelid. If these are present, serious conditions, such as orbital cellulitis, should be ruled out. Findings consistent with orbital cellulitis include fever, vision changes, pain with extraocular eye movements, violaceous discoloration, significant erythema and tenderness, and possibly proptosis.    

If orbital cellulitis or other serious ophthalmological conditions are ruled out clinically, benign eyelid diseases can be considered, such as chalazion or hordeolum (stye). Hordeola are typically erythematous and tender and occur acutely on the upper or lower eyelids. A pustule can form at the margin of the eyelid, which can become infected. Differentiating a chalazion from a hordeolum may be challenging, but careful history and physical examination is usually sufficient to make a diagnosis. The chart below provides key characteristics for each condition.  



Option Analysis

✅ Gradual onset:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Associated pain and tenderness to palpation:
Incorrect: This patient’s findings are most consistent with a chalazion, which typically develops gradually and is painless. Chalazions can become uncomfortable if they become enlarged or secondarily infected, but they are not typically painful and tender to palpation.   
❌ Improvement with conservative management in less than one week:
Incorrect: Treatment for both chalazia and hordeola is supportive with warm compresses. Hordeola typically resolve within one to two weeks, while chalazia take longer to resolve (up to several months) and require treatment by an ophthalmologist. 
❌ Proptosis:
Incorrect: Proptosis may be associated with orbital cellulitis. This patient’s finding of a rubbery, nontender lesion in the inner eyelid is more consistent with a chalazion. 
❌ Leukocytosis:
Incorrect: Leukocytosis may be associated with orbital cellulitis. This patient’s finding of a rubbery, nontender lesion in the inner eyelid is more consistent with a chalazion.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the primary care physician for persistent left eyelid swelling. The patient states he accidentally bumped his eye on a doorframe one week ago, resulting in a small abrasion that subsequently became increasingly swollen, red, and painful. His primary care physician examined him two days ago, prescribed cephalexin, and instructed him to return if his symptoms worsened. Today, he returns for new pain with eye movements and blurry vision in the left eye. He has been taking his antibiotics as prescribed. The patient has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia for which he takes amlodipine, atorvastatin, and metformin. He drinks socially and does not use tobacco products. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 120/60 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there is evidence of marked peri-orbital erythema and swelling. There is tenderness to palpation of the left upper eyelid and chemosis of the left eye. Extraocular movement causes pain. Visual acuity is decreased in the left eye compared to the right. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the orbits and hospital admission for intravenous antibiotics
Fluorescein eye stain test and ophthalmology evaluation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a worsening eyelid lesion unresponsive to antibiotic therapy. He has several findings that suggest orbital cellulitis: periorbital swelling erythema and tenderness, pain with extraocular eye movements, vision changes, and fever. When encountered in a primary care setting, these patients should be transferred to the nearest hospital for admission, CT imaging of the orbits, and intravenous antibiotics.     

In the evaluation of eyelid lesions, it is important to assess for erythema, edema, and tenderness to palpation of the eyelid; this can indicate serious conditions, such as orbital cellulitis. Additional signs and symptoms that may suggest this vision-threatening diagnosis include fever, associated vision changes, pain with extraocular eye movements, violaceous discoloration, and proptosis of the eye.    

Workup for orbital cellulitis should include a CBC, cultures of the blood, nasal passage, and/or periorbital discharge as well as a CT or MRI of the orbits. Imaging is particularly important to assess the extent of the infection and rule out abscess formation or other complications. Treatment includes IV antibiotics to cover common causative pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Haemophilus influenzae. Surgical consultation is warranted if there is evidence of an abscess, intracranial extension of the infection, worsening visual acuity, pupillary changes, or failure to respond to antibiotics.   

Option Analysis

✅ CT of the orbits and hospital admission for intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Outpatient trimethoprim-sulbactam therapy:
Incorrect: Antibiotic coverage for Staphylococcus aureus should be considered; however, this patient with clinical evidence of orbital cellulitis requires inpatient admission and intravenous antibiotics.  
❌ Outpatient reevaluation in 24 hours :
Incorrect: Reevaluation in 24 hours would be inappropriate given the patient has clinical evidence of orbital cellulitis, which requires inpatient admission and intravenous antibiotics. 
❌ Outpatient ciprofloxacin therapy:
Incorrect: Although ciprofloxacin would enhance coverage for Pseudomonas aeruginosa, this patient requires more intensive management for suspected orbital cellulitis, including hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics. 
❌ Fluorescein eye stain test and ophthalmology evaluation :
Incorrect: Fluorescein staining the eye is a useful clinical test to assess for corneal abrasions, herpetic lesions, corneal ulcers, or penetrating globe injuries. However, it is not a useful test in the diagnosis of orbital cellulitis. Additionally, while an ophthalmology evaluation may be helpful, the immediate need for imaging and systemic management of the infection with intravenous antibiotics takes precedence.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of black, tarry stools and lightheadedness for two days. He has a history of cirrhosis due to chronic alcohol use. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 116/min, blood pressure is 96/42 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears pale and fatigued but is oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with a positive fluid wave. Rectal examination reveals guaiac positive dark, tarry stool. Laboratory results are shown below. Intravenous access is established via two peripheral 18-gauge catheters. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin      9.4 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      28 %     
 Leukocyte count      12,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      88,000/mm3     
 PT/INR      25 seconds     
 PTT      28 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of hemorrhagic shock (tachycardia, hypotension, pallor, and lethargy), melena (i.e. black, tarry stool, guaiac positive stool), and anemia indicating gastrointestinal bleeding. Given the clinical history of cirrhosis the most likely source of bleeding is an upper gastrointestinal source. Gastrointestinal bleeding in patients with cirrhosis is often exacerbated by thrombocytopenia (platelet count less than 150,000/mm3), which is seen in this patient. The primary goal in acute management of a hemodynamically unstable patient who is actively bleeding is to restore and maintain perfusion of vital organs. The patient should receive immediate administration of IV fluids (normal saline or lactated Ringer's).        

Patients with cirrhosis and end stage liver disease can experience multiple hemostatic abnormalities that can lead to or exacerbate bleeding. Altered blood flow, thrombocytopenia, diminished functioning of platelets, and inflammatory alterations in endothelial cells can increase the risk of bleeding in this patient population. The cause of thrombocytopenia is often multifactorial in patients with chronic liver disease.    

Option Analysis

❌ Platelet transfusion :
Incorrect: While a platelet transfusion may be necessary to treat thrombocytopenia in patients who are actively bleeding, the immediate focus for this patient should be IV fluid resuscitation.  
✅ Intravenous fluid resuscitation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Octreotide infusion :
Incorrect: Octreotide infusion serves as a part of the treatment for variceal bleeding. However, this patient should first be stabilized with intravenous fluids before being evaluated for variceal bleeding with an EGD.  
❌ CT angiography of abdomen/pelvis :
Incorrect: CT angiography of the abdomen/pelvis can be used for localizing the source of bleeding in patients who are hemodynamically stable without an obvious source of bleeding. This test would not be performed prior to stabilization with intravenous fluid resuscitation and EGD to look for the source of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.  
❌ Intravenous vitamin K :
Incorrect: Vitamin K should be considered when there is evidence of vitamin K deficiency affecting clotting parameters, which is likely in this patient with cirrhosis. However, this would follow immediate resuscitative efforts with intravenous fluids.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with a past medical history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension is found to have acute right leg pain and swelling during morning rounds.  Five days ago, he was admitted to the hospital with community-acquired pneumonia and was intubated due to acute hypoxic respiratory failure. His medications during the admission included aspirin, atorvastatin, losartan, ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and subcutaneous heparin. He was extubated yesterday and transferred to the step-down unit. Vitals are within normal limits. Pulses are intact in bilateral lower extremities. On examination, there is swelling of the right calf with tenderness to palpation in the posterior calf. A Doppler ultrasound shows a deep vein thrombosis in the right popliteal vein. Laboratory studies from the morning are shown below. Which of the following studies should be performed next to confirm the most likely diagnosis?  

       Today      On admission (5 days ago)     
 Hemoglobin      10.6 g/dL      11.1 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count      8,500 /mm3      16,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count      78,000/mm3      278,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient who was hospitalized and treated for severe community acquired pneumonia is found to have a new deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and thrombocytopenia after being treated with subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis. He most likely has heparin induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) and should have platelet factor 4 antibody testing to confirm the diagnosis.          

The diagnostic workup for thrombocytopenia varies significantly based on the most likely underlying cause based on the clinical presentation and history. Initial evaluation typically involves a complete blood count (CBC) with a peripheral smear, which helps identify whether the thrombocytopenia is isolated or accompanied by other cytopenias. This may also reveal important clues like schistocytes in cases of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) or blasts suggestive of a bone marrow disorder.        

Further diagnostic tests may include coagulation profiles PT, aPTT, fibrinogen, and D-dimer level), especially when disorders like disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are suspected, which presents with a combination of bleeding, clotting, and organ dysfunction. Coagulation profiles should be checked in cases of chronic liver disease. In patients with suspected thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), tests for ADAMTS13 activity level and ADAMTS13 inhibitors are used to confirm the diagnosis. For suspected HUS, a stool sample should be sent for culture, Shiga toxin and complement testing. For suspected bone marrow pathologies, a bone marrow biopsy is essential to identify the nature of the marrow involvement (i.e. infiltration by malignant cells or fibrosis). In cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), platelet factor 4 antibody testing and platelet serotonin-release testing are used to confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate management.  



Option Analysis

❌ ADAMTS13 activity level :
Incorrect: ADAMTS13 activity testing is not used for diagnosing heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). It is used to diagnose thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), where a deficiency of this enzyme leads to microvascular thrombosis and platelet consumption. This patient most likely has HIT from the use of subcutaneous heparin. 
✅ Platelet factor 4 antibody :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ D-dimer :
Incorrect: A D-dimer test is typically used to rule out thrombosis when clinical suspicion is low. Given that a DVT has already been confirmed via ultrasound, this test would not contribute any additional information. This patient has findings that are most consistent with HIT. 
❌ Bone marrow biopsy :
Incorrect: A bone marrow biopsy could help in the evaluation of thrombocytopenia where there is suspicion of bone marrow failure; infiltration by malignant cells; or other marrow pathologies, such as myelodysplastic syndrome or aplastic anemia. A bone marrow biopsy is not used to diagnose heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, which is the most likely diagnosis in this case.  
❌ Peripheral blood smear :
Incorrect: A peripheral blood smear would show thrombocytopenia in a patient with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), but it would not confirm the diagnosis. The presence of HIT antibodies directed against PF4 would confirm the diagnosis of HIT.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of left foot pain. The patient recently joined a fitness program that requires her to walk two to three miles daily. The pain begins with her first steps and worsens throughout her daily walks. The pain improves with rest and does not recur with normal daily activities. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a normal left and right foot arch. Direct pressure applied to the bottom of the left heel elicits a sharp pain. Mediolateral squeezing of the heels does not elicit pain. There is tenderness to palpation between the left heel and forefoot when the left toes are dorsiflexed. The remainder of the bilateral lower extremity examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve
Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s heel pain is most likely due to the inflammation and degeneration of plantar aponeurosis, resulting in plantar fasciitis. 

Plantar aponeurosis is a thick fibrous band that extends from the calcaneus of the foot to the toes, which functions to support the longitudinal arch of the foot. Plantar fasciitis results from chronic overuse and repetitive trauma to aponeurosis near its insertion point at the calcaneus. Risk factors include obesity, excessive foot pronation, excessive running, and prolonged standing. Patients typically present with stabbing heel pain that worsens with walking and may worsen after activity or at the end of the day. Physical examination often demonstrates tenderness at the insertion of the plantar fascia on the calcaneus, especially with toe dorsiflexion. 

The diagnosis is based on clinical findings, but plain radiographs may reveal heel spurs, which are of little diagnostic significance. Plantar fasciitis is a self-limited condition with most resolution of symptoms within twelve months. Initial treatment consists of ice, heat, massage, stretching, and elimination of exacerbating activities.   

Option Analysis

❌ Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve :
Incorrect: Injury or compression of the posterior tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel may result in numbness or paraesthesias over the sole of the foot. Pain is reproduced with percussion of the tarsal tunnel (Tinel sign) and not by the palpation of the heel. 
❌ Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves :
Incorrect: Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves can result in a Morton neuroma, which presents with pain between the third and fourth toes on the plantar surface and a clicking sensation upon squeezing the metatarsal joints. Tenderness of the heel with dorsiflexion of the toes is typical of plantar fasciitis. 
✅ Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Overuse injury of the calcaneus :
Incorrect: Calcaneal stress fractures can occur following the initiation of high-impact exercise programs or overuse. It causes pain at the heel that worsens with weight bearing. Pain is often elicited by firm palpation at the lateral and medial aspect of the heel. Tenderness of the heel reproduced on dorsiflexion of toes is more typical for plantar fasciitis. 
❌ Neurogenic arthropathy :
Incorrect: Neurogenic arthropathy (charcot joint) presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma, secondary to imapired proprioception and pain sensations. Therefore, pain is typically mild in these patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of difficulty wearing her shoes due to medial eminence of the right big toe. She is a dancer which requires her to work for twelve hours a day wearing specially fitted, tight closed shoes. The patient also reports pain worse with weight-bearing and when wearing her shoes. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows lateral deviation of the right great toe and enlargement of a medially deviated first metatarsal head. Skin over the enlarged toe is hard, warm, and red. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s toe pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral deviation of the great toe and enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head, suggestive of hallux valgus (bunion).

Hallux valgus is a progressive foot deformity that occurs when the first metatarsal head deviates medially, producing a painful bump causing the hallux to compensate with lateral deviation. Patients usually present with a prominent bump at the medial side of the metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP) joint.

Common risk factors include gender (women), footwear (tight pointed shoes), congenital deformity, or chronic achilles tension. Symptoms can range in severity from mild to severe discomfort, aggravated by standing, walking, or wearing narrow or stiff shoes. Examination and radiographs reveal the diagnosis.    Pressure and friction from prolonged hallux valgus deformity can lead to the development of corn(s), which are hyperkeratotic localized overgrowths.    

Option Analysis

❌ Gout :
Incorrect: Patients with gout often report a relatively sudden onset of severe symptoms including pain, swelling, and redness. This patient’s deformity developed insidiously. 
❌ Hallux rigidus :
Incorrect: Patients with hallux rigidus will typically present with pain, stiffness, and swelling in the first MTP joint, aggravated by repetitive dorsiflexion at the MTP joint. Physical examination will reveal limited and often painful range of motion of the big toe, along with crepitus. Prominent osteophytes on the dorsal aspect of the joint are usually visible and palpable. Lateral deviation of the great toe with enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head is seen in hallux valgus. 
✅ Hallux valgus :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Charcot arthropathy :
Incorrect: Charcot joint presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma and impaired proprioception and sensation of pain. Patients often have underlying diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Turf toe :
Incorrect: Turf toe refers to an acute injury at the MTP joint when the great toe is forced superiorly injuring the plantar plate. A classic mechanism is an athlete jamming his or her foot against a hard surface. Prominent enlargement on the medial foot is suggestive of hallux valgus deformity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right inguinal swelling that he first noticed today while showering. The patient reports mild discomfort. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows enlarged, tender right inguinal and popliteal lymph nodes. Which of the following conditions, if found, would most likely explain this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Painless ulceration on the glans penis
Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence

questions.solution:
Lymphadenopathy is characterized by an abnormality in size, number, or consistency of any lymphatic nodes and usually occurs in response to infection, malignancy, or an auto-immune condition.

The lower extremity lymphatic system gets divided into both superficial and deep lymphatic vessels, which follow the path of the venous and arterial system. The superficial lymphatic vessels drain lymph from the skin and subcutaneous tissues, whereas the deep lymphatic system drains lymph from both the superficial vessels and deep muscles. The superficial system is further divided into both medial and lateral tracks.
 

Therefore, an infected lesion on the lateral foot would result in the enlargement of both popliteal and inguinal lymph nodes, in contrast to medial foot lesions (only inguinal lymphadenopathy). 

Lymph from the superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes traverses the external and common iliac nodes before entering the lateral lumbar (aortic) lymph nodes and the lumbar lymphatic trunk.       

Option Analysis

❌ Firm nontender right testicular mass :
Incorrect: Lymph from the testes drains directly into the para-aortic lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Asymmetric firm prostatic nodules :
Incorrect: Lymph from the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Painless ulceration on the glans penis :
Incorrect: The glans penis is drained by the deep lymphatic system into the deep (not superficial) inguinal lymph node.  
❌ Exudative pharyngitis  :
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis results in cervical (not inguinal) lymph node enlargement. 
✅ Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the primary care office because of a weak urinary stream. This has been going on for the past six months and is gradually worsening to the point that he has to strain to urinate. The patient has urinary frequency and urgency but no incontinence or pain with micturition. He was treated two weeks ago with antibiotics for a presumed urinary tract infection. He also states that he has had difficulty maintaining erections for the past six months. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The rest of the examination is noncontributory. His recent HbA1c was 5.6%. Urinalysis is shown below. Prostate-specific antigen is 5.5 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s symptoms? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Urinalysis    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     negative    
 Blood     negative    
 Leukocyte esterase     negative    
 Nitrites     negative    
 Leukocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     1-2/hpf
questions.solution:
The findings of irritative (urinary frequency, urgency) and obstructive symptoms (weak urinary stream and straining on micturition) in combination with a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, non-tender prostate with rubbery texture on digital rectal examination (DRE) make benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) the most likely diagnosis. The patient’s difficulty maintaining an erection indicates erectile dysfunction. Tadalafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor, is the most appropriate medication for this patient.   

PDE-5 is responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to smooth muscle relaxation (by enhancing NO activity). The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis. Common indications include erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension. Tadalafil, however, can also be used in the management of BPH. PDE-5 is highly expressed in the lower urinary tract and supporting vasculature. Tadalafil, due to its slightly different structure than other medications in its class, can also affect PDE-5 in the lower urinary tract. This decreases smooth muscle cell proliferation in the prostate and relaxes the smooth muscle in the prostate, bladder, neck, and supporting vasculature, thereby relieving the irritative and obstructive urinary symptoms.   

Option Analysis

❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole :
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an antibiotic often used to treat urinary tract infections (UTI). These can present with suprapubic pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency, with or without systemic toxicity. Urinalysis would show positive leukocyte esterase, more significant pyuria (white blood cells), and possibly nitrites. This patient’s urinalysis does not indicate UTI. 
❌ Prostatectomy :
Incorrect:  Although a prostatectomy is a management option for BPH, it is not usually pursued until medical treatment or transurethral techniques are proven ineffective or unavailable. 
❌ Sildenafil :
Incorrect: Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor and is usually used to manage erectile dysfunction. It does not provide symptomatic improvement of BPH. 
✅ Tadalafil  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ceftriaxone :
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic often used to treat UTIs. These can present with suprapubic pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency, with or without systemic toxicity. Urinalysis would show positive leukocyte esterase, more significant pyuria (white blood cells), and possibly nitrites. This patient’s urinalysis does not indicate UTI.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crushing substernal chest pain that started one hour prior to arrival. The patient’s initial electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, for which he is taken to the cardiac catheterization lab for stent placement. Shortly thereafter, his telemetry monitor alarms and a stat electrocardiogram is obtained and shown below. Of the following medications, which is the most effective treatment for this patient’s clinical condition? 



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a wide complex tachycardia, which is consistent with ventricular tachycardia, after having an acute inferior myocardial infarction with stent placement. The most appropriate medication to treat this patient’s condition is a class IB antiarrhythmic, such as lidocaine or mexiletine.        

Class IB antiarrhythmics are weak sodium channel blockers and preferentially affect ischemic or depolarized purkinje and ventricular tissue. This property makes them excellent agents for use in ventricular arrhythmias in the peri-myocardial infarction period. These medications effectively block sodium channels in depolarized tissues or inactivated sodium channels, which are highly abundant in ischemic cardiac tissue.   

Option Analysis

✅ Mexiletine :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Propafenone:
Incorrect: Propafenone is a class IC antiarrhythmic medication that has no effect on the effective refractory period in Purkinje and ventricular tissue. As a result, this medication would not be effective in treating this patient’s ventricular tachycardia. 
❌ Procainamide:
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class IA antiarrhythmic medication that has utility in treating ventricular tachycardia. However, it is not the most effective agent in this situation due to its lack of selectivity towards ischemic cardiac tissue. Mexiletine would be a more effective treatment option.       
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a class IV antiarrhythmic medication used for rate control for supraventricular tachycardias. It is not used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia. 
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is a class II antiarrhythmic medication, which, like diltiazem, is used for rate control for supraventricular tachycardias. In contrast, it is not used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset palpitations. She was out walking her dog when she suddenly felt light-headed and dizzy. Past medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications daily. The patient does not drink alcohol or use illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg. Physical examination is grossly unremarkable. Electrocardiogram demonstrates atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, delta waves, and wide QRS complexes. The patient is given a medication which alters the ventricular action potential as illustrated below. Which of the following medications was most likely used to terminate this patient's arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations and electrocardiographic findings that demonstrate atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Additionally, she has concerning features of Wolff-Parkinson White including delta waves and wide QRS complexes. She is given a medication that increases the action potential duration, increases the effective refractory period, and increases the QT interval. These properties are consistent with those of class IA antiarrhythmic medications.       

Class IA antiarrhythmic medications include quinidine, procainamide, and disopyramide. These are the only class I antiarrhythmic medications that also have class III antiarrhythmic properties, meaning that they have some potassium channel-blocking effects. Hence, these medications lead to an increased action potential duration, QT interval, and effective refractory period.   

Option Analysis

✅ Procainamide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone does prolong the QT interval, effective refractory period, and action potential duration by inhibiting cardiac potassium channels and hence prolonging repolarization. However, amiodarone does not significantly affect phase 0 of the action potential, which is mediated by sodium channel blockade. 
❌ Adenosine:
Incorrect: Adenosine works via blockade of the A1 adenosine receptor, which triggers an increase in potassium efflux via blockade of the AV node. In the setting of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, blockade of the AV node can result in ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death due to increased conduction through the accessory bypass tract.  
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic medication, which will decrease the QT interval and action potential duration. In contrast, the above figure demonstrates an increase in action potential duration.   
❌ Flecainide:
Incorrect: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic medication, which has minimal to no effect on action potential duration. In contrast, the above figure demonstrates an increase in action potential duration.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman is seen by her primary care physician for a well-care visit. She has been doing well and has not seen her physician in over 2 years. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She has no shortness of breath, palpitations, dizziness, chest pain, or syncope. She has no family history of coronary artery disease. She does not use tobacco. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, heart rate is 96 beats per minute and irregularly irregular, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears comfortable. A 12-lead electrocardiogram is obtained and shows an irregular rhythm with a rapid ventricular response, without the presence of P Waves, and with variable P-R intervals. Trans-thoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows normal left ventricular (LV) function. Laboratory tests are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin     13.5 g/dL   
 Thyroid-stimulating hormone     2.1 µU/mL   
 Creatinine     0.9 mg/dL   
 INR     1.0

choices.text: Start oral anticoagulant now followed by cardioversion

questions.solution:
This patient is found to have atrial fibrillation (AF) of unknown duration. She is asymptomatic, hemodynamically stable, over 70 years of age, without other risk factors for cardiovascular disease, and has normal left ventricular (LV) function; therefore, a rate control strategy using the calcium channel blocker diltiazem is preferred for managing her AF. Rate control is associated with fewer side effects and aims to reduce symptoms, improve heart function, and reduce the risk of tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. This patient should also have risk stratification for thromboembolic and bleeding risks to help determine the need for antithrombotic therapy to prevent stroke and the risk of embolization. In addition to using calcium channel blockers, rate control can be managed with beta-blockers or digoxin.      

In contrast, rhythm control is effective at reducing symptoms, and is preferred in patients with reduced LV function, those less than 70 years of age who are more likely to maintain sinus rhythm, and patients with A-fib for less than a year. Rhythm control can be performed using electrical cardioversion, pharmacologic therapy, or catheter ablation. Pharmacological options for rhythm control include antiarrhythmics like amiodarone, flecainide, or propafenone.  

Option Analysis

✅ Start rate control with diltiazem:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Start oral anticoagulant now followed by cardioversion:
Incorrect: This patient who has atrial fibrillation of unknown duration is asymptomatic, hemodynamically stable, over 70 years of age with normal LV function. Therefore, a rate control strategy is preferred. 
❌ Schedule catheter ablation  :
Incorrect: Immediate catheter ablation without prior anticoagulation for patients with atrial fibrillation lasting more than 48 hours is contraindicated due to the elevated risk of thromboembolism. Anticoagulation for at least 3 weeks is required before considering rhythm control strategies like ablation. Additionally, this patient should be treated with a rhythm control strategy. 
❌ Perform synchronized cardioversion:
Incorrect: Synchronized cardioversion without anticoagulation in a patient with atrial fibrillation for more than 48 hours increases the risk of stroke from embolization of an atrial thrombus. Anticoagulation should be initiated first before cardioversion. Additionally, this patient should be treated with a rhythm control strategy.  
❌ Start antiarrhythmic therapy immediately:
Incorrect: Starting antiarrhythmic therapy without addressing the risk of thromboembolism is inappropriate in this patient with potential prolonged atrial fibrillation. Additionally, this patient can be treated with a rhythm control strategy.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute-onset lower abdominal pain, difficulty urinating, and a weak urinary stream for one day. He has no fever, chills, dysuria, or hematuria. He has not had any changes in medication, travel, or trauma. Past medical history includes benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), for which he takes tamsulosin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg, heart rate is 102 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The abdomen is distended, and there is suprapubic tenderness with palpation. A digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged, smooth, non-tender prostate without nodules. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral hydronephrosis and a distended bladder without evidence of renal parenchymal abnormalities. Laboratory results are shown below. Post-void residual bladder volume is 450 mL. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory test      Result     
 Sodium      138 mEq/L     
 Potassium      5.3 mEq/L     
 Serum creatinine      4.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL)     
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)      45 mg/dL     
 Urinalysis      Bland sediment

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute urinary retention (AUR) secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is a common cause of post-renal acute kidney injury (AKI). The initial step in treatment is bladder decompression by catheterization (either urethral or suprapubic).       

Acute management of acute kidney injury (AKI) begins with a rapid assessment to identify and address life-threatening conditions such as associated hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, volume overload, or symptomatic uremia, which may require emergent hemodialysis. ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Environment/Exposure) should be used to stabilize unstable patients, followed by establishing IV access and continuous monitoring.        

For stable patients, the priority is to identify the underlying cause of AKI through history, physical examination, and initial laboratory testing (e.g., serum creatinine, urinalysis with microscopy, and imaging). Management is then tailored to the underlying etiology, such as administering intravenous fluids for hypovolemia in prerenal AKI, avoiding nephrotoxic drugs in intrinsic AKI, and relieving obstruction (e.g. Foley catheter) in cases of post-renal AKI. Consultation with nephrology or urology may be required for complex or refractory cases or for patients with indications for hemodialysis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous fluids:
Incorrect: Intravenous fluids can help treat prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypovolemia; however, this patient’s AKI is post-renal, caused by obstruction from BPH. Administering fluids will not relieve the obstruction. 
✅ Bladder decompression with catheterization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Additional imaging is not required since the cause of obstruction has been identified as BPH based on history, physical exam, and ultrasound findings.  
❌ Alpha-blocker therapy:
Incorrect: Tamsulosin (an alpha-blocker) is a component of this patient’s chronic BPH management. Alpha-blockers do not provide immediate relief for acute urinary retention and are not a substitute for bladder decompression with a Foley catheter.  
❌ Urgent hemodialysis:
Incorrect: This patient does not currently have indications for emergent hemodialysis, such as life-threatening hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, or uremia. The acute kidney injury (AKI) is likely to improve once the obstruction is relieved.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to clinic with one week of fatigue, nausea, and a diffuse pruritic rash. She has no fever, chills, hematuria, dysuria, or significant changes in urinary frequency. Past medical history includes seasonal allergies and hypertension. She was recently prescribed amoxicillin for a sinus infection, which she started 10 days ago. She takes lisinopril for hypertension and loratadine as needed for allergies. She had not recently used non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), traveled, or been exposed to nephrotoxins. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg, heart rate is 84 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. A diffuse, erythematous, maculopapular rash is noted over the trunk and arms. There is no edema, jugular venous distension, or costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory results are shown below. Renal ultrasound shows normal kidney size without hydronephrosis. Which of the following would be expected on urinalysis with microscopy? 

 Laboratory test      Result     
 White blood cell count      13,000 g/dL        Differential:    Neutrophils 68%    Lymphocytes 24%    Eosinophils 8%     
 Sodium      138 mEq/L     
 Potassium      4.3 mEq/L     
 Serum creatinine      2.6 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL 2 months ago)     
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)      45 mg/dL     
 Urine culture      Negative
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation, including recent amoxicillin use, maculopapular rash, eosinophilia, and intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI) with a BUN-to-creatinine ratio <20:1, is consistent with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). The most likely finding on urinalysis with microscopy in patients with AIN is white blood cells without bacteria (i.e. sterile pyuria). Other findings on urinalysis with microscopy can include white blood cell casts, which reflect underlying tubular inflammation and interstitial immune cell infiltration, and eosinophils.        

The diagnostic workup for acute kidney injury (AKI) involves a combination of history, physical examination, laboratory testing, and imaging to determine the underlying cause. Initial testing includes assessing serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and electrolytes, along with calculating the BUN-to-creatinine ratio. This ratio helps differentiate prerenal AKI (BUN: creatinine >20:1) from intrinsic and postrenal causes. Urinalysis can identify key features such as proteinuria, hematuria, white blood cells, red blood cells, white blood cell casts, or muddy brown casts. Active urine sediment is most often seen with intrinsic causes of AKI like glomerulonephritis or acute tubular necrosis. Postrenal AKI is suggested by findings such as a distended bladder, decreased urine output, or hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound. Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is also helpful, with values <1% seen in prerenal AKI and >2%seen in intrinsic AKI.   

Option Analysis

❌ Dysmorphic red blood cells:
Incorrect: Dysmorphic red blood cells are specific for glomerular injury, such as glomerulonephritis, which is not supported by this patient’s clinical or lab findings. This patient with systemic symptoms including a rash and recent use of amoxicillin most likely has acute interstitial nephritis which is characterized by findings of sterile pyuria on urinalysis with microscopy (i.e. white blood cells without bacteria).
✅ White blood cells without bacteria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Muddy brown granular casts:
Incorrect: Muddy brown granular casts indicate acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This condition is typically caused by ischemia or nephrotoxins. This patient with systemic symptoms including a rash and recent use of amoxicillin most likely has acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) which is characterized by findings of sterile pyuria on urinalysis with microscopy (i.e. white blood cells without bacteria). 
❌ Hyaline casts:
Incorrect: Hyaline casts are nonspecific and often seen in patients with prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) due to low urine flow, but do not reflect the inflammation associated with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN).   
❌ Uric acid crystals:
Incorrect: Uric acid crystals are associated with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) or urate nephropathy, neither of which fits this clinical scenario.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with a history of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, confusion, and fever for one day. He was discharged 10 days ago after completing his third cycle of R-CHOP chemotherapy. Temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, heart rate is 112 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. The skin feels cool and clammy, and extremities are mottled. There are crackles throughout the lungs bilaterally. No jugular venous distension or peripheral edema is present. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is provided with supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula, and oxygen saturation improves to 94%. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  
 
 Laboratory value      Result    
 Hemoglobin     8 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     24 %    
 Leukocyte count     1,000/mm3    
 Platelet count     400,000/mm3

choices.text: Oral antibiotics and discharge with close follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient presents with neutropenic sepsis, which is a medical emergency that can occur in patients with hematologic malignancies, such as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, who are receiving chemotherapy. Neutropenic patients (leukocyte count < 1,500/mm³) are particularly susceptible to severe infections due to the lack of functional immune cells needed to defend against bacterial and fungal pathogens. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous fluids along with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics.

The acute management of a patient presenting with lymphoma and neutropenic sepsis begins with a rapid ABCDE (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) assessment to determine if the patient is stable or unstable. If the patient is unstable, immediate interventions should focus on stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation and may involve administration of intravenous fluids, oxygen, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Lymphoma patients receiving chemotherapy can become unstable for other reasons like tumor lysis syndrome (TLS), which requires aggressive hydration and electrolyte correction.

Option Analysis

❌ Oral antibiotics and discharge with close follow-up:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics and outpatient management is inappropriate management for a patient with neutropenic sepsis and septic shock.
✅ Intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous steroids:
Incorrect: Steroids are not indicated in this patient as there is no evidence of adrenal insufficiency or a condition such as septic shock refractory to fluids and vasopressors. Steroids could suppress his immune system even further and worsen his status. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest:
Incorrect: Imaging studies are necessary, but in this patient who is unstable with sepsis, immediate resuscitation with IV fluids and broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy takes precedence.
❌ Intravenous diuresis:
Incorrect: This patient is hypotensive due to septic shock and in need of fluid resuscitation. Diuretics would be indicated for patients with cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of a rapidly enlarging mass over the left side of his neck for the past month. He also reports increasing fatigue, night sweats and a 7-kg (15-lbs) unintentional weight loss over the 6 weeks. The patient has not experienced epigastric or abdominal pain, dyspepsia, or gastroesophageal reflux. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a 6 cm firm, non-tender lymph node over the left cervical region with additional palpable lymphadenopathy in the axillary and inguinal regions. A lymph node biopsy reveals large, atypical lymphoid cells with prominent nucleoli and basophilic cytoplasm and loss of lymph node architecture. Immunophenotyping shows CD19 and CD20 positivity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Gastric Marginal zone lymphoma of mucosa associated lymphoid tissue (MALT)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a rapidly enlarging lymph node, B symptoms (night sweats, weight loss), and biopsy findings of large, atypical B cells. These findings, in combination with CD19 and CD20 positivity, suggest diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), which is an aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Patients with DLBCL typically present with rapidly enlarging masses and systemic symptoms.

When evaluating a patient with suspected lymphoma, the first step is to obtain a thorough history and physical examination, focusing on B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss) and lymph node characteristics (painless, firm, non-tender). Initial laboratory tests should include a complete blood count (CBC), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level, and basic metabolic panel.

Definitive diagnosis requires a lymph node biopsy. If abnormal lymphoid cells are present and Hodgkin malignant/Reed-Sternberg cells are present, then the patient can be diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma. If abnormal lymphoid cells are present but Reed-Sternberg cells are absent, then non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) can be diagnosed. Immunophenotyping differentiates between B-cell and T-cell lymphomas and the specific subtypes of NHL, such as DLBCL (CD19, CD20 positive), mantle cell lymphoma, and follicular lymphoma. Imaging studies, such as CT or PET scans, are used to assess the extent of disease, while bone marrow biopsy may be needed to evaluate for bone marrow involvement.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma is identified by the presence of malignant Hodgkin/Reed-Sternberg cells (large, binucleated cells with prominent "owl's eye" nucleoli). It typically presents in young adults.  
✅ Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Follicular lymphoma:
Incorrect: Follicular lymphoma is the second most common subtype of NHL. It typically has an indolent course and patients have lymphadenopathy that waxes and wanes spontaneously over time rather than the rapidly growing lymphadenopathy seen in this case.
❌ Gastric Marginal zone lymphoma of mucosa associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) :
Incorrect: patients with Marginal zone lymphoma of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) tend to present with extra nodal involvement, commonly affecting the stomach, lung, or salivary glands. Patients with gastric MALT typically present with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease, epigastric pain or discomfort, anorexia, weight loss, or occult gastrointestinal bleeding. This patient has no GI symptoms.
❌ Mantle cell lymphoma:
Incorrect: Mantle cell lymphoma typically presents in older adults with widespread lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and gastrointestinal involvement. It can have a variable course. Typical findings on biopsy are small to intermediate-sized lymphoid cells and not the large cells seen in this case.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the primary care physician due to severe fatigue. The patient has had a mild sore throat, myalgias, and severe fatigue for the past two weeks. She reports that rest and ibuprofen have not alleviated the symptoms. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medication daily. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational substances. Temperature is 38.6 ºC (101.5 ºF), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 106/67 mmHg. A thorough physical examination is performed. Oropharyngeal exam shows swollen edematous tonsils bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Serum testing shows a positive heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This 17-year-old girl presents with two weeks of myalgias, sore throat, and severe fatigue with positive heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM testing confirming a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM). Splenomegaly is often seen in patients with infectious mononucleosis (IM) due to lymphocytic infiltration of the spleen.    

IM is a viral syndrome caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which spreads through saliva or respiratory secretions (often referred to as the “kissing disease” in young patients). After the virus enters the mouth, it infects oropharyngeal epithelial cells leading to sore throat, and B cells, which contribute to the presence of atypical lymphocytes seen on a peripheral smear.    

Patients generally present with fever, fatigue, myalgias, and sore throat. On physical examination, patients may have erythematous swollen tonsils, tonsillar exudates, and palatal petechiae. Posterior cervical chain lymphadenopathy is frequently present as well. In some cases, splenomegaly can be seen. Patients with splenomegaly should avoid strenuous exercise and contact sports for at least three weeks, due to the risk of splenic rupture.  



Option Analysis

✅ Splenomegaly :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Infraclavicular lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Infraclavicular lymphadenopathy is not specifically associated with infectious mononucleosis. Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, however, is a common feature. 
❌ Hepatomegaly:
Incorrect: Hepatomegaly can occur in patients with infectious mononucleosis in rare cases; however, splenomegaly is much more common, in up to 50% of infectious mononucleosis cases. 
❌ Arthritis:
Incorrect: While myalgias can be a prominent symptom of infectious mononucleosis, arthritis would not be an expected finding. Acute arthritis would suggest a different process (e.g., parvovirus B19). 
❌ Productive cough:
Incorrect: A dry cough can rarely be seen in patients with infectious mononucleosis due to pharyngeal irritation; however, a productive cough would not be expected.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for his yearly visit. The patient states he has been well since his last visit one year ago, and he has no new medical problems. The patient has a history of hypertension for which he takes amlodipine daily. He has no other significant medical or surgical history. He has no family history of colon cancer or coronary artery disease. He drinks 1-2 alcoholic beverages a week and lives with his partner with whom he is sexually active. He does approximately 30-60 minutes of moderate exercise daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 127/60 mmHg, heart rate is 82 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 23.7 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The patient is well appearing, and a full physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following additional historical elements, if present, would prompt further evaluation or treatment?

choices.text: History of normal colonoscopy 6 years ago
History of laceration repair and Tdap 7 years ago

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a well-patient geriatric care visit. A core component of this annual evaluation is a comprehensive history and physical exam. Patients with a history of tobacco smoking should be further evaluated regarding the need to screen for lung cancer with chest computed tomography (CT). Low dose CT-chest imaging is indicated for patients up to age 80 years old who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and are currently smoking or have quit smoking within the last 15 years.

The well-patient geriatric care visit for adults aged 65 years and older refers to an annual check-up that promotes physical, mental, and social health while building trust between the healthcare provider and patient. At each yearly visit, patients should have a comprehensive history and physical exam performed, followed by screening and counseling about a variety of topics, including substance use, mental health, functional status, and fall risk. All patients should be asked about past medical and surgical history, family and social history, sexual activity, medications, and diet and exercise habits. The physical examination should include height, weight, body mass index, vital signs, and a comprehensive physical examination. Additional screening and counseling should be provided based on individual risks and biological sex.   

Option Analysis

✅ History of daily tobacco smoking:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ History of travel to Europe:
Incorrect: Travel history is not typically a core component of a focused history for geriatric patients presenting for well-patient visits. High-risk patients, such as those who have recently immigrated from a country with increased prevalence of tuberculosis, should have a PPD placed. Travel to Europe is not considered high-risk.
❌ History of normal colonoscopy 6 years ago:
Incorrect: Patients who are at average risk for colon cancer like this patient should have a colonoscopy performed every 10 years. This patient is not due for another colonoscopy for 4 more years.
❌ History of laceration repair and Tdap 7 years ago:
Incorrect: Tdap should be given every 10 years. This patient is not yet due for another Tdap vaccination.  
❌ History of daily caffeine consumption:
Incorrect: Geriatric patients presenting for well health visits should be asked about tobacco alcohol and other recreational substance use. However, caffeine consumption is not typically considered a risk factor that needs targeted screening and interventions.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man presents to a new primary care physician for a routine wellness examination. The patient states he has been well since his last visit several years ago, and he has no new medical issues. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and diabetes for which he takes amlodipine, carvedilol, aspirin, clopidogrel, and metformin daily. He has no other significant medical or surgical history. There is no family history of colon cancer. He received all childhood vaccinations, and his last vaccine was a Tdap administered 6 years ago after he cut his index finger with a kitchen knife. The patient does not drink alcohol and smoked for 5 years when he was in his 30’s. He lives with his partner and has no issues performing activities of daily living. He has no sexual concerns and no urinary incontinence. He eats a diet of lean protein, fruits, vegetables, and healthy carbohydrates. The patient does approximately 30-60 minutes of light exercise daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 132/70 mmHg, heart rate is 76 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
