Body mass index (BMI) is 25 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The patient is well appearing, and a full physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Osteoporosis screening with dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan
Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a well-patient geriatric care visit. A core component of this annual evaluation is to determine the need for additional diagnostic evaluations, screenings, and immunizations based on patient age and risk factors. This patient has received childhood vaccinations and Tdap vaccination within 10 years. Given that he has never received the herpes zoster (shingles) vaccination, he should have it administered during this visit. This vaccine should be administered to all patients ≥ 50 years old.

At each well-patient geriatric visit, patients should undergo a comprehensive history and physical exam, followed by screening and counseling about a variety of topics, including recreational substance use, mental health, functional status, and fall risk. All patients should have their past medical and surgical history, family and social history, sexual activity, medications, and diet and exercise habits reviewed. Patients should have a physical examination, including height, weight, body mass index, and vital signs. These factors then help determine the need for further diagnostic screening and management. Geriatric patients may get yearly vaccinations for COVID-19, influenza, and RSV. Pneumococcal vaccination is recommended for all adults over 65 years old. Also, patients ≥ 50 who have not been vaccinated against herpes zosters (shingles) should be vaccinated. Adult patients should also receive a Tdap or Td vaccine every 10 years.

Option Analysis

✅ Herpes zoster (shingles) vaccination:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Stool-based testing for colon cancer:
Incorrect: Stool-based testing for colorectal cancer screening is not indicated for this patient given his age and average risk. This type of colorectal screening is only indicated for patients up to age 75. All adults between the ages of 45 and 75 should be screened for colorectal cancer. But in patients between the ages of 76 and 85, the decision should be made on a case-by-case basis.
❌ Tdap vaccination:
Incorrect: This patient received a Tdap vaccination within the last 10 years. Repeat vaccination is not indicated at this time.
❌ Osteoporosis screening with dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan:
Incorrect: Biological males are not routinely screened for osteoporosis; however, certain factors increase the risk of osteoporotic fractures, including long-term corticosteroid use, low BMI, active smoking, and excessive alcohol consumption. These factors are absent in this patient's history.
❌ Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging:
Incorrect: Low dose CT-chest imaging is indicated for patients up to age 80 who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and are currently smoking or have quit smoking within the last 15 years. This patient's history does not meet criteria for lung cancer screening.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine yearly visit. The patient has been well since her last visit without new concerns. She has a history of hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide and newly diagnosed Parkinson disease. The patient has not yet been seen by a neurologist and has an appointment scheduled for next week. The patient has no other significant medical or surgical history. The patient’s mother died of metastatic lung cancer, and the patient’s father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient drinks 1-2 alcoholic beverages each week, and she smoked one pack per day for 5 years when she was in her 40’s. She lives with her partner and has had several falls over the past six months. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 134/60 mmHg, heart rate is 80 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. BMI is 26.7 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The patient is well-appearing, and a full physical examination is unremarkable except for a pin rolling tremor and masked facies. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Addition of a second antihypertensive medication
Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a well-patient geriatric care visit. She has newly diagnosed Parkinson disease and is at increased risk for falls. The next best step in management is to address any concerns and provide supportive measures, such as referral to physical therapy services. Physical therapists can make assessments and provide appropriate exercise regimens for patients to reduce the risk of falls. Additional measures that may decrease the risk of falls include removing loose rugs, using non-slip mats, and ensuring proper lighting in the home.

Providers should regularly ask older patients about recent falls and fall risks because of the high incidence and potential for fracture and hospitalization. All patients who have fallen or who have limited mobility that increases their risk for falls should be asked about contributing factors, such as polypharmacy and unsafe home environments. Effective interventions include physical therapy, assistive devices, and a supervised exercise program.

Option Analysis

✅ Referral to physical therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transfer to rehabilitation facility:
Incorrect: This patient is not in need of inpatient rehabilitation at this time. Physical therapy can provide the necessary exercise program to help prevent falls.
❌ Addition of a second antihypertensive medication:
Incorrect: This patient has a mildly elevated blood pressure on hydrochlorothiazide. It would be more appropriate to perform serial blood pressure measurements prior to prescribing additional antihypertensive medications.
❌ Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging:
Incorrect: Low dose CT-chest imaging for lung cancer screening is indicated in patients up to age 80 who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and are currently smoking or have quit smoking within the last 15 years. This patient does not meet criteria for chest CT screening for lung cancer.
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Despite this patient's family history, a screening abdominal ultrasound for aortic aneurysm is not indicated. Screening for abdominal aortic ultrasound is indicated for biological males with a tobacco history who are between the ages of 65 and 75.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of fever, body aches, headache, and chills since returning to the United States two days ago. The patient is a medical student who is returning from Ecuador where she was pursuing a medical Spanish elective in the Amazon rainforest. The patient ate the local food and drank water from a tap. She was bitten by multiple mosquitos during her elective. The patient has no past medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 113/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. No rash is present. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination are within normal limits. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient who recently returned from a tropical region presents with fever, headache, myalgias, and chills. The peripheral blood smear reveals visible plasmodium parasites, confirming the diagnosis of malaria. Malaria is the most common life-threatening tropical disease associated with fever in returned travelers, particularly from regions such as South America, Africa, and Asia.

All patients returning from travel with a fever should be presumed to have an endemic illness from the country where they traveled. The differential diagnosis is then formulated based on travel history, symptoms, and physical exam features, including the presence or absence of a rash. Further confirmatory testing may then be necessary to make a diagnosis, which can be achieved via a variety of modalities, including nucleic amplification testing, serology, or stool/blood culture. Malaria can be diagnosed by microscopic analysis of the blood showing visible plasmodium parasites or by using parasite-specific NAAT of the serum.

Option Analysis

✅ Malaria :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ African sleeping sickness:
Incorrect: Patients with African sleeping sickness may have fever and headaches; however, microscopic analysis of blood will show elongated slender trypanosomes. The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.
❌ Rocky Mountain spotted fever:
Incorrect: Patients with Rocky Mountain spotted fever typically present with a diffuse petechial rash, and diagnosis can be made with serologic testing. The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.
❌ Japanese encephalitis:
Incorrect: Japanese encephalitis typically presents with neurologic findings and a history of recent travel to Asia. Diagnosis is made with the presence of serum or cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) IgM antibodies. The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.
❌ Yellow fever:
Incorrect: Patients with yellow fever typically present with jaundice and bleeding. The disease is caused by a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes or Haemagogus mosquitoes. It is diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT). The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic for an annual well-patient care visit. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She works as a marketing manager and reports a moderate amount of work-related stress over the past several months. She shares that she has had a challenging time concentrating at work lately. She does not smoke or use alcohol or other recreational substances. She exercises once a week and tries to maintain a healthy diet. During the review of systems, she mentions that she has been feeling more fatigued recently. She has not had recent weight loss or weight gain. She does not experience cold or heat intolerance. She has not experienced constipation or diarrhea. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Referral to a psychiatrist for further evaluation

questions.solution:
Depression is often underdiagnosed, and patients may have subtle symptoms; therefore, all patients should be screened for depression at the well-patient visit. The PHQ-9 (Patient Health Questionnaire-9) is a widely used tool to screen for depression in primary care settings and should be utilized for this patient. Additionally, this patient describes symptoms of fatigue and inability to concentrate, which can be signs of depression.       

A detailed medical history that includes questions about the patient’s diet, exercise habits, and sexual activity should be part of all well-patient visits for adults. Patients should be counseled regarding lifestyle factors, and all patients should be screened for alcohol, tobacco, and recreational substance use since these are preventable causes of morbidity and mortality. Validated questionnaires exist to screen for these conditions. All patients should be asked about interpersonal relationships and domestic violence, in addition to screening for polypharmacy and appropriate medication use. All adult patients should be screened for Hepatitis C and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).        

The physical examination should assess vital signs, including blood pressure and body mass index (BMI) to screen for hypertension and obesity. A thorough cardiovascular, respiratory, and abdominal examination should be performed. Age-appropriate cancer screening and cancer screening based on the patient’s biological sex should be performed. Immunization status should be reviewed and vaccines administered if necessary. Further screening should be performed based on whether patients are at elevated risk for certain diseases and age.   

Option Analysis

❌ Referral to a psychiatrist for further evaluation:
Incorrect: While referral to a psychiatrist may be necessary if significant depressive symptoms are found, the first step is to screen for depression using a tool like the PHQ-9 before considering specialist referral.
✅ Administration of PHQ-9 questionnaire:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reassurance and follow-up in 6 months:
Incorrect: All patients should be screened for depression at the well-patient care visit. Additionally, given the patient's symptoms, reassurance without further evaluation would be inadequate. Screening for depression should be performed. 
❌ Thyroid function testing:
Incorrect: Although hypothyroidism can cause fatigue and cognitive difficulties, the absence of other classic symptoms such as weight gain and cold intolerance makes depression more likely in this case. Screening for depression should take precedence.  
❌ Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT):
Incorrect: CBT is an effective treatment for depression, but initiating therapy without first screening and diagnosing the condition would be premature. Administering the PHQ-9 is the best next step in management.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset hematuria and left flank pain. The patient has a history of recurrent kidney stones and states these symptoms feel similar. One year ago, her right kidney was removed due to injuries sustained in a motor vehicle accident. The patient does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 190/87 mmHg, heart rate is 88 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and in mild distress. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The patient has left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness, and the rest of the abdominal examination is unremarkable. Initial laboratory studies and a urinalysis are shown below. Post-void residual (PVR) is <100 mL. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 1 cm stone at the left ureteropelvic junction with upstream hydronephrosis; the right kidney is absent. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Sodium      140 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride     97 mEq/L    
 BUN     47 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      2.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.3 mg/dL six months ago)    
 Albumin      3.2 g/dL    
 Urinalysis    
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Blood     Positive        
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative        
 Nitrites     Negative        
 Leukocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     100/hpf    
 Casts     None

choices.text: Urology consultation for ureteral stent placement

questions.solution:
This patient has a single functioning kidney and presents with laboratory evidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) and obstructive nephrolithiasis on CT imaging. Given the stone size and the AKI, the next step is to consult urology for ureteral stent placement, lithotripsy, or surgical stone removal.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) refers to a sudden decline in kidney function that leads to electrolyte imbalances, extracellular dysregulation, and accumulation of nitrogenous wastes such as ammonia and uric acid. Postrenal AKI occurs when urinary flow is blocked anywhere in the urinary tract, whether in the upper tract (i.e. ureters) or the lower tract (i.e. bladder or urethra). In cases of nephrolithiasis, obstruction must typically involve both kidneys to cause AKI unless only one functioning kidney remains, as in this case.

Management of postrenal AKI depends on the cause and location of the obstruction. In general, an upper urinary tract obstruction (e.g., obstructive nephrolithiasis, malignancy, external compression) can be managed with ureteral stent placement to bypass the obstruction, lithotripsy to fragment an obstructing stone, or surgery. Lower urinary tract obstruction is managed first with catheterization and then by addressing the underlying condition (e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia, bladder tumor).

Option Analysis

✅ Urology consultation for ureteral stent placement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supportive measures only:
Incorrect: Supportive measures alone (e.g., intravenous fluids, analgesia, and medical expulsive therapy) would be insufficient in a patient with a solitary kidney and a large obstructing ureteropelvic junction stone resulting in postrenal acute kidney injury. Urology consultation for decompression is required.
❌ Foley catheter placement:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of obstructive nephrolithiasis causing postrenal acute kidney injury. Foley catheter placement is not indicated given the obstruction is in the upper urinary tract. Instead, urology consultation for decompression is required.
❌ Intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics would be indicated if this patient were to have evidence of an associated urinary tract infection. This patient's urinalysis is only notable for blood, as expected with a large kidney stone. Instead, urology consultation for decompression is required.
❌ Suprapubic catheter placement:
Incorrect: A suprapubic catheter is used for lower urinary tract obstruction or urinary retention after a failed Foley catheter placement; it would not relieve an upper tract obstruction due to nephrolithiasis. Instead, urology consultation for decompression is required.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past several weeks. There is associated fatigue, anorexia, and an unintentional weight loss of 4.1 kg (9 lbs). Past medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft and nondistended, with mild diffuse tenderness to palpation and no guarding. There are multiple tender, erythematous nodules on the patient’s shins bilaterally. Laboratory studies show anemia, leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. Stool studies are negative for infectious organisms. Which of the following is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Order CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast
Order magnetic resonance imaging with small bowel enterography

questions.solution:
Crohn disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the GI tract (from the mouth to the anus). It typically presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. It is characterized by transmural inflammation and most commonly affects the ileum.  

It can be difficult to differentiate IBD from other diagnoses with similar presentations. Fecal calprotectin is a marker of colon inflammation. Since irritable bowel syndrome does not cause colon inflammation, a positive fecal calprotectin would increase the suspicion for IBD. Negative stool PCR or culture rules out infectious etiologies such as C. difficile, E. coli, Yersinia, and other infections. In patients with new or uncontrolled IBD, serum studies often demonstrate anemia, volume depletion, malnutrition, and elevated inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP.  

If the clinical findings and laboratory workup suggests IBD, the next step is to confirm the diagnosis with ileocolonoscopy with biopsy. In Crohn disease, biopsy samples from affected areas can show the characteristic transmural inflammation and non-caseating granulomas. Patients with suspected Crohn disease can also undergo magnetic resonance enterography (MRE) to evaluate the small bowel. MRE can reveal complications such as strictures, fistulas, and mesenteric fibrofatty proliferation (also called creeping fat).  

Mild-moderate Crohn disease presents with symptoms that minimally affect a patient’s quality of life and without any systemic signs or symptoms or significant weight loss. Moderate-severe Crohn disease presents with significant clinical symptoms (e.g., fever, severe pain, weight loss) and abnormal serum laboratory studies. Severe-fulminant Crohn disease presents with severe malnutrition (e.g. cachexia) or complications such as bowel obstruction or peritonitis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform ileocolonoscopy with biopsies   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Order CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast   :
Incorrect: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast may be helpful for evaluating for complications of Crohn disease – such as abscesses, fistulae, and strictures – but is not the best next step in the diagnostic workup of this patient.   
❌ Measure serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA)   :
Incorrect: Serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies levels and fecal calprotectin assay may aid in making the diagnosis of Crohn disease and ruling out other diagnoses, but they are not specific and should not be relied on as diagnostic tests.   
❌ Perform a fecal calprotectin assay   :
Incorrect: Serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies levels and fecal calprotectin assay may aid in making the diagnosis of Crohn disease, but they are not specific and should not be relied on as diagnostic tests.   
❌ Order magnetic resonance imaging with small bowel enterography   :
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance imaging with small bowel enterography (MRE) is useful for identifying areas of involvement in the small bowel and can be part of the diagnostic workup when Crohn disease is found on ileocolonoscopy, but is much less sensitive than colonoscopy with biopsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic due to diarrhea for the past several weeks. There is no associated fatigue, anorexia, or unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable only for mild diffuse abdominal tenderness. Stool studies are negative for infectious organisms. Bloodwork shows mild anemia. An ileocolonoscopy is performed, and biopsies of the colon and terminal ileum are obtained. Pathology shows transmural inflammation and non-caseating granulomas isolated to the ileum. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication for treating this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Once the diagnosis of Crohn disease is confirmed, the severity should be determined based on signs and symptoms such as abdominal pain, presence of bloody diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, anemia, presence of complications, and how much Crohn disease impacts the patient’s quality of life. Treatment is based on severity and the location of involvement within the gastrointestinal tract.  The goal of treatment is to use induction therapy to induce a remission. Once remission is achieved with treatment, a colonoscopy extending to the ileum (ileocolonoscopy) should be repeated in 6-12 months.  

Mild-moderate Crohn disease presents with symptoms that minimally affect a patient’s quality of life. Patients typically do not have nausea, vomiting, or fever. Serum laboratory studies do not typically show anemia, dehydration, or malnutrition, and imaging does not show complications. Budesonide is a steroid that is used for induction of remission in patients with mild-moderate Crohn disease with ileocecal involvement, the most common site of involvement in Crohn disease. For patients with predominantly colonic involvement and mild-moderate Crohn disease, an oral 5-aminosalicylate medication should be given (e.g., sulfasalazine).  

Moderate-severe Crohn disease presents with significant clinical symptoms (e.g., fever, severe pain, weight loss) and abnormal serum laboratory studies. This category also includes patients who have failed treatment of mild-moderate Crohn disease. Treatment involves induction therapy with systemic corticosteroids followed by monoclonal antibodies, or immunomodulators (e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine).  

Severe-fulminant Crohn disease presents with severe malnutrition (i.e. cachexia) or complications such as bowel obstruction or peritonitis. Treatment also involves induction therapy with systemic corticosteroids followed by monoclonal antibodies or immunomodulators (e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine). These patients are at high risk for requiring surgical interventions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Oral budesonide   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ IV corticosteroids   :
Incorrect: This patient’s Crohn disease would be considered mild given that there are no constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, fatigue). This patient does not meet criteria for hospital admission for IV corticosteroids.   
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is generally reserved for patients with moderate-severe Crohn disease who have failed to respond to other therapies. It is typically used as a second-line or third-line therapy after corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive agents have been tried.   
❌ Ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic that can be used to treat infections in the gastrointestinal tract, but is not effective for the treatment of Crohn disease.   
❌ Sulfasalazine:
Incorrect: Sulfasalazine is typically used to treat mild-moderate Crohn disease that is limited to the colon. This patient only has ileocecal involvement without colon involvement.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is seen in the emergency department for three days of profuse watery diarrhea, nausea, and weakness. The patient has not eaten in two days. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease and a recent dental infection. Current medications include famotidine, omeprazole, and a recently finished 10-day course of clindamycin. Temperature is 39.3 ºC (102.7 ºF), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and SpO2 is 99% on room air. Blood pressure is 78/41 mmHg after infusion of 2 liters of 0.9% sodium chloride. The patient’s abdomen is rigid with hypoactive bowel sounds. Serum white blood cell count is 28,000/mL, serum creatinine is 2.6 mg/dL, and lactic acid is 3.8 mmol/L. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fulminant C. difficile infection (CDI) given evidence of circulatory shock. While this patient will require stool studies to detect C. difficile toxin, his risk factors (i.e. use of famotidine and omeprazole and recent antibiotic use) and watery diarrhea make this diagnosis extremely likely. Oral (or rectal) vancomycin and IV metronidazole should be started immediately.  

This patient’s abdominal examination is concerning for peritonitis, and an emergent computed tomography of the abdomen is the next best step to evaluate for toxic megacolon or colonic perforation. After the patient is stabilized, it may be appropriate to initiate total parenteral nutrition.  

If this patient did not have shock or signs of peritonitis, his disease would instead be classified as severe CDI (serum creatinine mg/dL ≥ 1.5 OR serum white blood cells > 15,000/mL). Patients have non-severe CDI if serum creatinine mg/dL < 1.5 AND serum white blood cells ≤ 15,000/mL.  

Diagnosis of CDI can be confirmed with glutamate dehydrogenase antigen testing, and C. difficile toxins A and B sent on stool samples. If both tests are negative it rules out CDI, and if both tests are positive it confirms CDI. If one test is negative and the other is positive the results are inconclusive, and nucleic acid amplification testing, or NAAT, should be sent. A positive NAAT test confirms CDI.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer oral metronidazole  :
Incorrect: Oral metronidazole should only be used for non-severe Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). This patient likely has fulminant CDI.
❌ Repeat lactic acid level  :
Incorrect: This patient’s fever, leukocytosis, acute kidney injury, and shock point toward a fulminant infection. Assessing for life-threatening complications with abdominal imaging should take precedence.
✅ Computed tomography of abdomen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiate droplet precautions  :
Incorrect: Clostridioides difficile is spread via the fecal-oral route, so only contact isolation is required to prevent spread.  
❌ Initiate total parenteral nutrition  :
Incorrect: While patients with severe or fulminant Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) may require TPN during their hospitalization, it is not appropriate to initiate this in the acute setting.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with four days of watery stools and diffuse abdominal pain. The patient has been treated three times for Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) with courses of oral vancomycin and oral fidaxomicin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam shows minimal lower abdominal tenderness to palpation. Stool testing is positive for C. difficile toxin and glutamate dehydrogenase antigen. Computed tomography of the abdomen shows mild inflammatory changes of the colon without sign of bowel dilatation, perforation, or free air. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fourth episode of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). Fulminant CDI (as evidenced by shock, ileus, or megacolon) requires oral vancomycin, IV metronidazole, and abdominal imaging. For non-fulminant CDI, initial occurrences can be treated with oral vancomycin, oral fidaxomicin, or oral metronidazole. Recurrences of CDI should be treated with oral vancomycin or oral fidaxomicin, with fidaxomicin being the preferred agent. Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against C. difficile toxin B and can be used in patients with three or more episodes (two or more recurrences).  

Patients with three or more episodes of CDI (two or more recurrences) should be evaluated for fecal microbiota transplant (FMT). Stool samples are collected from healthy donors and tested extensively. These stool samples are then placed into the intestinal tract of patients with recurrent CDI to repopulate the patient’s normal healthy intestinal flora. This can be accomplished via an oral capsule or by intra-colonic delivery via colonoscopy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Surgical consultation  :
Incorrect: This patient has minimal tenderness to palpation and no concerning findings on abdominal imaging. Surgical consultation would be indicated in patients with complications such as toxic megacolon or colonic perforation.  
✅ Fecal microbiota transplantation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral vancomycin  :
Incorrect: This patient has developed recurrent C. difficile infection despite oral vancomycin and oral fidaxomicin. The next best step is fecal microbiota transplantation.  
❌ Oral metronidazole  :
Incorrect: Vancomycin and fidaxomicin are more effective than metronidazole for severe and recurrent C. difficile infection.  
❌ IV vancomycin  :
Incorrect: IV vancomycin is not used to treat C. difficile infection. Oral vancomycin is poorly absorbed through the GI tract thus increasing the concentration in the intestines, making it ideal for treating C. difficile.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with acute pancreatitis is admitted to the hospital. She is given intravenous fluid resuscitation and pain control. The patient’s hospital course is complicated by acute respiratory distress syndrome on day 2 requiring mechanical ventilation. She clinically improves over the next few days and is gradually weaned off the ventilator. However, on day 6 of her hospital stay, ventilator settings are increased to optimize oxygenation. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on 60% FiO2 with a positive end-expiratory pressure of 8 cm H2O. On physical examination, rales are noted throughout the lungs and are significantly louder over the right lower lung field. A point-of-care ultrasound reveals a new subpleural consolidation and dynamic air bronchograms in the right lower lobe, along with findings consistent with ARDS in other lobes. Purulent secretions are obtained from the endotracheal tube. The prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus at this hospital is unknown. The patient should be started on which of the following antibiotic regimens?
questions.solution:
The patient develops a fever, tachycardia, worsening hypoxia, purulent secretions, and prominent rales over the right lower lung field. Given the patient has required mechanical ventilation for more than 48 hours, these findings are concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). This diagnosis is confirmed with point-of-care ultrasound demonstrating consolidation and air bronchograms over the right lower lobe of the lung.

Once VAP is suspected, empiric antibiotics should be initiated. Overall, management for VAP and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is similar and requires assessment of the patient’s risk for multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Risk factors for MDR pathogens include IV antibiotics within the preceding 90 days, hospital stay ≥ 5 days, need for acute renal replacement therapy, ARDS prior to VAP, and septic shock at the time of VAP.

The decision regarding MRSA coverage depends on the prevalence of MRSA at the hospital. Coverage is only required if there is high or unknown prevalence. When results from sputum testing become available, the antibiotic regimen can then be adjusted based on these findings.

If no risk factors for MRSA or MDR pathogens are present, then antibiotic monotherapy is typically sufficient. However, this patient has several risk factors for MDR pathogens (e.g., prolonged hospital stay, ARDS, sepsis). Additionally, the prevalence of MRSA is unknown. Therefore, it is important to initiate an antipseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic, a non-beta-lactam antibiotic, and MRSA coverage. In this scenario, the best answer choice is cefepime, levofloxacin, and vancomycin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vancomycin, cefepime, and levofloxacin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: This patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia and has multiple risk factors for multidrug-resistant pathogens (e.g., prolonged hospital stay, ARDS, sepsis). Additionally, the prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is unknown, thus requiring empiric coverage. Piperacillin-tazobactam alone is a more appropriate choice when there are no multidrug-resistant pathogen risk factors and MRSA prevalence is known to be low.  
❌ Ceftriaxone and azithromycin:
Incorrect: This patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia. Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin would be more appropriate for an individual admitted to the hospital for high-risk community-acquired pneumonia.  
❌ Levofloxacin and cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia and has multiple risk factors for multidrug-resistant pathogens (e.g., prolonged hospital stay, ARDS, sepsis). Additionally, the prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is unknown, thus requiring empiric coverage. While levofloxacin and cefepime do provide adequate coverage for most relevant multidrug-resistant pathogens, they do not provide adequate coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Vancomycin and cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia and has multiple risk factors for multidrug-resistant pathogens (e.g., prolonged hospital stay, ARDS, sepsis). Additionally, the prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is unknown, thus requiring empiric coverage. Vancomycin and cefepime do not adequately cover the multidrug-resistant pathogens.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to chest pain with inspiration, shortness of breath, and a cough productive of yellow sputum. His symptoms developed two days prior and have progressively worsened. The patient was in good health prior to returning from an overseas trip to Europe five days ago. Medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease. Temperature is 39.2 °C (102.6 °F), blood pressure is 125/81 mmHg, pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination is notable for decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung. Which of the following would be most helpful for confirming this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: Frontal and lateral view chest radiographs

questions.solution:
This patient presents with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and a productive cough. Vital signs are notable for fever, tachypnea, and decreased oxygen saturation. Lung exam is significant for decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. In combination, these findings are most suggestive of community-acquired pneumonia. Chest radiography, ideally both frontal and lateral views, would be most helpful for confirming the patient’s condition.  

Pneumonia is an infection of the lung parenchyma that results in inflammation of one or both lungs. The diagnosis is made based on a combination of the history, physical examination, and laboratory studies. It is typically confirmed with chest imaging. Laboratory studies such as a complete blood count and arterial blood gas are often ordered. For imaging, chest radiography is the first-line modality. A CT scan of the chest can be obtained if there is strong clinical suspicion for pneumonia but the chest radiograph is negative.  

Once a diagnosis has been made, patients should be started on empiric antibiotics. This is typically a beta-lactam plus a macrolide, though a macrolide, doxycycline, or amoxicillin alone can be used in certain patients with mild CAP. Supplemental oxygen should be given to maintain oxygen saturation levels above 92%.  

Option Analysis

✅ Frontal and lateral view chest radiographs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CT angiography of the chest:
Incorrect: A pulmonary embolism can present with dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. The condition can be diagnosed with a CT angiography of the chest. However, a pulmonary embolism is less likely to cause fever and would not cause a productive cough and decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung.
❌ Quantiferon gold assay:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical history and physical examination findings are most concerning for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient lacks symptoms such as hemoptysis, weight loss, or night sweats suggestive of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. As a result, a Quantiferon gold assay would not be helpful in diagnosing this patient’s condition.
❌ Sputum culture and Gram stain:
Incorrect: Sputum culture and Gram staining can identify the underlying pathogen causing pneumonia, which can help narrow the spectrum of antibiotic coverage. However, it may take several days before these results are available and they may not be of adequate quality. Chest radiographs would be much faster for confirming pneumonia and indicating the need to start empiric antibiotic treatment.
❌ Serum alpha-fetoprotein levels:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has community-acquired pneumonia. Serum alpha-fetoprotein levels do not play a role in the work-up of this infection. They would more likely be checked in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma or testicular cancer.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of five episodes of vomiting up blood. Past medical history is significant for hepatitis C infection. The patient never completed antiviral treatment. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows jaundiced skin and icteric sclerae. The patient is noted to have an episode of hematemesis while in the emergency department. Two large bore peripheral IVs are placed, and the patient is started on IV fluids. The initial laboratory evaluation is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Schedule the patient for emergent upper endoscopy
Start the patient on a non-selective beta blocker

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with active upper gastrointestinal bleeding. After initial stabilization of the patient by securing airway, breathing, and circulation; the best next step is to perform an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to confirm the diagnosis. If there are actively bleeding varices on EGD, the diagnosis of gastroesophageal varices is confirmed.

In a stable patient with suspected bleeding from gastroesophageal varices, focused history and physical examination should be performed followed by laboratory evaluation including complete blood count (CBC) and comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) to assess liver function, as well as PT, PTT, and INR. Labs might reveal anemia; thrombocytopenia; low albumin; possibly elevated ALT, AST, and indirect bilirubin; as well as elevated PT, PTT, and INR. These findings suggest cirrhosis. In such cases, imaging (including ultrasound, CT, or MRI) and a possible biopsy should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. Patients with gastroesophageal varices confirmed on EGD and underlying cirrhosis have cirrhotic portal hypertension.

In cases where the patient history reveals malignancy, vascular disease, systemic infiltrative disease, or a hypercoagulable state and physical exam shows splenomegaly; a doppler ultrasound to assess portal vein flow should be performed to rule out underlying portal vein thrombosis as the cause of the gastroesophageal varices. Patients with portal vein compression or thrombosis on ultrasound are diagnosed with non-cirrhotic portal hypertension.

Once the underlying etiology is confirmed in stable patients, an EGD can be performed to assess the size and condition of varices and to determine treatment.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain doppler ultrasound of abdomen:
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound of the abdomen should be obtained in patients with suspected portal vein thrombosis which can lead to gastroesophageal varices. History might reveal underlying malignancy, vascular disease, systemic infiltrative disease, or a hypercoagulable state. Physical examination might show splenomegaly. Regardless of the underlying etiology, this patient’s current presentation warrants an emergent endoscopy for an active upper GI bleed.  
❌ Obtain liver biopsy:
Incorrect: Liver biopsy is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of cirrhosis. Biopsy will show nodularity and fibrosis. Cirrhosis can lead to portal hypertension and formation of esophageal varices. Regardless of the cause of the upper GI bleed, this patient’s current presentation warrants an emergent endoscopy.  
✅ Schedule the patient for emergent upper endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start the patient on a non-selective beta blocker  :
Incorrect: Non-selective beta blockers, such as propranolol, are indicated in the management of medium and large sized non-bleeding varices. Upper endoscopy is needed first to determine the choice of treatment in this patient with likely gastroesophageal varices.  
❌ Perform transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt:
Incorrect: A transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt may be placed for patients with actively bleeding varices (especially gastric) who fail first-line methods of hemostasis or who have initial hemostasis but then rebleed within 120 hours of initial hemorrhage. To determine the choice of treatment, an upper endoscopy should be performed first.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dizziness and black tarry stools for the past week. Past medical history is significant for chronic alcohol use. The patient has not experienced similar symptoms before. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination is significant for conjunctival pallor. After initial stabilization, the patient undergoes esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) which shows two medium sized esophageal varices with red signs. No actively bleeding varices or ulcers were seen during the procedure. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Refer for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an upper GI bleed due to esophageal varices diagnosed on EGD. Small varices (≤5 millimeters) do not require any treatment and warrant repeat EGD in 2-3 years to reassess.

Patients with medium and large varices with red signs(red patches or strips and cherry red spots) usually require treatment with a non-selective beta blocker, like nadolol or propranolol, to decrease the risk of future bleeding. A transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) can be performed by interventional radiology and should also be considered. During a TIPS procedure, the portal vein is connected directly to the hepatic vein, which allows blood to bypass the liver, decreasing portal vein pressure. Alternatively, portacaval shunt surgery can bypass the liver by creating a connection between the portal vein and the inferior vena cava. Patients may need to be referred for transplant evaluation, especially if their Model for End-Stage Disease (MELD) score is ≥14.

Patients with actively bleeding varices found on EGD should be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and splanchnic vasoconstrictors like octreotide. Those with vitamin K deficiency should receive vitamin K and blood transfusion if hemoglobin is <7 g/dL. During EGD, endoscopic band ligation and sclerotherapy can be performed to eradicate varices. Other options include variceal coiling or embolization, TIPS procedure, or portocaval shunt surgery. EGD should be repeated in 2-3 weeks to assess if the bleeding has completely resolved, persisted, or recurred.  

Option Analysis

❌ Repeat EGD in 2-3 years:
Incorrect: Repeat EGD in 2-3 years is recommended in patients with small varices that are 5 millimeters or less in size that do not require any treatment. This patient has medium sized varices with red signs and requires further treatment.  
❌ Refer for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS):
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt can be placed in patients with actively bleeding esophageal varices who fail first-line treatment with endoscopic variceal ligation and/or beta blocker therapy. The esophageal varices in this patient are a new finding and should be treated with first-line therapies before considering TIPS.  
✅ Start propranolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Refer for transplant evaluation:
Incorrect: Liver transplant is indicated in some patients with cirrhosis. This patient can be referred for transplant evaluation after starting initial treatment for esophageal varices.  
❌ Repeat EGD in 2 weeks:
Incorrect: EGD should be repeated in 2-3 weeks in patients who are found to have actively bleeding varices on initial EGD to assess if the bleeding completely resolved, has persisted, or has recurred.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents to the primary care office due to two months of intermittent moderate abdominal pain and bloating. The pain occurs around the xiphoid process. It is burning in quality and comes and goes throughout the day. It improves when the patient drinks milk and often worsens after eating spicy food. The patient also noticed a small amount of bright red blood on the toilet paper after having a bowel movement yesterday. The patient drinks two beers per day, rarely exercises, and has not made any dietary changes in the last several years. He has noticed that his clothing has been fitting much more loosely over the past few months. On physical examination, there is mild epigastric tenderness to palpation. Peptic ulcer disease is suspected. Which of the following features of this patient’s history is most concerning?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has peptic ulcer disease (PUD), as evidenced by burning epigastric pain and bloating. PUD may occur in the stomach or duodenum. Patients should be asked about the location and quality of the pain, and if it is intermittent or constant. Patients should also be asked about any signs of bleeding (e.g., hematemesis, hematochezia, melena) since ulcers can cause gastrointestinal bleeding.

Gastric ulcers can become malignant. Therefore, patients should be questioned about the presence of signs and symptoms associated with gastric cancer including unintentional weight loss (e.g. change in clothing size), dysphagia, nausea, and early satiety.

History should also focus on risk factors for PUD. Medications such as NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) and corticosteroids can damage the gastric lining. While COX-2-selective NSAIDs (e.g., celecoxib, meloxicam) have a lower risk of this side effect, they can still damage the gastric lining. Tobacco and alcohol use increase the risk of PUD. A prior history of Helicobacter pylori infection or recurrent peptic ulcers raises suspicion for infection by this pathogen.

Physical examination for patients with PUD should focus on assessing the location and severity of pain via palpation. Patients with hypotension, signs of peritonitis, or severe tenderness to palpation should be evaluated emergently for viscus perforation. If gastrointestinal bleeding is suspected, a digital rectal exam may be helpful.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blood after bowel movement:
Incorrect: While bleeding may occur with peptic ulcer disease, a small amount of bright red blood when wiping is likely due to another etiology (e.g., anal fissure, hemorrhoids). Concerning features with regards to PUD-associated bleeding would be melena, hematemesis, or severe hematochezia.  
❌ Current alcohol use:
Incorrect: While alcohol and tobacco use increase the risk of peptic ulcer disease, the patient’s unintentional weight loss is much more concerning with regard to peptic ulcer disease and its association with gastric cancer.  
❌ Age of 51 years old:
Incorrect: In patients aged 60 years or older, new onset of dyspepsia (e.g., bloating, abdominal pain, early satiety) is concerning for malignancy. Since this patient is 51 years old, dyspepsia alone would not be considered an “alarming feature”.  
✅ Unintentional weight loss:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intermittent moderate abdominal pain:
Incorrect: Severe constant pain may indicate complicated peptic ulcer disease (e.g. perforated viscus, gastrointestinal bleed). In contrast, this patient’s pain is intermittent and is associated with only moderate pain.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to one week of moderate abdominal pain, bloating, and frequent belching. The pain fluctuates in severity and lessens after eating. The patient also passes one or two black-colored bowel movements per month. Past medical history is significant for bilateral knee osteoarthritis. The patient takes naproxen once per week for arthritis pain as well as an over-the-counter iron supplement three times daily. Temperature is 36.7ºC (98.1ºF), pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 145/89 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. Serum hemoglobin is within normal limits and is unchanged from values obtained two years ago. On physical examination, the epigastrium is mildly tender to palpation. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography of abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient likely has peptic ulcer disease (PUD), as evidenced by the burning epigastric pain, belching, and bloating. PUD may occur in the stomach or duodenum. PUD is generally caused by medications that erode the gastric lining (e.g., NSAIDs, corticosteroids) or by Helicobacter pylori, a Gram-negative bacterium. Rarer causes include high gastric acid-producing states such as stomach cancer or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Patients should first be assessed for hemodynamic stability. If patients are unstable or have high-risk features (e.g., melena, severe and constant abdominal pain) then emergent upper endoscopy should be performed. If there is concern for peritonitis or perforated viscus, then emergent CT imaging of the abdomen should be considered.

For hemodynamically stable patients suspected of having PUD, Helicobacter pylori testing should be performed first. In patients older than 60 years old or those with features concerning for malignancy (e.g., unintentional weight loss), upper endoscopy should be the first step with gastric or duodenal biopsies sent for H. pylori testing. In patients without these features, H. pylori testing should be done via stool antigen testing or urea breath testing. If test results are positive, patients should be treated with 14 days of amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and a proton pump inhibitor. They will then require proof of eradication via repeat testing. If H. pylori testing is negative, common etiologies such as NSAID-induced PUD should be investigated. If no obvious causes are found, rarer etiologies such as MEN1 syndrome, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, or substance abuse should be considered.  

Option Analysis

❌ Emergent upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: If this patient had signs of severe gastrointestinal bleeding, hemodynamic instability, severe constant pain, or features very concerning for malignancy (e.g. age ≥ 60 years old, significant tobacco use), then an upper endoscopy would be appropriate. However, in this case, Helicobacter pylori testing would be a more appropriate first step.  
✅ Testing for Helicobacter pylori infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Change naproxen to celecoxib:
Incorrect: Celecoxib is COX-2-selective and causes less gastrointestinal irritation. As a result, it would be reasonable to switch this patient from naproxen to celecoxib if long-term NSAID therapy is indicated. However, at this point it would be more appropriate to hold any NSAIDs if possible and pursue further testing to rule out Helicobacter pylori infection.  
❌ Computed tomography of abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical history is concerning for peptic ulcer disease. While further workup may be required, it would not include CT imaging. However, if the patent has findings concerning for peritonitis and/or perforated viscus associated with peptic ulcer disease, then CT imaging would be indicated.  
❌ Serum gastrin level measurement:
Incorrect: States of severely elevated gastrin levels (e.g. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) are rare and workup should only be pursued after more common causes of PUD (e.g. NSAID use, Helicobacter pylori infection) are ruled out.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of chest pain and vomiting coffee-ground colored material. The patient has had heartburn, food regurgitation, and occasional dysphagia for the past five months. Over-the-counter omeprazole has provided partial relief of symptoms. There is no associated diaphoresis, dyspnea, hemoptysis, or nausea. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient takes no other medications and does not use tobacco or alcohol. Temperature is 36.7ºC (98.1ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 110/60, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination is remarkable for epigastric tenderness to palpation. Electrocardiogram and chest radiograph show no abnormalities. Laboratory evaluation shows microcytic anemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer intravenous pantoprazole and perform upper endoscopy
Prescribe oral pantoprazole and schedule outpatient upper endoscopy in two weeks
Order a CT of the chest with angiography
Administer aspirin and heparin and consider emergent reperfusion therapy

questions.solution:
This patient with a 6-hour history of chest pain, coffee-ground emesis (hematemesis), severe reflux symptoms, and microcytic anemia with a history of heartburn and dysphagia likely has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) that may be complicated by erosive esophagitis.

Patients with GERD who present with alarming (or alarm) features – gastrointestinal bleeding (hematemesis, melena, hematochezia, pallor), anorexia, unexplained weight loss, dysphagia, odynophagia, persistent vomiting, and the presence of gastrointestinal cancer in a first-degree relative – should have bloodwork and an EGD with biopsies done initially to rule out complications of GERD (like Barrett esophagus, erosive esophagitis, and underlying malignancy).

If there are complications of GERD, a multidisciplinary management approach is recommended; which may include medical therapy with PPIs, management of anemia (if present), GI consultation for possible endoscopic therapies that may include dilation or ablation, and surgical consultation for possible laparoscopic fundoplication. All patients with GERD should be counseled on lifestyle modifications, including weight loss and tobacco cessation. Many patients with significant GERD will need to undergo endoscopic surveillance and screening.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intravenous pantoprazole and perform upper endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prescribe oral pantoprazole and schedule outpatient upper endoscopy in two weeks:
Incorrect: This patient has severe reflux symptoms with dysphagia, coffee-ground emesis, and microcytic anemia despite intermittent treatment with omeprazole. This is likely an upper GI bleed secondary to complicated GERD with possible erosive esophagitis. This patient should be stabilized and treated with IV PPI and have an EGD within the next 12 hours for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.  
❌ Order a CT of the chest with angiography:
Incorrect: A pulmonary embolism can present with acute chest pain. However, given this patient’s history of coffee-ground emesis, normal ECG findings, and lack of respiratory signs or symptoms this diagnosis is unlikely.  
❌ Order a barium swallow test:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with an upper GI bleed, likely from erosive esophagitis. EGD should be performed to assess the source of bleeding and to treat it.  
❌ Administer aspirin and heparin and consider emergent reperfusion therapy:
Incorrect: Administration of aspirin and heparin and emergency reperfusion therapy is indicated for the management of an acute ST-elevation MI (STEMI). This patient has a normal electrocardiogram and thus does not have STEMI.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for a two-month history of hoarseness and a dry cough that worsens at night. The patient also reports a one-year history of heartburn that worsens after eating and a sour taste in the mouth relieved with over-the-counter antacids. There is no associated chest pain, nausea, vomiting, blood in the stool, or unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient drinks one glass of wine daily with dinner. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is pale. On cardiopulmonary auscultation, there are diffuse wheezes and normal heart sounds. There is mild tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Which of the following findings that is present in this patient, indicates the need for further studies prior to initiating treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient with nocturnal dry cough and hoarseness in the setting of heartburn and sour taste in the mouth has GERD with both typical symptoms and atypical extraesophageal symptoms. Patients without alarm features and a combination of typical and atypical GERD symptoms can be treated with proton pump inhibitors (PPI). However the presence of pallor is an alarm feature and may represent anemia. If the patient has microcytic anemia, then they should undergo EGD with biopsies to assess for complications of GERD or underlying malignancy.

GERD is a common chronic condition characterized by reflux of stomach contents into the esophagus. It is caused by a decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter or by anatomic disruption to the gastroesophageal junction. Predisposing factors include obesity, pregnancy, smoking, alcohol intake, and hiatal hernia.

GERD can have typical symptoms (heartburn, acid regurgitation, and sour/bitter taste in the mouth) and atypical extraesophageal symptoms (nocturnal dry cough, hoarseness, and throat clearing). Patients with typical symptoms or with a combination of typical and atypical symptoms can be started empirically on a trial of PPI. Patients with atypical symptoms only should undergo EGD with biopsies. Any patient with alarm features (gastrointestinal bleeding, iron deficiency anemia, anorexia, unexplained weight loss, dysphagia, odynophagia, persistent vomiting, and gastrointestinal cancer in a first-degree relative) should undergo EGD with biopsies initially to assess for Barrett esophagus, erosive esophagitis, esophageal stricture, or underlying malignancy.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Pallor on skin examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nocturnal cough:
Incorrect: This patient’s nocturnal dry cough and hoarseness in the setting of heartburn and sour taste in the mouth relieved with antacids is most likely due to GERD. Chronic nocturnal dry cough is a common extraesophageal symptom of GERD, and in the presence of typical GERD symptoms like heartburn and sour taste in the mouth, it can be treated with empiric PPI without first doing diagnostic testing.  
❌ Hoarseness:
Incorrect: This patient’s nocturnal dry cough and hoarseness in the setting of heartburn and sour taste in the mouth relieved with antacids is most likely due to GERD. Hoarseness is a common extraesophageal symptom of GERD, and in the presence of typical GERD symptoms like heartburn and sour taste in the mouth, it can be treated with empiric PPI without first doing diagnostic testing.  
❌ Sour taste in the mouth:
Incorrect: This patient’s nocturnal dry cough and hoarseness in the setting of heartburn and sour taste in the mouth relieved with antacids is most likely due to GERD. Sour taste in the mouth is a common symptom of GERD and is not an indication for further evaluation prior to treatment.  
❌ Wheezing on lung auscultation:
Incorrect: Diffuse bilateral wheezing in the setting of heartburn and sour taste in the mouth relieved with antacids is most likely due to GERD with extraesophageal signs and symptoms. GE reflux-triggered asthma can be an extraesophageal finding in GERD and is not an indication for further evaluation prior to treatment if typical symptoms are also present.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to 10 weeks of epigastric discomfort and heartburn. The patient also reports nocturnal cough and frequent throat clearing. There is no difficulty swallowing, melena, hematemesis, vomiting, or unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is unremarkable. BMI is 31 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is significant for pharyngeal erythema and epigastric tenderness to palpation. Which of the following is the best next step in the evaluation and management of this patient?

choices.text: Eight-week trial of proton pump inhibitor and lifestyle modifications
Eight-week trial of H2 receptor antagonist and lifestyle modifications
Six-month trial of lifestyle modifications with scheduled follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient presents with epigastric discomfort, heartburn, nocturnal cough, frequent throat clearing, and physical findings of pharyngeal erythema and epigastric tenderness to palpation. This likely indicates GERD with both typical and atypical symptoms.

The initial management of a patient presenting with typical GERD symptoms or typical and atypical GERD symptoms in the absence of alarm features consists of an eight-week trial of PPI treatment and lifestyle modifications. If adequate symptom control is achieved, GERD is diagnosed clinically and a maintenance dose of PPI therapy and lifestyle modifications can be continued with a follow-up surveillance EGD scheduled after one year. However, if there is no improvement after empiric therapy or if alarm features are present, EGD with biopsies is indicated to confirm the diagnosis and assess for possible complications. Patients with only atypical symptoms or a non-diagnostic EGD with high-suspicion for GERD should undergo a 24-hour esophageal impedance study with pH monitoring.

When complications of GERD exist, the approach should be multidisciplinary with GI consultation for possible endoscopic dilation or ablation of any precancerous lesions in Barrett esophagus and surgical consultation for possible fundoplication. Endoscopic surveillance and screening is needed and the timing of repeat endoscopy depends on the type of complication, response to management, and degree of dysplasia seen on biopsies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Eight-week trial of proton pump inhibitor and lifestyle modifications:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eight-week trial of H2 receptor antagonist and lifestyle modifications:
Incorrect: H2 receptor antagonists (e.g. famotidine) are less effective than PPIs for controlling acid reflux. They can be used as additional therapy for the management of patients diagnosed with GERD with incomplete resolution of symptoms on PPI therapy.  
❌ Six-month trial of lifestyle modifications with scheduled follow-up:
Incorrect: Although lifestyle modifications are important in the management of GERD, they are often not sufficient alone. Therefore, treatment with a PPI is also typically recommended.  
❌ Upper endoscopy (EGD) with biopsies:
Incorrect: EGD with biopsies is indicated for the evaluation of GERD in patients with alarm symptoms (e.g. chest pain, dysphagia, odynophagia, GI bleeding, frequent vomiting, unintentional weight loss), patients unresponsive to initial PPI therapy, and patients with only atypical symptoms. This patient does not have alarm symptoms and should undergo an initial trial of PPI therapy and lifestyle modifications.  
❌ Referral for surgical consultation:
Incorrect: Surgical management is reserved for patients who have severe GERD refractory to medical management and complications such as Barrett esophagus, esophageal stricture, or erosive esophagitis. Surgical management is not indicated in this patient.

questions.text:
An 84-year-old man presents to the emergency department from a nursing facility after a fall. Paramedics report that the nursing home staff reported that the patient has been more fatigued over the past 24 hours. The patient cannot provide a history due to baseline mental status from Alzheimer dementia which the nursing home staff reported as unchanged. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, Alzheimer dementia, and coronary artery disease. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 82/65 mmHg, pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical exam the patient is fatigued and ill-appearing. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids, piperacillin-tazobactam, and vancomycin; and bloodwork (including blood cultures) is obtained. Results of the initial work-up are detailed below. A central venous catheter is placed and norepinephrine is started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
The initial work-up and management of a patient with sepsis includes measuring lactic acid and drawing blood cultures as well as administering broad-spectrum antibiotics and IV hydration. Following initial management of hemodynamic instability, patients should undergo a thorough evaluation to determine the source of infection, which would include a thorough skin examination in this nursing home patient with Alzheimer dementia who recently had a fall.

Sepsis refers to an exaggerated immune response to infection associated with end organ dysfunction and potential shock. The infection can be bacterial, viral, or fungal and may originate from any tissue, which initiates a complex interplay between infectious virulence factors and host defense mechanisms.

Patients with sepsis typically present with tachycardia, fever, and often hypotension as well as associated symptoms secondary to the source of underlying infection. However, patients may also present with nonspecific symptoms, including fatigue, dizziness, or syncope, or, as in this case, they may be unable to provide a history due to altered mental status. If patients are able to provide a history, they should be questioned regarding symptoms of infection, including fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, dysuria, increased urinary frequency, confusion, and pain. Patients should also be questioned regarding recent procedures or trauma, which may serve as a nidus for bacteremia. Physical examination should attempt to reveal the source of infection and should include assessment of abdominal pain, respiratory distress, focal neurologic deficits, or skin lesions (such as abscesses or cellulitis).  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform thorough skin assessment:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform rapid sequence intubation:
Incorrect: While this patient is acutely ill, he is currently protecting his airway and is saturating well on room air. Rapid sequence intubation would be inappropriate management at this time.  
❌ Perform lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is an invasive procedure that can be used to diagnose underlying meningitis. While lumbar puncture may be appropriate if the source of sepsis is not identified, this patient should have a thorough skin examination to assess for an obvious source of infection first.  
❌ Perform bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy can be a useful tool to identify a specific causative organism in patients with signs and symptoms of pneumonia. This is an invasive procedure that is often not necessary. Additionally this patient’s chest radiograph shows no obvious acute pulmonary abnormalities.  
❌ Measure mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2):
Incorrect: SvO2 reflects the amount of oxygen left in the bloodstream following tissue circulation and is typically measured using a pulmonary artery catheter. While this could provide information regarding the tissue extraction of oxygen, it is not generally indicated as part of the evaluation or management of sepsis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 1-month history of “feeling down” and a 5 kg unintentional weight loss. The patient reports vague abdominal pain radiating to the back and several episodes of tender erythematous, and palpable cord-like veins on the extremities. The patient has not had night sweats, fever, vomiting, dysphagia, change in urine or stool color, or change in bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Family history is significant for a parent who died from breast cancer at the age of 35. The patient has a 13-pack-year smoking history. BMI is 27 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 135/89 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination is significant for epigastric tenderness on palpation and a erythematous, tender, cord over the right lower extremity. Laboratory findings are significant for an elevated CA19-9. Which of the following studies should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of vague abdominal pain radiating to the back, “feeling down”, weight loss, migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome), and an elevated CA-19-9. Together, these findings are suggestive of pancreatic cancer in the body or tail of the pancreas. The most appropriate initial step in the evaluation of this patient with suspected pancreatic cancer without jaundice is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast.

Pancreatic cancer has an insidious onset and is often diagnosed at an advanced stage. The diagnostic workup for pancreatic cancer includes a combination of clinical, laboratory, and imaging tests. Initial laboratory evaluation should include an assay of serum aminotransferases, alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, and CA 19-9 for establishing a baseline level for future monitoring. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast is the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected pancreatic cancer without signs or symptoms of obstruction. It can identify the tumor location, size, lymph node involvement, and abdominal/pelvic metastases. Other imaging modalities for evaluation include a transabdominal ultrasound and MRCP. If a pancreatic mass is identified on imaging, an endoscopic ultrasound or CT-guided biopsy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.

After the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer is established, further imaging studies are performed including CT, MRI, or PET CT to determine the cancer stage and classification of resectability. If imaging demonstrates a tumor contained within the pancreas without metastases, it is amenable to resection. Tumors that have grown into nearby tissues, but have not yet developed distant metastases are considered “borderline” resectable. Tumors that involve, encase, or occlude a major peripancreatic vessel as well as those with distant metastases are considered unresectable.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings suggestive of pancreatic cancer including a 1-month history of vague abdominal pain, weight loss, migratory superficial thrombophlebitis, and an elevated CA19-9. CT is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating patients with suspected pancreatic cancer.  
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy:
Incorrect:  Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is used in the evaluation of gastric malignancies, which can present with weight loss and vague abdominal pain. The presence of Trousseau syndrome, predisposing familial factor, and an elevated CA-19-9 makes the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer more likely.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is indicated in the management of patients with pancreatic cancer complicated by cholangitis and suspected pancreatic cancer with cholangitis. It is not used for the initial evaluation of suspected pancreatic cancer without cholangitis, as it is an invasive procedure associated with significant risks, including pancreatitis and bleeding. It should be reserved for diagnosis only in cases of obstructive cholangitis or when other imaging modalities are inconclusive.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is used in the evaluation of suspected colon cancer, not pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He has left-sided chest pain that is worse with inspiration and significant shortness of breath. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 100/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. On physical examination, no penetrating injuries are noted. However, there is significant bruising over the left chest wall. Additionally, the trachea is deviated to the right and there is decreased chest expansion on the left. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of suspected blunt force chest trauma, chest pain, and shortness of breath should raise concerns for pneumothorax. The physical examination findings of decreased chest wall expansion on the affected side and tracheal deviation in the opposite direction support the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax. Additionally, the patient’s tachypnea, hypoxemia, and tachycardia indicate instability.

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency. It occurs when air enters the pleural space via a one-way valve mechanism. Air is unable to escape and instead continues to accumulate with each breath, raising the pressure within the pleural space. These changes eventually result in shifting of the mediastinum and compression of the contralateral lung, vena cava, and heart. Consequently, patients develop hypoxia, hypotension, and eventual cardiopulmonary collapse.

When evaluating a patient with a pneumothorax, it is imperative to assess and manage the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs). This may include supplemental oxygen to maintain adequate oxygenation or intubation for respiratory failure. Additional measures include obtaining IV access and close vital sign monitoring (for heart rate, blood pressure, and pulse oximetry).

Ultimately, decompression is necessary. Decompression can be achieved with needle thoracostomy, which releases the trapped air. Many times, needle thoracostomy is performed before a chest radiograph can be completed due to the life-threatening nature of the condition. Decompression is usually followed up with chest tube placement and connection to continuous low-pressure suction to allow full reinflation of the affected lung.



Option Analysis

✅ Provide supplemental oxygen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform needle thoracostomy:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is concerning for tension pneumothorax. Needle thoracostomy should be performed. However, this patient’s hypoxemia should be addressed first with supplemental oxygen while obtaining the supplies for this procedure.
❌ Obtain a chest x-ray:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is concerning for tension pneumothorax. A chest radiograph can help confirm the diagnosis. However, the patient’s respiratory status should be addressed first.
❌ Obtain an arterial blood gas:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is concerning for tension pneumothorax. An arterial blood gas would not be needed in this scenario.
❌ Place a chest tube:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is concerning for tension pneumothorax. A chest tube may be required for management. However, this patient’s hypoxemia should be addressed first by administering supplemental oxygen.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of chest pain and progressive shortness of breath. The chest pain is sharp, right-sided, worse with inspiration, and was not precipitated by trauma. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals a tall thin man in no acute distress.
