Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient’s chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following lung examination findings would most likely be present?


Image reproduced from Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This patient has a right-sided pneumothorax and more specifically a primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP). This type of pneumothorax is predominantly seen in tall, thin, young men and is caused by a rupture of pleural blebs or bullae.

Affected patients typically present with sudden onset of sharp, pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. Physical examination findings can vary depending on the size of the pneumothorax, but may include diminished or absent breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion and reduced chest expansion on the affected side. These findings are due to the presence of air within the pleural space and subsequent decreased expansion of the affected lung. While it is rare for PSP to cause tension pneumothorax or clinical instability, it is nonetheless important to always perform an ABCDE assessment. Signs that may suggest associated tension pneumothorax include respiratory distress, hypotension, and tracheal deviation.

A chest radiograph can show a visible pleural edge without visible peripheral lung markings and a deep sulcus sign (abnormally prominent costophrenic angle secondary to air accumulation). Imaging can also determine the size, which coupled with clinical symptoms, will guide subsequent management.

Option Analysis

❌ Whispered pectoriloquy:
Incorrect: Whispered pectoriloquy describes the increased transmission of whispered sounds through the lung fields, which is usually due to lung consolidation (e.g. pneumonia). This patient’s chest radiograph demonstrates a pneumothorax, thus transmission of whispered sounds would be reduced or absent.
❌ Wheezing on auscultation:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest radiograph demonstrates a pneumothorax. Wheezing is typically indicative of obstructive airway diseases such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or asthma. Decreased or absent breath sounds are typically noted on the side of the pneumothorax secondary to diminished air movement.
❌ Crackles on auscultation:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest radiograph demonstrates a right-sided pneumothorax. Crackles are typically indicative of fluid within the alveoli, such as in pneumonia or pulmonary edema. Decreased or absent breath sounds are typically noted on the side of the pneumothorax secondary to diminished air movement.
❌ Increased tactile fremitus:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest radiograph demonstrates a pneumothorax. Air in the pleural space would reduce vibratory transmission to the chest wall. Thus, tactile fremitus over the affected area is usually reduced or absent in pneumothorax.
✅ Hyperresonance to percussion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend due to shortness of breath that started abruptly two hours ago. There is no associated cough or difficulty lying flat. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. The patient drinks one beer and smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 36.5 ºC (97.7 ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 123/78, respiratory rate is 20/min, and SpO2 is 94% on room air. Height is 6’ 4” (1.93 m) and weight is 180 lbs. (81.6 kg). Electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm without abnormalities. Which of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased resonance to percussion in the right upper lobe
Rales in the bilateral lung bases
Decrease in systolic blood pressure by 15 mmHg during inspiration
Posterior knee and calf pain with passive foot dorsiflexion

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient with sudden-onset dyspnea appears to be tall, thin, and actively smoking, all of which raise suspicion for primary spontaneous pneumothorax. The area of the pneumothorax (generally the upper lobes) will have diminished or absent breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion.  

Dyspnea is an incredibly common reason for patients to seek medical care. Its differential diagnosis is wide and includes both life-threatening and non-life-threatening pathologies. It accounts for anywhere from 3-9% of chief complaints in patients presenting to the emergency department in the United States.  

History should focus on the progression, chronicity, and associated symptoms. Smoking and occupational/environmental exposures should be determined. Chest pain may occur with cardiac and non-cardiac etiologies (e.g., pneumonia, pneumothorax, pulmonary embolism). Patients should be evaluated for historical features of acute coronary syndrome and congestive heart failure. Chest radiograph and ECG should be performed. Clear lungs and normal chest radiograph and ECG may suggest a metabolic cause, so history should focus on toxic ingestions, medication use, and anxiety.  

Physical exam should first focus on determining the severity of dyspnea (e.g., accessory muscle use). Look for systemic signs of congestive heart failure (e.g. jugular venous distention, pedal edema, displaced apical impulse). Abnormal lung sounds (e.g., crackles, rhonchi, wheezing) can help point toward specific diagnoses. 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased resonance to percussion in the right upper lobe:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rales in the bilateral lung bases:
Incorrect: This may be seen in pulmonary edema which often occurs in congestive heart failure. This patient is only 25 years old, the dyspnea started abruptly and there is no orthopnea, making congestive heart failure unlikely.
❌ Decrease in systolic blood pressure by 15 mmHg during inspiration:
Incorrect: This is considered pulsus paradoxus which occurs in diseases such as constrictive pericarditis and cardiac tamponade. Pressure on the right ventricle prevents it from accommodating increased blood inflow during inspiration. This increases pressure in the left ventricle, reducing cardiac output and blood pressure. This patient has no significant past medical history and normal sinus rhythm on ECG, and is not likely to have these conditions.
❌ Posterior knee and calf pain with passive foot dorsiflexion:
Incorrect: This maneuver describes the Homan sign, which was classically suggested to diagnose lower extremity deep venous thrombosis (DVT). This test has poor sensitivity and specificity and cannot rule out or rule in DVT. Moreover, the patient does not have risk factors for the development of DVT.
❌ Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema:
Incorrect: This may be seen in congestive heart failure (as well as liver failure, renal failure, and as a medication side effect). This patient is 25 years old without a significant past medical history. HIs dyspnea started abruptly and there is no orthopnea, making congestive heart failure and these other conditions unlikely.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with four hours of severe shortness of breath and wheezing. The patient has been hospitalized three times this year due to exacerbations of severe persistent asthma. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 136/89 mmHg, respirations are 28/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 88% on room air. The patient appears tachypneic and diffuse wheezing is present on pulmonary auscultation. Initial arterial blood gas shows pH 7.50 and pCO<sub>2</sub> 23 mmHg. The patient is given supplemental oxygen, ipratropium-albuterol nebulizer, methylprednisolone, and intravenous magnesium sulfate. The patient is re-evaluated one hour later. SpO<sub>2</sub> is 88% on room air. The patient appears fatigued and is no longer tachypneic. Only minimal wheezing is noted on repeat pulmonary auscultation. Repeat arterial blood gas shows pH 7.36 and pCO<sub>2</sub> 47. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Place the patient on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a severe asthma exacerbation and has evidence of impending respiratory failure requiring intubation. Patients with asthma exacerbations present with diffuse wheezing and tachypnea, frequently causing a respiratory alkalosis pattern on arterial blood gas analysis (ABG). If patients begin to appear fatigued, a repeat ABG should be performed. Patients with impending respiratory failure will demonstrate decreased minute ventilation, and the resultant pCO2 may seem “more normal” as it increases closer to or above 40 mmHg. As patients approach respiratory failure, wheezing may lessen due to less air moving through narrow and inflamed airways. Endotracheal intubation should be performed at this point to prevent respiratory failure.

Medical management for patients with asthma exacerbations includes IV corticosteroids, IV magnesium, and nebulized short-acting bronchodilators. Supplemental oxygen should be provided for hypoxemia, and bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP) can be used to help assist the work of breathing. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation should be pursued early in high-risk patients with rapid decline, as it provides airway protection and improved oxygenation and ventilation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Place the patient on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP):
Incorrect: CPAP can help with oxygenation and provide a small amount of positive pressure but will not provide adequate ventilatory support. This patient has impending respiratory failure and should be intubated and started on invasive mechanical ventilation.  
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer oral prednisone:
Incorrect: Initiation of steroids is indicated in asthma exacerbations; however, this patient has already received IV steroid therapy, and has evidence of impending respiratory failure requiring intubation.  
❌ Administer continuous nebulized albuterol:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of imminent respiratory failure requiring intubation.  
❌ Administer heliox:
Incorrect: Heliox is a breathing gas mixture of helium (He) and oxygen (O2) that can be used to treat asthma exacerbations. This patient has evidence of imminent respiratory failure requiring intubation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for acute decompensated heart failure. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis via an internal jugular venous catheter. The patient has challenging venous anatomy and has had significant difficulty with obtaining venous access in the past. On day 4 of the hospitalization, the patient develops chills and a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 113/74mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is significant for tenderness and erythema at the catheter site. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein. Blood cultures from two peripheral sites grow Gram-positive cocci in clusters. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Attempt central line lock therapy with IV vancomycin
Remove the central line and start IV vancomycin
Attempt central line lock therapy with IV gentamicin
Remove the central line and start IV caspofungin
Await blood culture sensitivities before starting antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient with an internal jugular venous catheter has fever, chills, exam findings suggesting a line infection, and Gram-positive bacteremia. Along with the absence of findings indicating another source of infection, central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) is the most likely cause of his condition.

All patients with CLABSI should have blood cultures drawn from two separate sites and, subsequently, be started on empiric IV antibiotics. Antifungals may be indicated in patients with predisposing risk factors (e.g. immunocompromised, femoral vein catheterization, Candida colonization). For patients with CLABSI complicated by hemodynamically instability, septic thrombophlebitis, or metastatic infection; the central venous catheter must be removed. For patients with uncomplicated CLABSI, catheter removal is ideal. In cases where it is not feasible, the catheter can be exchanged over a wire or can be retained with antibiotic lock therapy. Lock therapy consists of instilling a high concentration of antibiotic solution into the catheter lumen to eradicate any bacterial biofilm and reduce the risk of recurrence.

A positive response to treatment is evidenced by clinical resolution of symptoms and negative follow-up blood cultures. Lack of blood culture clearance may indicate the presence of a metastatic infection or another source of infection. Further evaluation (e.g. echocardiogram) is required in such cases.  

Option Analysis

✅ Attempt central line lock therapy with IV vancomycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Remove the central line and start IV vancomycin:
Incorrect: While this is a reasonable option in most patients with CLABSI (especially if related to septic shock), this patient has had significant difficulty in the past with venous access; therefore, an attempt should first be made to keep the central line.  
❌ Attempt central line lock therapy with IV gentamicin:
Incorrect: Gentamicin does not have significant Gram-positive coverage and would not treat the bacteria growing in this patient’s blood.  
❌ Remove the central line and start IV caspofungin:
Incorrect: Empiric caspofungin and catheter removal is indicated in the management of CLABSI in patients with risk factors for a fungal infection (e.g. immunocompromised, femoral vein catheterization, Candida colonization). This patient has none of these risk factors and blood cultures are not growing fungi.  
❌ Await blood culture sensitivities before starting antibiotics:
Incorrect: Waiting for blood culture sensitivities before starting antibiotics delays appropriate treatment and can lead to worse outcomes. Antibiotics can be started based on knowledge of the likely organism.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G1P0 woman at 16 weeks’ gestation presents to the primary care clinic with 3 days of dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. She has not had fevers, chills, flank pain, or vaginal discharge. She has no significant past medical history, and her current pregnancy has been uneventful. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient has mild suprapubic tenderness and no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis is positive for nitrites and leukocyte esterase and reveals 15-20 WBCs and 3-4 RBCs. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate empiric treatment with oral amoxicillin-clavulanate
Initiate empiric treatment with oral ciprofloxacin
Initiate empiric treatment with IV ceftriaxone

questions.solution:
This 30-year-old pregnant patient at 16 weeks’ gestation presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. Her symptoms and the presence of suprapubic tenderness, pyuria, positive leukocyte esterase, and nitrites on urinalysis are consistent with acute cystitis. Once a urine culture has been obtained, she should be started on empiric antibiotics, like amoxicillin-clavulanate, that covers the likely pathogens and is considered safe during pregnancy.

The best next step in the management of a pregnant patient with acute cystitis is to obtain a urine culture and sensitivity prior to initiating antibiotics and to begin empiric antibiotic treatment with a medication that covers potential pathogens and also is considered safe in pregnancy. Potential complications associated with UTIs during pregnancy including preterm labor, low birth weight, and acute pyelonephritis. Because of potential complications, pregnant patients with a clinical picture and urinalysis consistent with acute cystitis should be treated empirically with antibiotics. Some antibiotics such as fluoroquinolones and TMP-SMX should be avoided in pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects.

Uncomplicated UTIs are typically seen in otherwise healthy, non-pregnant women with normal genitourinary anatomy and function. The usual diagnostic and management approach includes urinalysis and, if indicated, empirical treatment with antibiotics such as nitrofurantoin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or fosfomycin.

Complicated UTIs occur in patients who have predisposing risk factors for the development of upper UTIs and those that have complications, such as bacteremia and sepsis. Patients may display signs or symptoms indicating the spread of infection beyond the bladder, such as fever, chills, flank pain, and CVA tenderness. Predisposing factors include being a biological male, elderly, immunocompromised, having a renal transplant, urinary obstruction, instrumentation, or an indwelling catheter. To diagnose a complicated UTI, a urine culture and sensitivity test is indicated prior to initiating antibiotics to guide antibiotic therapy. Additionally, imaging studies may be performed if anatomical abnormalities, obstructions, and complications are suspected.

Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) are defined as UTIs that occur in patients who have a urinary catheter in place or have had one removed within the previous 48 hours. These infections are typically caused by biofilm-producing hospital-acquired organisms. The urinary catheter provides a direct pathway for bacteria to enter the urinary tract. To address this issue, it is necessary to remove or replace the catheter and administer suitable antibiotics.   

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate empiric treatment with bactrim:
Incorrect: Bactrim and fluoroquinolones may have teratogenic effects and should be avoided in pregnant patients with UTIs.  
✅ Initiate empiric treatment with oral amoxicillin-clavulanate:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Initiate empiric treatment with oral ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, is not recommended during pregnancy due to potential teratogenic effects, including cartilage damage.  
❌ Initiate empiric treatment with IV ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used for managing lower urinary tract infections (UTIs) complicated by sepsis, as well as severe ascending UTIs. This patient's symptoms and findings are consistent with acute cystitis which can be managed as an outpatient with oral medication.  
❌ Obtain a renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Imaging is not indicated in this case, as this patient's presentation and urinalysis findings are consistent with a lower UTI. She has no flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, fevers, or chills that would indicate pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to worsening bilateral leg swelling. The patient first noticed swelling in both lower extremities last month. It has been worsening since then and lately it has been causing difficulty ambulating. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and morbid obesity. The patient’s only medication is losartan. Temperature is 37.4 ºC (99.3 ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 132/85, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation (SpO<sub>2</sub>) is 90% on room air. On pulmonary auscultation, there are bibasilar crackles. There is moderate pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally up to the distal tibias. The patient’s skin is erythematous and cool bilaterally up to the distal tibias as well. Bilateral lower extremity ultrasound shows a non-compressible small saphenous vein on the right. Further workup is pending. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient with bibasilar crackles and bilateral lower extremity edema most likely has congestive heart failure and needs diuresis with a loop diuretic such as furosemide.

Lower extremity (LE) edema is a common presentation for patients and is a feature seen with many different pathologies. Knowing the differential diagnosis and initial management of both unilateral and bilateral edema is important. If unilateral edema is not obvious, calf circumference of both legs can be measured and compared.

LE edema occurs most often due to impaired venous or lymphatic flow, or excessive distribution of fluid into the interstitial space. Obstruction (e.g., deep vein thrombosis or tumor mass effect) anywhere from the pelvis to the lower extremities can impair venous and lymphatic drainage. Venous insufficiency (e.g. varicose veins) and compartment syndrome can also cause impaired venous return. Cirrhosis and congestive heart failure both cause venous congestion which can cause excessive interstitial fluid accumulation. Loss of oncotic pressure, such as from nephrotic syndrome or protein-wasting enteropathy, can also cause lower extremity edema.

Life-threatening or limb-threatening diagnoses such as cardiogenic shock, acute liver failure, and compartment syndrome must be considered early and treated. Otherwise, treatment of edema is guided by the underlying cause. Loop diuretics (e.g., bumetanide, furosemide, torsemide) are very effective at treating edema. Long-term strategies to help with edema include compression stockings or wraps, elevation of the feet, and lower extremity exercises.

Option Analysis

❌ Enoxaparin:
Incorrect: This patient’s lower extremity ultrasound shows a unilateral superficial vein thrombosis, which does not require anticoagulation. In addition, this patient has bilateral lower extremity edema so this clot is unrelated to the current presentation.  
✅ Furosemide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are weak diuretics and should not be used for active diuresis of patients. They should be used for hypertension, or to augment diuresis with loop diuretics (e.g. using metolazone with furosemide).  
❌ Compression stockings:
Incorrect: Compression stockings would be a good long-term strategy for this patient to help reduce lower extremity swelling. However, this patient is volume overloaded as evidenced clinically by the low oxygen saturation and bibasilar crackles, and therefore needs diuresis first for CHF.  
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin can be used to treat uncomplicated cellulitis. Patients with bilateral lower extremity venous stasis changes, as this patient likely has, can have significant erythema and are often misdiagnosed with bilateral leg cellulitis. This patient is afebrile, has cool skin, and signs of congestive heart failure making cellulitis highly unlikely.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the office to follow up on recent blood testing. The patient has no previously diagnosed medical conditions. The patient has been feeling more fatigued recently but attributes it to working long hours. The patient drinks 6-8 cans of beer on weekday evenings and 10-12 cans on weekend days. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6° F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 132/74 mmHg. Physical exam shows palmar erythema and spider angiomas. Neurologic examination is normal. There is no distension of the abdomen and no abdominal tenderness to palpation. Lab results are shown below. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a small, nodular liver and minimal ascites. The patient is referred for upper endoscopy which shows medium varices with no signs of active bleeding. Which of the following medications should be started at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient presentation suggests a new diagnosis of cirrhosis. The patient currently has no complications and thus has compensated cirrhosis. Management of cirrhosis includes treating the underlying cause of cirrhosis, as well as preventing and treating complications. Once a patient has been diagnosed with cirrhosis, it is important to stage it and determine mortality risk using the Child-Pugh and Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) scores. Patients should be referred for evaluation for liver transplantation when the MELD score is greater than 10 or the patient has had signs of decompensation (e.g., variceal hemorrhage, ascites, hepatic encephalopathy).

All patients with cirrhosis should be screened with upper endoscopy (EGD) for gastroesophageal varices. Those with medium, large, or high-risk varices on endoscopy should be treated with non-selective beta-blockers and/or endoscopic band ligation for primary variceal bleeding prevention. Timing for repeat EGD is determined based on initial findings. Patients should be screened for hepatic encephalopathy at each visit by assessing neurologic function.

All patients with cirrhosis should be screened for hepatocellular carcinoma every 6 months with ultrasound. Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary malignancy in patients with cirrhosis. Cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis B and C infection is the most common risk factor.

Patients should have a paracentesis if they have new-onset moderate to severe ascites or if there is concern for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Patients should follow a strict low sodium diet (less than 2 g daily) and should be given furosemide plus spironolactone if they have moderate to severe ascites. If patients do not respond to medications then therapeutic paracentesis should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Beta-blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Proton pump inhibitor:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors are used in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease and peptic ulcer disease, not for prevention of variceal bleeding.  
❌ Octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide is used in the management of actively bleeding gastroesophageal varices. It causes vasoconstriction and reduces inflow of blood to the portal system. This patient has medium-sized, non-bleeding varices on upper endoscopy.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a diuretic that is used to manage ascites in patients with cirrhosis. It is used in combination with spironolactone, not as monotherapy. In addition, since the patient has minimal ascites, initial management can be salt restriction and abstinence from alcohol.  
❌ Lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is used in the management of hepatic encephalopathy. This patient is not presenting with neurologic signs or symptoms to support a diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to burning with urination for five days. This morning, the patient developed chills and pain in the right flank. The patient has not experienced nausea or vomiting, and review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. The patient has had three urinary tract infections in the last four years. The patient has no other significant medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 38.2 ºC (100.8 ºF), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 128/79 mmHg. On physical examination, the right costovertebral angle is tender to palpation. Pregnancy test is negative. Urine microscopy shows white blood cell casts and many bacteria. Serum white blood cell count is 14,000/mm<sup>3</sup>.  Serum basic metabolic panel shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for IV piperacillin-tazobactam therapy and IV fluids
Admit to the hospital for IV fluids and urology consultation
Administer intramuscular ceftriaxone and prescribe oral ciprofloxacin
Collect a urine culture and wait for results before starting antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient likely has acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis which can be treated as an outpatient or in the hospital. Outpatient treatment is reasonable for patients like this one who do not have significant medical comorbidities, are not pregnant, can adhere strictly to the treatment, and can tolerate oral antibiotics and hydration (i.e. not vomiting). She should be given a one-time dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone in the office and a prescription for an oral antibiotic such as ciprofloxacin (usually seven to ten days but in some cases five to seven days). A urine culture should also be sent to assess for bacterial resistance and to tailor treatment.
 

If patients have medical comorbidities, are significantly ill or in persistent pain, cannot tolerate PO, have had recent urologic manipulation, or are pregnant, they require hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics.

Complicated pyelonephritis occurs when the patient has functional or structural abnormalities, like neurogenic bladder or urinary obstruction due to nephrolithiasis or when they have specific host risk factors, such as immunosuppression, advanced age, or male sex. Patients with complicated pyelonephritis require hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics and hydration and a urology consultation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Admit to the hospital for IV piperacillin-tazobactam therapy and IV fluids:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis. She is not vomiting (i.e. can keep pills and water down), is not pregnant, doesn’t have comorbidities, and is not severely ill. Outpatient management would be more appropriate than hospitalization at this time.  
❌ Admit to the hospital for IV fluids and urology consultation:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis. She is not vomiting (i.e. can keep pills down), is not pregnant, doesn’t have comorbidities, and is not significantly ill. She does not require urology consultation and can be managed as an outpatient with oral antibiotics and hydration.  
❌ Prescribe seven days of nitrofurantoin:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis. While nitrofurantoin can be used to treat uncomplicated cystitis, it is ineffective at treating pyelonephritis.  
✅ Administer intramuscular ceftriaxone and prescribe oral ciprofloxacin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Collect a urine culture and wait for results before starting antibiotics:
Incorrect: Urine culture should be collected to identify the causative organism and associated antibiotic sensitivities, however this patient has an infection, and sending her home without antibiotics would be inappropriate. She should be started on empiric antibiotics.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to shortness of breath and lethargy. He also has sharp anterior chest pain. The patient was seen yesterday at an urgent care clinic and was prescribed azithromycin for a suspected upper respiratory infection. Past medical history is notable for mild intermittent asthma treated with an as needed albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 79/54 mmHg, respirations are 20/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 90% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic. The skin is cool to touch and pale, and capillary refill is delayed. On lung auscultation, there are bibasilar crackles and decreased breath sounds at both lung bases. Pressing on the right upper quadrant of the abdomen causes a prolonged elevation of the jugular venous pulse. Moderate non-pitting edema is present bilaterally up to the proximal tibias. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
There are three types of distributive shock, septic shock, anaphylactic shock, and neurogenic shock. Patients with distributive shock generally have skin that is warm and dry. Fever, infectious symptoms, and leukocytosis may indicate septic shock. Urticaria or an obvious trigger may indicate anaphylactic shock. A known brain or spinal cord injury may indicate neurogenic shock.

Patients with hypovolemic shock,  generally appear severely volume depleted. History may suggest significant volume loss (e.g. profuse diarrhea) in hypovolemic shock, or blood loss (e.g. hematemesis, melena) in hemorrhagic shock. On examination, these patients may have dry mucous membranes, skin tenting (decreased turgor), and poor urine output.

In patients with obstructive shock, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, or known DVT may point to massive pulmonary embolism (“massive” means causing hypotension and does not indicate the clot size). The presence of the Beck triad (hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds) suggests cardiac tamponade. Localized decreased breath sounds, severe dyspnea, and a deviated trachea suggest tension pneumothorax.

Patients with cardiogenic shock, like the patient in this case, generally appear “cold and wet,” unlike the “warm and dry” presentation of distributive shock. Poor cardiac output causes decreased perfusion and results in skin that is cool to the touch. Poor cardiac output and impaired ventricular filling also leads to volume overload. Substernal chest pressure may suggest myocardial infarction. This patient likely has new onset heart failure, which in young patients, may be due to severe viral myocarditis.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Ruptured apical bleb:
Incorrect: This is a frequent cause of secondary pneumothorax and could potentially lead to tension pneumothorax, a cause of obstructive shock. This patient’s crackles and decreased breath sounds are symmetric, and the clinical findings and history of preceding viral infection support a diagnosis of viral myocarditis and cardiogenic shock.  
✅ Viral myocarditis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial pneumonia:
Incorrect: Severe bacterial pneumonia can lead to septic shock. This patient is afebrile, volume overloaded, and has cool skin to the touch. This supports cardiogenic shock rather than septic shock which is a type of distributive shock.  
❌ Anaphylaxis caused by azithromycin:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis can be delayed and does not always occur immediately. However, this patient is volume overloaded, has no wheezing, and has skin that is cool to the touch. This supports cardiogenic shock rather than anaphylactic shock.  
❌ Spinal cord injury:
Incorrect: Brain or spinal cord injuries can lead to neurogenic shock from impaired vascular tone. Like other types of distributive shock, these patients generally have warm and flushed skin without significant volume overload.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of respiratory distress. About 30 minutes ago the patient was eating lunch at a restaurant with a group of friends when she suddenly started feeling shortness of breath. The patient has a history of asthma and eczema. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 93/64 mmHg, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. The patient can speak in full sentences but uses accessory muscles to breathe. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral wheezes. There is an urticarial rash on the bilateral upper extremities. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This young woman’s presentation of shortness of breath, increased respiratory effort, and an urticarial rash after exposure to a likely unknown inciting agent while eating is highly suggestive of anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine, prostaglandins, cytokines). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

If anaphylaxis is suspected, immediate intramuscular epinephrine (typically in the lateral thigh) should be administered, even before obtaining a history and physical examination. Epinephrine raises blood pressure, reduces bronchospasm, and counteracts other effects of circulating inflammatory mediators.
 

Following administration of epinephrine, an ABCDE (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) assessment should be performed to determine if the patient is unstable or stable. If the patient is unstable, stabilization of the airway and volume resuscitation should occur. Endotracheal intubation should be performed if there is concern for impending respiratory failure; this should be done as soon as possible since airway edema can progress quickly and make intubation difficult. Obtaining IV access is critically important as well; if the patient is hypotensive, IV fluids for volume resuscitation should be started as soon as possible.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intramuscular administration of epinephrine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Intravenous diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine that can help to relieve itching and hives in anaphylaxis, but it does not address the potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension, respiratory distress, and airway obstruction. It can be administered once epinephrine is given.   
❌ Administer nebulized albuterol   :
Incorrect: Nebulized albuterol is a bronchodilator that can help to relieve bronchoconstriction, which is a common symptom of anaphylaxis. However, it does not address the other potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension and airway obstruction. It can be given once epinephrine is administered.   
❌ Intravenous fluids:
Incorrect: Administering IV fluids may be necessary to maintain blood pressure in patients with anaphylaxis, but it is not the most appropriate immediate next step in the management of anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis is a rapidly progressive and potentially life-threatening condition that requires immediate treatment with epinephrine to prevent further deterioration.   
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: Respiratory distress can occur in anaphylaxis, as seen in this patient, and endotracheal intubation may be necessary for this patient. However, epinephrine should be administered first as this may lead to significant improvement in the patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department by her partner for evaluation of shortness of breath. The patient has a history of asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient is able to speak in full sentences and is not using accessory muscles to breathe. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral wheezes. There is an urticarial rash seen on the bilateral upper extremities, abdomen, and trunk. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with shortness of breath and an urticarial rash after a likely exposure to an unknown inciting agent has anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., tryptase, tumor necrosis factor, histamine, and prostaglandins). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

Laboratory findings can sometimes be useful in patients presenting with anaphylaxis; however, it is a clinical diagnosis and clinical signs and symptoms must be recognized early to prevent catastrophic complications. Laboratory studies may occasionally show signs of end-organ damage but are not necessary for the diagnosis of anaphylaxis. An elevated serum tryptase level will confirm the diagnosis if it is not already clear by the history and physical. However, tryptase levels do not peak until 1 to 1.5 hours after the onset of symptoms. Elevated histamine and tumor necrosis factor levels can be indicators of anaphylaxis but are not routinely measured.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased serum tryptase   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Increased serum immunoglobulin A   :
Incorrect: IgE is an immunoglobulin that plays a critical role in allergic reactions and is elevated in patients with atopic conditions and allergies. During anaphylaxis, IgE mediates the activation of mast cells and basophils leading to the release of histamine and other mediators. IgA does not play a role in anaphylaxis.   
❌ Decreased tumor necrosis factor   :
Incorrect: Tumor necrosis factor is one of the pro-inflammatory cytokines that is released and elevated during anaphylaxis.   
❌ Decreased histamine   :
Incorrect: Histamine is one of the pro-inflammatory mediators, along with tryptase and tumor necrosis factor, that are released and elevated during anaphylaxis.   
❌ Decreased prostaglandins   :
Incorrect:  Prostaglandin is one of the pro-inflammatory mediators, along with tryptase and tumor necrosis factor, that are released and elevated during anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. About 30 minutes ago the patient was stung by a bee while hiking and quickly became short of breath and vomited once. The patient has a known allergy to bee stings but misplaced her epinephrine auto-injector several months ago. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 115/65 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. The patient is not using accessory muscles but appears to have difficulty breathing. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezes bilaterally. There is an urticarial rash on the bilateral upper extremities. Paramedics administered one dose of intramuscular epinephrine in the ambulance while en route to the hospital. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of a second dose of intramuscular epinephrine

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with shortness of breath, vomiting, and an urticarial rash after exposure to a known inciting agent has anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine, prostaglandins, cytokines). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

If anaphylaxis is suspected, intramuscular epinephrine should be administered immediately (typically in the lateral thigh), even before obtaining a history and physical examination. Epinephrine raises blood pressure, reduces bronchospasm, and counteracts other effects of circulating inflammatory mediators.

It is important for clinicians to recognize that patients may need multiple doses of epinephrine (up to 3). Most patients respond to a single dose of IM epinephrine, particularly if it is given promptly after the onset of symptoms. IM epinephrine may be repeated at 5- to 15-minute intervals if there is no response or inadequate response. In severe cases where IM epinephrine is inadequate, a slow, continuous infusion of epinephrine can be used.

H1 and H2 antihistamines and corticosteroids can be given as adjunctive therapy with epinephrine but they should not be given alone. They do not prevent or treat bronchoconstriction or hypotension that can be associated with anaphylaxis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of a second dose of intramuscular epinephrine   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Immediate endotracheal intubation   :
Incorrect: While respiratory distress and airway obstruction can occur in anaphylaxis, this patient is not using accessory muscles to breathe and should be given a second dose of epinephrine. Most patients improve after 1 or 2 doses, although up to 3 doses can be given.   
❌ Administration of intravenous fluids   :
Incorrect: Administration of IV fluids may be necessary to maintain blood pressure in patients with anaphylaxis; however, this patient is not currently hypotensive. This patient should immediately be given a second dose of epinephrine since symptoms have not resolved with the first dose.   
❌ Administration of intravenous diphenhydramine   :
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine that can help to relieve itching and hives, but it does not address the potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension, respiratory distress, and airway obstruction.   
❌ Administration of nebulized albuterol   :
Incorrect: Nebulized albuterol is a bronchodilator that can help to relieve bronchoconstriction, which is a common symptom of anaphylaxis. However, it does not address the other potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension and airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with a history of cerebral palsy is admitted to the hospital for treatment of a catheter-associated urinary tract infection. The patient is nonverbal and bedbound. On hospital day three the patient becomes short of breath. On assessment, SpO2 is 87% on room air and improves to 98% on 2 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. Tracheal deviation to the right is observed. Auscultation demonstrates minimal breath sounds over the right lung. CBC and BMP are obtained and the results are within normal limits. Chest radiograph demonstrates opacification of the right lung. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has atelectasis of the right lung, which refers to partial or complete collapse of a portion of the lung resulting in poor aeration (ventilation) and gas exchange. It is common in hospitalized patients, especially following intra-abdominal or intra-thoracic surgery. Most patients develop atelectasis in small portions of the lung or in a specific lobe. Patients with impaired coughing (e.g., cerebral palsy, dementia, severe chronic lung disease) are prone to mucus plugging. When this occurs in a mainstem bronchus, atelectasis can occur in the entire lung, manifesting as an opacified hemithorax. If the trachea deviates toward the opacification, this indicates volume loss (e.g., mucus plug, obstructing mass). If the trachea deviates away from the opacification, this indicates something such as massive hemothorax or pleural effusion.

Atelectasis can be treated with deep breathing exercises, incentive spirometry, and patient ambulation. Atelectasis due to mucus plugging, as is the likely case in this patient,  should be treated with chest physiotherapy (e.g., flutter valve, intermittent percussive ventilation, manual percussive therapy). Medications such as guaifenesin or nebulized hypertonic saline can also be used to assist with mucus clearance. Bronchoscopy can also be performed to remove large mucus plugs and assist with lung reinflation.

Option Analysis

✅ Chest physiotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chest tube placement:
Incorrect: Chest tube placement would be appropriate if hemothorax were present. In the absence of trauma, this diagnosis is unlikely.
❌ Needle decompression thoracostomy:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if tension pneumothorax were suspected. Tension pneumothorax would cause the trachea to deviate away from the affected lung and would not demonstrate an opacified hemithorax.
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: This patient is requiring minimal supplemental oxygen and does not require intubation.
❌ Administer IV furosemide:
Incorrect: A massive pleural effusion involving an entire lung would more likely cause the trachea to deviate away from the opacified lung. This patient's history and exam do not support volume overload.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by EMS after a syncopal episode at home. She has been experiencing bright red blood per rectum for the past 24 hours. Temperature is 99.4°F, blood pressure is 80/48 mmHg, pulse is 130/minute, respiratory rate is 22/minute, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. While in transport, 2 large bore IVs were placed and she was given 1-liter normal saline bolus. On arrival at the emergency department, her blood pressure is 95/50 mmHg and heart rate is 120/minute. She is given another liter of normal saline. She has a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. She has not had any previous colonoscopies. Physical examination reveals a pale woman who appears ill. She does not have abdominal tenderness to palpation. Rectal examination reveals bright red blood in the rectal vault. Hemoglobin is 8.5. Her blood pressure responds well to IV fluid resuscitation. Which of the following diagnostic studies should be performed next?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with hematochezia with hemodynamic instability. She has already begun to receive fluid resuscitation with improvements in her blood pressure. After stabilization, a focused history and physical examination should be performed, and initial laboratory tests should be sent. Upper endoscopy should then be performed since the source of her GI bleeding is unclear and large brisk upper GI bleeds can cause hematochezia and hemodynamic instability. If the upper endoscopy fails to reveal a source of bleeding, a colonoscopy should then be performed.

A Colonoscopy has been shown to identify the source of lower GI bleeds in more than 75% of patients. A colonoscopy should be done within 24 hours of admission, following adequate bowel prep, if a lower GI bleed is suspected. If the patient is not stable enough for a colonoscopy or has ongoing massive bleeding, other forms of evaluation should be considered such as CT angiography and tagged red blood cell scan.

Option Analysis

✅ Capsule endoscopy:
Correct: Capsule endoscopy can be used to evaluate the small intestine if upper endoscopy and colonoscopy fail to reveal the source of GI bleeding.  
❌ CT angiography:
Incorrect: CT angiography is a diagnostic modality that can be used for localizing the bleeding site. In this patient, an upper GI source of bleeding, that may be diagnosed and treated with upper endoscopy, should first be ruled out.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy is the diagnostic test of choice in all patients presenting with an acute lower GI bleed. In patients, like this one, with an unclear source of bleeding, upper endoscopy should be performed first, and then if it is negative, colonoscopy can be performed.  
❌ Tagged red blood cell scan:
Incorrect: A tagged red blood cell scan can sometimes be used to help localize the site of bleeding if other modalities have not found the source.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis can further evaluate for abdominal pathology or complications, but upper endoscopy and colonoscopy should be performed first to locate the source of bleeding.

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents to the office for evaluation of frequent urination and increased thirst for 6 months without associated dysuria or hematuria. She has had vaginal itching with increased thick, white vaginal discharge without odor. She has used over the counter treatments 2 times in the past 3 months to treat possible yeast infections, but the discharge and itching returns. She has no known medical history and does not have a primary care provider. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus in her mother and older sister, as well as hypothyroidism in her sister. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 82/minute, blood pressure is 140/82 mmHg, BMI is 30. Skin examination reveals multiple skin tags on her neck and axilla and darkened, velvety skin on her neck. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable. On genitourinary examination, she has vulvar erythema and edema, with white, thick discharge. Wet mount of the vaginal discharge confirms the presence of candida. Which of the following laboratory studies is most likely to confirm this patient’s primary diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic symptoms of diabetes mellitus (polyuria and polydipsia) and recurrent yeast infections. Hyperglycemia increases the risk for bacterial and fungal infections which explains her recurrent yeast infections. Combined with her physical examination findings and family history, diabetes mellitus type 2 is the most likely diagnosis.
 

The diagnosis of diabetes mellitus can be made using the glycated hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) or plasma glucose concentration (fasting, random, or 2 hour glucose tolerance test). HbA1C is the most widely used test to estimate mean glucose using glycated hemoglobin. The level of glycated hemoglobin shows the mean plasma glucose level during the previous 1-3 months. HbA1C values 5.7-6.4% are consistent with a diagnosis of pre-diabetes, while values ≥ 6.5% confirm a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. Prediabetes is a precursor to diabetes in which patients may be asymptomatic with elevated blood sugars. It is important to identify and intervene to prevent progression to diabetes mellitus.

Fasting plasma glucose is obtained from a blood sample after the patient has fasted for 8 hours. Values 100-125 mg/dL are consistent with a diagnosis of pre-diabetes, while a level ≥ 126 mg/dL is consistent with diabetes mellitus.  A glucose tolerance test measures plasma glucose levels both before and 2 hours after a patient has ingested 75 grams of glucose. Pre-diabetes is diagnosed with levels 140-199 mg/dL. While diabetes mellitus is diagnosed when levels are ≥ 200 mg/dL. Lastly, a random blood glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL in patients presenting with classic symptoms of diabetes mellitus (polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia and weight loss) is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus.

Obtaining levels for glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD65 antibodies), islet cell (ICA2 antibodies), and C-peptide helps to differentiate between type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Positive GAD65 or ICA2 antibodies with low C-peptide levels confirms a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Option Analysis

✅ Hemoglobin A1C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urinalysis:
Incorrect: The patient is presenting with complaints of frequent urination, and also has vaginal discharge and itching. While a urinalysis is reasonable to evaluate for urinary tract infection, the most likely underlying diagnosis is type 2 diabetes mellitus which would be confirmed with a hemoglobin A1C  
❌ Complete Blood Count:
Incorrect: This patient presents with frequent urination without dysuria, increased thirst, and recurrent vaginal yeast infections. Type 2 diabetes mellitus is the most likely underlying condition which can be diagnosed with a hemoglobin A1C.  
❌ Complete Metabolic Panel:
Incorrect: Complete metabolic panel should be done as part of the workup in patients diagnosed with diabetes. Assessing renal function and having a baseline is important, but it would not diagnose diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Thyroid panel:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a history of yeast infections, polyuria, polydipsia, and a family history of diabetes mellitus suggesting a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus type 2. This would not be diagnosed with a thyroid panel.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of cough and shortness of breath. The patient’s spouse is at the bedside and reports that the patient currently resides in a nursing facility due to advanced multiple sclerosis. The patient has had increased difficulty swallowing over the past week. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 114/min, blood pressure is 148/91 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination is significant for a chronically ill-appearing male with contractures in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. The patient is coughing but has no significant increased work of breathing. Blood work is obtained and is pending, and chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This chronically ill patient presents for evaluation of cough, shortness of breath, and recent increased difficulty swallowing. Chest radiography shows a left lower lobe opacity, confirming aspiration pneumonia. Based on this patient's clinical history and exam and radiography findings, the best treatment to initiate is ampicillin-sulbactam.

Aspiration pneumonia and pneumonitis share many overlapping clinical features. Symptoms include chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough, and fever. Physical examination may show labored breathing, and rales or decreased breath sounds may be heard in the gravity-dependent portions of the lung, typically the right lung base. Aspiration pneumonia is typically gradual in onset and is usually assciated with impaired swallowing conditions (e.g. stroke, seizure disorder, motor neuron disease). Aspiration pneumonitis generally develops acutely, is more likely to be a witnessed event, and usually occurs in patients with impaired consciousness (e.g. severe alcohol intoxication or following administration of general anesthesia).

Chest radiography along with history and physical exam can be used to make the diagnosis. Chest radiography can show infiltrates in the dependent portions of the lungs, primarily the right basal segments of the lower lobes (if the patient has been upright) or the superior segments of the lower lobe/posterior segments of the upper lobes (if the patient has been supine). Appropriate treatment for uncomplicated aspiration pneumonia includes ampicillin-sulbactam or respiratory fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin or moxifloxacin).  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer ampicillin-sulbactam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy may be indicated for intubated patients for airway clearance as well as if further diagnostic testing is needed to identify an infectious organism. Bronchoscopy is not indicated for this patient as a presumptive diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia can be made.  
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable with adequate room air oxygen saturation and no respiratory distress. Endotracheal intubation is not indicated at this time.  
❌ Administer azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin alone does not offer adequate coverage for aspiration pneumonia. It is generally given in conjunction with a beta-lactam (e.g. ceftriaxone) for community-acquired pneumonia or aspiration pneumonia without suspicion for anaerobic bacteria involvement.  
❌ Bi-level positive airway pressure:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable with adequate room air oxygen saturation and no respiratory distress. Bi-level positive airway pressure is not indicated at this time.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is seen in the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain. For the past five days, the patient has had a dull ache in the right upper quadrant that does not change with position or eating. The patient has been drinking 13 beers per day for the past three months and his last drink was two days ago. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 126/min, blood pressure is 155/98 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is tremulous and anxious. Bloodwork is obtained and results are shown below. Abdominal ultrasound shows increased echogenicity and surface nodularity of the liver with patent venous flow into the liver. The gallbladder and pancreas are not well-visualized due to overlying bowel gas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Laboratory Test
Result
White blood cell count  
4.3 cells/mm3   
Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL  
AST
210 U/L  
ALT
110 U/L  
Total bilirubin  
7.0 mg/dL  
Prothrombin time  
18 seconds  
Lipase
180 U/L (nl: 0-160 U/L)
questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with RUQ abdominal pain, elevated transaminases, elevated bilirubin, and elevated prothrombin time, indicating alcohol-induced hepatitis.

Alcohol use disorder can cause hepatitis (such as in this patient), cirrhosis (with chronic long-term use), and pancreatitis. The patient's history can generally differentiate between these three etiologies. Alcohol-induced hepatitis (and sometimes cirrhosis) will typically cause RUQ pain that does not change with eating or position. Pancreatitis can cause RUQ or LUQ pain but classically causes epigastric pain that worsens with eating and with lying down. Older age and a longstanding history of alcohol use increases the likelihood of cirrhosis. Younger patients or those with shorter duration of alcohol use are more likely to have hepatitis or pancreatitis. Nausea, vomiting, and weight loss can be common features due to the underlying alcohol use disorder. Patients with any of these three pathologies may also present with alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Physical examination in alcohol-induced hepatitis and alcohol-induced pancreatitis may be similar; however, tenderness to palpation is more likely to be in the epigastric region with pancreatitis. Patients with hepatitis may have scleral icterus or jaundice which would not be present with pancreatitis. Patients may also show signs of alcohol withdrawal including tremulousness, anxiety/agitation, confusion, and hallucinations. Patients with severe alcohol-induced hepatitis may also have asterixis. Patients with cirrhosis will often have other physical examination stigmata of cirrhosis such as ascites, gynecomastia, palmar erythema, and spider angiomata.  

Option Analysis

✅ Alcohol-induced hepatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alcohol-induced pancreatitis:
Incorrect: This patient’s pain description is more suggestive of hepatobiliary pathology rather than pancreatitis. In addition, his blood work, including the AST to ALT ratio, indicates alcohol-induced hepatitis.  
❌ Acute cholecystitis:
Incorrect: While not completely ruled out, the pain description is much more suggestive of alcohol-induced hepatitis, and the lack of fever and leukocytosis make cholecystitis much less likely. Patients with biliary pathology are more likely to describe a colicky pain that worsens with eating.  
❌ Alcohol-induced cirrhosis:
Incorrect: The ultrasound findings suggest changes that can be seen in both cirrhosis and alcohol-induced hepatitis. Liver imaging should be repeated in a few months to reassess. While cirrhosis is possible in this case, it is less likely to be seen in a 25-year-old with alcohol use disorder.  
❌ Portal vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: This could cause a similar presentation; however, the portal vein is patent on ultrasound which rules this out.
